abstract: The failure of our naval vessels to capture the Alabama before this time has caused the most erroneous impressions to prevail relative to the doings of the Navy Department. The public has been so far misled in this matter that it is only right to state the facts of the case. Notwithstanding the still unchecked success of Capt. SEMMS, it is beyond contradiction that the history of the American, English or French Navy furnishes no parallel for the feats accomplished by our naval authorities in connection  with the much-dreaded pirate. In times of peace we had six Navy-yards, which were pretty generally kept going, providing for the current wants of the forty men-of-war we used to have in commission. When war came upon us, Norfolk and Pensacola were swept away, leaving only New-York, Philadelphia, Boston and Portsmouth, N.H., (Washington being an ordnance yard chiefly,) available. And these have had to fit out a series of squadrons, in fifteen months, which could not be armed elsewhere in the same time. We have now over sixty vessels more in commission than England, and to keep their wants supplied, to keep them repaired always relieved at the proper time, and to have ships approaching completion as others wear out, is one item of the daily work of the four Navy-yards named. Besides doing it well, time has been found, within the brief space of three months, to equip a fleet for the purpose of overhauling the Alabama, which is now represented in every sea. In order to estimate the extraordinary energy required to accomplish this it is only necessary to know that not one vessel in forty at Mr. WELLE's command would be worth anything for the business. The proper ships had to be first picked out, and as they all need great alterations, and as some of them were at the furthest end of the blockade, time was required to bring them home and put them in proper trim. And now, after twelve weeks' work, the following fleet is on the ocean, every vessel belonging to it a match for the Alabama, save in speed, and several well able to overhaul her:

abstract: Our advices from Tennessee, this morning, are extremely important. Gen. ROSECRANS made a general advice with his army on Monday, against the rebel army at Murfreesboro, and at last accounts up to Tuesday, heavy fighting was going on at various points. The rebels were pushed back seven or eight miles on Monday, a portion of Gen. McCOOK's Corps having a sharp brush with the enemy beyond Nolinsville.
lead_paragraph: Our advices from Tennessee, this morning, are extremely important. Gen. ROSECRANS made a general advice with his army on Monday, against the rebel army at Murfreesboro, and at last accounts up to Tuesday, heavy fighting was going on at various points. The rebels were pushed back seven or eight miles on Monday, a portion of Gen. MCCOOK's Corps having a sharp brush with the enemy beyond Nolinsville. The enemy here v[???]ted much ammunition during an hour's can[???]ing, and finally lost a gun and [???]aisson th[???] a dexterous flank movement made by the One Hundred and First Ohio. Our army, on Tuesday, was sweeping down all the roads leading to Murfreesboro, and heavy artillery firing w[???] heard on the Nolinsville road, where MCC[???]K's progress was disputed by the rebel Gen. [???]PEE. A general engagement was imminent, a[???] as probably been fought before this time.

abstract: Magazines or January
snippet: Magazines or January
lead_paragraph: -- The Atlantic for January has several notable articles -- articles so much above the standard which our magazines seem by some mutual agreement to have adopted, as to deserve special and honorable mention. The first paper of the number, "Happiest Days," by the lady whose pen-name is "Gail Hamilton," furnishes subject for a more extended notice than these columns will allow. It is such a complete and lively refutation, and, withal, such an indignant hurling back of that marrowless platitude about "Childhood's Happy Days," which every one feels bound to fire off on the least provocation, that a committee of grateful children should wait upon the authoress and bring her the best and rarest gifts that Santa Claus brings, as an eternal retaining fee. It is so ridiculously absurd that the poor little mannikin, that has to have its nose rubbed up the wrong way in morning face-washings, and pulled down by unnecessary applications of officious handkerchiefs, as though it were the rope of a cathedral bell -- that has all its best thoughts and carefully considered opinions nipped in the brain-bud before they can be blossomed forth in speech by the unasked-for information that "little boys should be seen and not heard," -- whose heads have to submit to as much patting as cakes of butter at the hands of unctuous old gentlemen and snuffy old ladies -- who are always helped at table to wing-lips and drumsticks and prohibited from pie on account of their health -- whose sympathies are worked upon by missionaries of all sexes and uncertain ages, who persuade them to give the quarter they intended to buy a coveted toy with, to further the education of some miraculous little pagan whose name puzzles them in dreams -- it is so ridiculously absurd, we say, selling the cruelty of the thing wholly aside, that in addition to all these and ten thousand other afflictions, the young voyager upon the sea of life should be constantly assured that he is seeing his happiest days, and taught to look forward to the future with a dim, undefined dread, that we have no words to express the indignation with which the mere thought of the outrage moves us, and so refer the reader to the sprightly, sparkling and profoundly logical and philosophical essay of "Gail Hamilton" on the subject.

snippet: Edgerton vs. Bloomer and Macbeth; Contract; Case vs. Bradburn; Indorser's Liability; United States vs. C. C. Pinckney, schr.; Capture of, and Owner Alleged Loyal; Alabama, List of Vessels in Pursuit
lead_paragraph: The United States vs. The schooner Gen. C.C. Pinckney and her cargo. -- This vessel was captured by the Ottawa on May 6, 1862, about fifty miles from Charleston Bar, having come out of Charleston under the rebel flag. She was laden with cotton and resin. She was registered to Hermann Koppel, a citizen of the Confederate States, on April 18, 1862, as having been conveyed to him on April 7, 1862, in Charleston, by a resident and citizen of that place. These papers, her crew list and the appointment of Koppel as master, were all authenticated by the rebel authorities at Charleston.

abstract: The Board of Aldermen met at 1 o'clock yesterday afternoon, and concurred in making the appropriations (amounting to $47,197,06, and chiefly for interest on the Family Aid and Union Defence Fund bonds) which the Comptroller recently discovered had been omitted at the time the regular appropriation bill was passed. The Mayor's veto on the resolution increasing the salaries of the Police Justices to $5,000 per annum, was taken up and overruled.
lead_paragraph: The Board of Aldermen met at 1 o'clock yesterday afternoon, and concurred in making the appropriations (amounting to $47,197,06, and chiefly for interest on the Family Aid and Union Defence Fund bonds) which the Comptroller recently discovered had been omitted at the time the regular appropriation bill was passed. The Mayor's veto on the resolution increasing the salaries of the Police Justices to $5,000 per annum, was taken up and overruled. The Comptroller reported that, for the fortnight ending on last Saturday, $67,836 had been disbursed from the Relief Fund, to 16,549 families, of whom 16,450 were adults, and 22,237 children. The Board adjourned till 10 o'clock A.M. on Friday,

abstract: INTERNAL REVENUE TAX NEWWARK. The books of Mr. GEo. A. HALSEY, Assessor for the Fifth District of New-Jersey, comprising Essex and Hudson Counties, show the following totals of taxes assessed on manufacturers products the same being exclusive of the tax for licenses: September, 65,000; October, $74,000; November, $65,000. Of the above, the highest amounts paid are for ale and beer, some manufacturers paying $3,000 per month.
lead_paragraph: INTERNAL REVENUE TAX -- NEWWARK. -- The books of Mr. GEO. A. HALSEY, Assessor for the Fifth District of New-Jersey, comprising Essex and Hudson Counties, show the following totals of taxes assessed on manufacturers products -- the same being exclusive of the tax for licenses: September, 65,000; October, $74,000; November, $65,000. Of the above, the highest amounts paid are for ale and beer, some manufacturers paying $3,000 per month. Next soap and candles, then leather, of various kinds, saddlery and harness, clothing, hats, trunks, jewelry, &c. One trunk manufacturer in the Second Ward was assessed $2,500 in the month of September. It would hardly be safe to base a calculation of the revenue which will accrue in the country at large, upon the above figures, as the manufacturing interests of Newark are known to be of extraordinary value and importance.

abstract: FINAL MEETING OF THE BROOKLYN COMMON COUNCIL. The final meeting of the Common Council for the present year was held yesterday afternoon, the object being to confirm the appointment of Commissioners of Deeds for 1863. The names of 104 were presented, when Alderman STRONG moved that all whose names appeared on the list of last year be reappointed, which was adopted. The Board then adjourned sine die.
lead_paragraph: FINAL MEETING OF THE BROOKLYN COMMON COUNCIL. -- The final meeting of the Common Council for the present year was held yesterday afternoon, the object being to confirm the appointment of Commissioners of Deeds for 1863. abstract: In anticipation of the Emancipation Proclamation which the President is expected to issue to-day, the colored people of this City held a grand jubilee last night at Shiloh Presbyterian Church, corner of Prince and Marion streets. By 9 o'clock in the evening the church was filled to overflowing, nearly one-third of the audience being white. Rev. HENRY HIGHLAND GARNET, pastor of Shiloh Church presided, and among the speakers were Rev. S.C. JOCELYN, C.C. LEIGH, EDWARD GILBERT, JUNIUS C. MORELL, and others.

abstract: Alabama; Inefficient Pursuit of the; Responsibility of Government for Depredations of the Alabama
snippet: Alabama; Inefficient Pursuit of the; Responsibility of Government for Depredations of the Alabama
lead_paragraph: Fifteen months ago we entreated the Government to build a few very fast war vessels, for the distinctly specified purpose of catching pirates; and we called attention to the undoubted principles and facts of steamship performance, to prove that such vessels could be constructed at a moderate cost and without risk of failure. Since that time the rebels have not only procured the "290," but have inflicted with their one ship, in the short period of a few weeks, more damage upon our commerce and disgrace upon our Government, than our whole navy has done to them since the capture of New-Orleans. While high officials have denied not only the feasibility of attaining high speed, but the importance of employing it, the "290" has achieved one of the most brilliant successes on record, solely and exclusively by reason of her high speed. And of all the immense and costly navy created by our Government, with the full knowledge of modern steamship improvement, not one of the vessels of the Department's own design will exceed ten knots at sea, and, according to present evidence, not more than one of their purchased vessels will catch the "290."
headline: {'main': 'The Alabama The Responsibility The Remedy.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Alabama The Responsibility The Remedy.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: New-Years and the War
snippet: New-Years and the War
lead_paragraph: In our review, yesterday, of our military successes during the year that has closed, it was made very apparent that the rebellion could not survive another twelvemonth of similar experience. It was shown that the reduction of a like amount of territory to the old flag in 1863, as in 1862, would literally wipe the Confederacy from the face of the earth. Considering the present magnitude and splendid condition of our army, and the superb fleet of gunboats just completed -- which will not only be able to gain possession of the three remaining Southern ports, but to ascend the Southern rivers far into the interior -- it is certainly not unreasonable to believe that the restoration of the National authority can proceed, to say the least, as rapidly hereafter as it has heretofore.

abstract: People vs. Shepherd; Arson
snippet: People vs. Shepherd; Arson
lead_paragraph: The People vs. James Shepherd. -- The Prisoner, James Shepherd, was tried in the Court of General Sessions for the City and County of New-York, on the 1st day of December, 1857, for the offence of arson in the first degree, and was found guilty by the jury. The offence alleged in the indictment was charged to have been committed on the 9th day of June, 1857, and the dwelling-house burned was stated to have been the dwelling-house of one Christian Gever. On the 21st day of December, 1857, judgment of death was pronounced upon the prisoner, and he was ordered to be executed on the 8th day of the ensuing February. His case was carried, by writ of error, to the General Term of the Supreme Court for the First Judicial District, for review, where the judgment of the Court of General Sessions was affirmed on the 11th day of June, 1859.

lead_paragraph: The Emancipation Proclamation of President LINCOLN was given to the world on the 1st inst., and has probably been already perused by the great majority of readers in the loyal States. It declares the freedom of all slaves in those portions of the country now in armed rebellion against the Government. Those portions comprise the States of Arkansas, Texas. Louisiana, Mississippi, Alabama, Florida, Georgia, South Carolina, North Carolina and Virginia, excepting those parts of Virginia and Louisiana which are under Government control. He enjoins upon the persons thus declared free to abstain from all violence, except in necessary self-defence, and further declares that such persons, of suitable condition, wilt be received into the armed service of the United States, to garrison forts, man vessels, etc.

abstract: -- Two nephews of the distinguished Hungarian, Gov. KOSSUTH, who have been serving in the Army of Italy for the last two years, have just arrived in this City -- intending to offer their services in any capacity to the Government of the United States in its contest with the rebellion. They are sons of Madame ZULAOSKI, whose decease a year ago was noticed generally by the Press. A son of Madame RUTTKAI, another sister of the Ex-Governor, has also entered our service. We are glad to learn, by the most recent arrivals, that the rumors of Gov. KOSSUTH'S ill health were without foundation. He is in excellent health and spirits.

abstract: Murfreesboro, the battle of
snippet: Murfreesboro, the battle of
lead_paragraph: The last day of the old year went out in quiet all over the great theatre of military operations excepting in Middle Tennessee. But there, on that day, one of the greatest, and we judge it will prove to be the very greatest battle yet known in the Southwest, was fought. The only other Southwestern battle that equals it in the magnitude of the forces engaged, was the battle of Pittsburgh Landing -- and that only on the second day, after the arrival of BUELL's column. The army of Gen. ROSECRANS comprises the greater part of the magnificent force so long drilled and manoeuvred by Gen. BUELL in Kentucky and Tennessee, and which was transferred to Gen. ROSECRANS after BUELL had failed, in Northern Kentucky, to destroy with it the same rebel army which it has now again met near Murfreesboro. The opposing rebel force is, next to the army at Fredericksburgh, the largest rebel army in the South. It was recently reviewed by JEFF. DAVIS; and in the account of the review published in the Chattanooga Rebel, the columns of Polk, Bragg, Hardee, Breckinridge, Cheatham and others were mentioned as being present. The whole, we believe, was under the immediate command of Gen. BRAGG, who handled the same army during the campaign in Kentucky. For, although Gen. JOSEPH JOHNSTON is the Commander of the Department, it was said when he took command that he was only to be a sort of closet strategist or Generalissimo, and not to lead in the field. We judge it would be a fair estimate to put each of the armies at at least eighty thousand men.

abstract: President Lincoln's Proclamation Emancipating Slaves in Southern States; Proclamation of Emancipation in Eight States
snippet: President Lincoln's Proclamation Emancipating Slaves in Southern States; Proclamation of Emancipation in Eight States
lead_paragraph: President LINCOLN's proclamation, which we publish this morning, marks an era in the history, not only of this war, but of this country and the world. It is not necessary to assume that it will set free instantly the enslaved blacks of the South, in order to ascribe to it the greatest and most permanent importance. Whatever may be its immediate results, it changes entirely the relations of the National Government to the institution of Slavery. Hitherto Slavery has been under the protection of the Government; henceforth it is under its ban. The power of the Army and Navy, hitherto employed in hunting and returning to bondage the fugitive from service, are to be employed in maintaining his freedom whenever and wherever he may choose to assert it. This change of attitude is itself a revolution.
headline: {'main': "The President's Proclamation.", 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': "The President's Proclamation.", 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The Board of Aldermen met at 10 o'clock yesterday morning. Mr. BOOLE presented a resolution to donate $1,500 to the Woman's Prison Association and Isaac T. Hopper Home -- a report upon a petition for which had been inadvertently omitted by the Finance Committee, and asked a unanimous adoption of it, stating that he desired that the Common Council would, for the first time do, in this case, what was common in legislative bodies, permit the unanimous adoption of the paper to answer the requirement of the law about laying over two days, the delay being intended only to afford time for consideration in cases where objection to the immediate passage of a paper was raised. The resolution was unanimously adopted. The ordinances to donate $50,000 to the Managers of the Roman Catholic Orphan Asylum, toward the construction of a new asylum building, and to issue change notes, were taken up separately, and passed over the Mayor's vetoes, the former unanimously, and the latter by 13 to 2. The resolutions relating to the Sixth-avenue Railroad, from the other Board, were laid over. The Board adjourned till 10 o'clock A.M. to-day.

abstract: AN AGREEABLE SURPRISE. On New-Year's Bye the United States Revenue Inspectors, headed by the Hon. RUFUS F. ANDREWS, Surveyor of the Port. proceeded in a body to the residence of J.L. VAN BOSKERCK, in Vestry-street, and took possession of the premises. Mr. PATTERSON, Chairman of the committee, then introduced the Surveyor, who proceeded to present, in behalf of the Inspectors, a splendid testimonial...
lead_paragraph: AN AGREEABLE SURPRISE. -- On New-Year's Bye the United States Revenue Inspectors, headed by the Hon. RUFUS F. ANDREWS, Surveyor of the Port, proceeded in a body to the residence of J.L. VAN BOSKERCK, in Vestry-street, and took possession of the premises. Mr. PATTERSON, Chairman of the committee, then introduced the Surveyor, who proceeded to present, in behalf of the Inspectors, a splendid testimonial consisting of four pieces of silver plate, of BALL, BLACK & CO.'s manufacture, worth about $300. Mr. ANDREWS was extremely felicitous in his remarks, feelingly alluding to the number of years Mr. V.B. had faithfully discharged the duties of Assistant-Surveyor, under different Administrations, with entire satisfaction to all; that in thirty-two years he had not missed ten days by leave of absence, sickness or any other cause; that he had never been in an omnibus but once, when he visited the grave of his child in Greenwood, and said if he himself had discharged the duties of his office to the satisfaction of the public, it was owing to the fact that Mr. V.B. was his adviser. He closed by presenting the testimonial, asking Mr. V.B. to remember in after years the United States Revenue Inspectors under the Administration of ABRAHAM LINCOLN. Mr. VAN BOSKERCK, in a few feeling remarks, accepted the gift. The Surveyor then, in behalf of the Inspectors, presented Mr. ANDREW R. TROTTER, Boarding Officer, a valuable American gold watch and chain. Mr. TROTTER responded in a very happy style. Mr. VAN BOSKERCK then invited the party to partake of a collation, at which good things were ate, drank and said. Among the distinguished gentlemen present were T.J. Brown, Esq., Deputy-Surveyor; Capt. George C. Byrnes; the Surveyor's Aids, Messrs. Isaacs, Archer and Graham; Robert Johnson, Esq., and others. Speeches in response to complimentary toasts were made by Surveyor Andrews, Deputy-Surveyor Brown, Messrs. Graham, Gardiner, Hall, Grover and Plumb. Great credit is due to the Presentation Committee and its able Chairman, Gen. ROBERT PATTERSON, for the agreeable manner in which the affair was carried out.

abstract: prospect of early slavery abolition; Farewell to People of New-Orleans
snippet: prospect of early slavery abolition; Farewell to People of New-Orleans
lead_paragraph: Gen. BUTLER'S farewell address to the people of New-Orleans will command general attention. It is brief, forcible and patriotic. It breathes the spirit of conscious rectitude of purpose, and of substantial and triumphant success. By reference to results, Gen. BUTLER vindicates the general tenor of his rule, and no one who has followed carefully and dispassionately the history of his administration will question the truth of his claims.

abstract: Message to Assembly
snippet: Message to Assembly
lead_paragraph: The Message of GOV. GAMBLE, of Missouri, opens by congratulating the Legislature and the State that at last a loyal General Assembly is convened. After describing the treachery by which the State was pushed into rebellion, he reviews the military efforts of Missouri, which now has in service for the war 38,031 loyal soldiers. The State debt is now $24,734,000. Of this amount $23,701,000 consists of bonds loaned to the several railroads, the interest upon which the roads are bound to provide for, as well as the principal, when it may become due. Still, the faith of the State is pledged to the holders of the bonds for the payment of both principal and interest; and the security which the State has is a lien upon the roads themselves. Some scheme must be resorted to by which the liabilities of the State can be so reduced as to bring them within its capacity to meet them; and as the chief liabilities are on account of the railroads, that scheme must look to the reduction of the principal of this railroad debt. To bring about this end the Governor recommends that a tax be imposed upon contracts and conveyances, such as is now imposed by Congress in requiring stamps upon all written contracts.

abstract: The Comercio announces that the American claims for the capture and confiscation of the ships Lizzie Thompson and Georgiana have been finally submitted to the King of the Belgians for arbitration. The claims of American citizens, EDMUND SARTORI, Dr. CHAS. EATON, and the owners of the whaleship William Lee, as also the claim of the Peruvian citizen, Capt. MONTANO, against the Government of the United States, will be submitted to a mixed commission from each country, who will choose an arbiter in case of disagreement, to be assisted by two lawyers, who advise only. Peru has appointed as her Commissioners, Don SANTIAGO TAVARRA and Dr. FELIPE BARRIGA ALVAREZ, and as Secretary, Dr. DOMINGO RADA.

abstract: of South Carolina, Prophecies on the Doom of Slavery
snippet: of South Carolina, Prophecies on the Doom of Slavery
lead_paragraph: One of the ablest public men in South Carolina is Mr. BOYCE, who so long represented the Central District of the State in Congress. He was a leading spirit in the Secession movement, as he was also in urging Secession in 1856, in case of the election of FREMONT. But in the projected South Carolina rebellion of 1851 -- at the era of the "Compromise" measures -- he was of a different mind, and delivered an able speech at the State Capital, showing why Secession should should not be resorted to, as a means of settling the Slavery question. In the course of his speech he used the following language, which he can now peruse in the light of the Emancipation Proclamation, and in the shade of the fast approaching doom of the whole system of Southern Slavery:

abstract: The colored people of Brooklyn held a grand jubilee on Friday evening in the Bridge-street African Methodist Church, in honor of the President's Proclamation of freedom. A platform was erected in front of the pulpit for the use of the officers of the meeting, over which was extended a banner bearing the inscriptions: "Wilberforce." "Our Country and the Day we Celebrate," "Clarkson," "Emancipation in 1827, New-York State," "Emancipation in 1834, British West Indies." This banner also represented three slaves with broken fetters under the folds of the British flag. Immediately opposite the platform, at the other extremity of the church were hung pendant from the choir gallery, the inscriptions: "Inasmuch as ye do it unto the least of these little ones, ye do it unto me;" "The Glory of a United People." At 8 o'clock the church was very comfortably filled, not a few of the audience being whites, among whom were numerous ladies. The meeting was called to order by the nomination of Rev. J.H. GLOSTER (colored) as President, and a number of Vice-Presidents and Secretaries. Rev. Mr. KING (colored) opened the proceedings with prayer, after which the audience joined in singing "Blow ye the trumpet, blow."

abstract: About 1 o'clock yesterday afternoon a fire occurred in the Petroleum or Kerosene Oil Manufactory of JOHN REED, Jr., No. 190 Duane-street. The alarm was promptly given, and the firemen were immediately on hand, but owing to the combustible nature of the stock in the building, the entire premises were soon destroyed.
lead_paragraph: About 1 o'clock yesterday afternoon a fire occurred in the Petroleum or Kerosene Oil Manufactory of JOHN REED, Jr., No. 190 Duane-street. The alarm was promptly given, and the firemen were immediately on hand, but owing to the combustible nature of the stock in the building, the entire premises were soon destroyed. At about the time that the flames were seen bursting out through the roof, a loud and, to those in the immediate neighborhood, an alarming explosion took place, which forced out the front windows of the store. In a few minutes thereafter the entire building was a sheet of flame, and it shortly after was a mass of ruins.

abstract: The pleasant weather which we have been favored with for so many days, has at length been superseded by rain. This change in the weather will doubtless be accompanied by a change in the position of the troops, it having been frequently observed that marching orders usually follow a rain storm.
lead_paragraph: CENTRE GRAND DIVISION, Tuesday, Dec. 30, 1862.

abstract: At the time of going to press this morning, our latest advices from the Murfreesboro battle-field are to the afternoon of Friday--the third day of the tremendous struggle. Our troops were then apparently in possession of Murfreesboro. Gen. ROSKCRANS had reorganized his forces during the previous night, and on Friday he had driven the enemy nearly two miles. Reinforcements were arriving, and the prospect, on the whole, looked favorable.
lead_paragraph: At the time of going to press this morning, our latest advices from the Murfreesboro battle-field are to the afternoon of Friday--the third day of the tremendous struggle. Our troops were then apparently in possession of Murfreesboro. Gen. ROSKCRANS had reorganized his forces during the previous night, and on Friday he had driven the enemy nearly two miles. Reinforcements were arriving, and the prospect, on the whole, looked favorable.

abstract: The old-fashioned sailing corvette Saratoga, which has been showing the United States flag in the isolated harbors on the African station, has returned. We have now no fleet in that part of the world, and slave-dealers have a holiday, as far as loading slaves is concerned. When the war broke out, the following formidable squadron was kept on the station:

abstract: Buckle, H. T.; Essays; Fremont, Mrs. J. B.; The Story of the Guard; Richards, Mrs.; Springs of Action
snippet: Buckle, H. T.; Essays; Fremont, Mrs. J. B.; The Story of the Guard; Richards, Mrs.; Springs of Action
lead_paragraph: -- In taking up Springs of Action, lately published by the HARPERS, we have an intuition that the book is in every respect an excellent one, and a single glance over its delicately tinted and clearly printed pages demonstrates that fact beyond all doubt and question. Must we confess that for no other reason than this exellence upon Its face we have conceived a prejudice against the work, that would grow by degrees, until it deepened and widened into confirmed and positive dislike, were we compelled to read it thoroughly and carefully through! To redeem our moral nature from the charge of inconsistency, if not of direct depravity, either or both of which would seem involved by the foregoing very candid confession, we must explain that, from the standard headings of the unexceptionable chapters of Mrs. RICHARDS' excellent book, we have a full and weary sense of what is coming. Recollections of innumerable "Letters to Young Ladies," and whole "Words to Young Men," of "Finger Posts to the Kingdom of Knowledge" -- and all other kingdoms for that matter -- which proved direct guides to the blessed "Republic of Sleep," instead, and of "Helps for the Weary," that left the reader exhausted at the foot of the first chapter -- recollections of all these and many other precious peerless volumes project their slanting shadows across our brain, and cause us to test the action of these springs by snapping them violently together and depositing them in an easy position on as far away a corner of the table as possible, lest another look should betray us into saying something either desperately stupid or desperately wicked. "Health," "Industry," "Cheerfulness," "Generosity," "Justice," "Transparency," "Earnestness," "Reverence," "Patience," "Magnanimity" -- these are the cheerful springs that are set under the cushions of our mentality in the table of contents. Health -- spring the first -- is undoubtedly a very good thing in its way, but we are tired of hearing it discussed -- bored of all books that refer to it even indirectly. Man in the concrete would have been so much happier and better had he never found out that he possessed a liver or a spine, that it is a great pity any impertinent groper among vertebrae and the interior economy of the human system ever made the discovery. Not to know that one had a stomach would be to enjoy to the full that ignorant bliss which poetry and experience tell us it is folly to make wise. Those Chinese conquerors, who cut out the stomachs of captives and hang them up beyond their reach on trees, are not so inhuman after all -- though the owner is, perhaps, slightly inconvenienced when hungry. Of the virtue of all the other Springs, "Industry," &c., we can speak from experience, if we except the singular one of "Transparency." Never within the limits of our brief yet varied experience upon earth can we remember of having been transparent, nor have we any special desire to be -- it is an attribute we are not ambitious of sharing in common with ghosts and glass doors. At first reading we thought this "spring" was simply a vehicle for the introduction of some pun about one's being "full of pains;" but no -- it is defined by the author in advice to the reader: Appear to be what you really are. This definition is not as deep as a well, perhaps, nor as broad as a church door, but still, like Mercutio's wound, 'twill do. The captious critic might urge that to appear to be what we really are might not after all conduce much to the harmony of society, and that it were preferable, so far as moral excellence is concerned, to extend the rule and be really something better than we appear to be. In either event, however, the world would be very apt to misjudge us, as the old proverb warns against trusting to appearances, and LONGFELLOW -- who is considerable of a philosopher as well as something of a poet -- advises the public that persons "and things are not what they seem."

abstract: Mr. HAUSEREK, United States Minister Resident, had returned to Quito from Guayaquil, in which latter city he has been for the past two months. President GARCIA MORENO had also gone to Quito from Quavaquil, and Gen. FLORES was to have left on the 19th. President MOSQUERA, of New-Granada, had demanded explanations from Ecuador, for the aid she rendered ARBOLEDA in Pasto, and a report was current that MOSQUERA had declared war against Ecuador, but this is not probable.

abstract: Plundering by the Union Army in Virginia
snippet: Plundering by the Union Army in Virginia
lead_paragraph: JEFFERSON DAVIS' proclamation will lead abroad, as it is leading at home, to a more earnest discussion then ever, of the manner of treatment by our armies of those portions of the rebel territory which they have occupied. Europe has been ringing for the last year with the charges of violence, outrage, plunder, &c., brought against our troops by the Confederates and their sympathizers; and all accounts that we receive from our correspondents in Virginia and elsewhere, testify that the inhabitants of the scene of operations, east and west, either believe, or appear to believe, them. We hear every day of men at the South once Unionists, who declare that whatever might have been the chances of a reconstruction at one time, the conduct of our armies has been such that all hope of it has passed away. We know that wherever our troops have been, houses are wrecked, fowls and pigs killed, horses carried off, fences burned, and the country, in fact, laid waste, and the people made bitterly hostile. Putting these two things together, we can hardly avoid the conclusion that for this state of affairs our officers and Government are responsible; that, in short, there is some stronger reason for the demonstrations of detestation with which our troops are constantly greeted than mere political alienation. Moreover, it is a well-known fact, that the march of our army from Washington to Maryland, prior to the battle of Antietam, was marked by almost unrestrained plunder; that bands of stragglers from the column cleared the farm-yards of their live stock on both sides of the road for miles, and this, too, we are pained to say, in districts through which the Confederates had marched without doing injury. In other words, our own forces made themselves more terrible than the invaders to our own people.

abstract: A BRUTAL ASSUALT.--At a late hour on Friday night a man named H. HISSINCK, partially intoxicated, entered the lager-bier saloon of CHAS. SCHULTE, at No.109 Greenwich-street, and had two drinks, which he paid for. Subsequently he had a third, but having no money to pay for this, a dispute arose between him and SOHULTZ, who was behind the bar. HISSINCK finally offered his watch as security, but Mr. SOHULTZ...
lead_paragraph: A BRUTAL ASSUALT. -- At a late hour on Friday night a man named H. HISSINCK, partially intoxicated, entered the lager-bier saloon of CHAS. SCHULTE, at No.109 Greenwich-street, and had two drinks, which he paid for. Subsequently he had a third, but having no money to pay for this, a dispute arose between him and SOHULTZ, who was behind the bar. HISSINCK finally offered his watch as security, but Mr. SCHULTZ not being satisfied with this, came round from behind his bar and attacked HISSINCK. He got him down on he floor and, as is alleged, commenced stabbing him tin the eyes with an ice-pick, and succeeded in destroying the left one altogether and probably the right one also. Some citizens who were passing at the time, came in and interposed, and SCHULTZ was arrested by Officer HEY, of the Twenty-seventh Precinct. Dr. STAGER, of No. 27 Whitehall-street, was sent for by the Police to attend the wounded man, but refused to come. Dr. WOLTJE was then called and rendered all the assistance in his power. The injured man was conveyed to the New-York Hospital, where he was pronounced to be in a dangerous condition. He will no doubt be totally blind for life. The ice-pick has blood on it for 1 1/2 inches of its length. The assault seems all the more brutal, as HISSINCK was quite drunk and gave no provocation. SCHULTZ was taken before Justice CONNOLLY at the Tombs yesterday morning, and committed to await the result of the injuries.

abstract: Although yesterday was the day, which in and by the citation of Gov. SEYMOUR, as published in the TIMES, the Police Commissioners were to appear in Albany to answer to the charges preferred against them, and to show cause why they should not be removed, in pursuance of the statute in such case made and provided, they did not see fit to appear before the Albany tribunal at the time specified. At an early hour yesterday morning, Mr. SETH C. HAWLEY, the amiable and gentlemanly Clerk of the Board of Commissioners was sent to the State Capital, in behalf of the delinquent officials, with instructions to obtain a postponement of the trial until some day in the ensuing week.

At an early hour yesterday morning, Mr. SETH C. HAWLEY, the amiable and gentlemanly Clerk of the Board of Commissioners was sent to the State Capital, in behalf of the delinquent officials, with instructions to obtain a postponement of the trial until some day in the ensuing week.

abstract: One Hundred picked men from California, all of whom are peculiarly qualified for cavalry service, arrived in this city yesterday forenoon per steamer Ocean Queen, having left San Francisco on the 11th ultimo, on their way to Boston, where they are to be incorporated into the Second Massachusetts Cavalry,...
lead_paragraph: One Hundred picked men from California, all of whom are peculiarly qualified for cavalry service, arrived in this city yesterday forenoon per steamer Ocean Queen, having left San Francisco on the 11th ultimo, on their way to Boston, where they are to be incorporated into the Second Massachusetts Cavalry, Col. C.R. LOWELL, now forming there. The "California Hundred," as this company is termed, is composed of representatives from every Northern State, who have been residents of California, as also Kentuckians, Virginians, Tennesseeans and Missourians, and presents the finest appearance of any detachment that has ever passed through our City. Recruiting for the "Hundred" was commenced on the 28th of October last, and the required number was recruited, of picked men, before the end of the month. Having obtained governmental permission to join the Second Massachusetts Cavalry, the expense of coming here (about $20,000,) was borne by the company.

abstract: --Among the passengers hither by the Scotia the other day, was Mr. THOMAS SILORR, a noted English engineer and inventor. Mr. SILORR purposes to establish, a line of large Transatlantic Express Steamers." to ply between New-York and Bristol, Eng.
lead_paragraph: -- Among the passengers hither by the Scotia the other day, was Mr. THOMAS SILORR, a noted English engineer and inventor. Mr. SILORR purposes to establish, a line of large Transatlantic Express Steamers." to ply between New-York and Bristol, Eng. The steamers are designed to carry from 1,500 to 2,000 passengers, at from $25 to $75 a-piece, and are to be constructed upon the principle of the Long Island Sound steamers, with modifications to suit Ocean navigation. Much has already been done toward the accomplishment of this scheme, such as obtaining charters and the completing of plans for a system of railways from the River Severn to Bristol, with the exception of a small engineering difficulty at Clifton, which has yet to be overcome, and which only hangs upon the question of choice of locality.

abstract: On the eve of the New-Year, a ceremony of a most interesting character took place at the residence of DAVID WATTS, Esq., in Thirty-fourth-street. The occasion illustrated one of the phases of these war times, wherein the characteristic energy of our people, in a commercial sense, rises superior to what would seem almost insuperable barriers to success. In this respect the occasion is worthy of being put on record. The following brief but explicit addresses fully indicate a career quite illustrative of those qualities of prompt enterprise and business foresight for which the American character has got credit all over the world. Suffice, by way of preface, to say that the occasion was the presentation of a magnificent service of plate to Mr. WATTS, from his business partners in Paducah, Ky., St. Louis, Mo., and New-Orleans, La. In presence of a large circle of fair ladies and "merchant princes," the presentation was made on the part of the donors, by JOHN BRYAN, Esq., in an address distinguished by eloquence and point. Mr. WATTS replied as follows:

abstract: The battle of
snippet: The battle of
lead_paragraph: There was, up to a late hour last evening. a painful suspense in regard to the result of the, great battle at Murfreesboro. Commencing with heavy skirmishing on the 30th ult., the conflict assumed the proportions of a gigantic and bloody battle that raged for eleven hours on the 31st. It was resumed at 3 A.M. on the 1st day of January, and protracted with unrelenting obstinacy and fury all that day -- each army practically holding at night the same ground it held in the morning. On the 2d there was a renewal of the sanguinary work, the fight raging down to the latest moments of the afternoon, of which we received any report. In all the history of the war, save only the seven days' battles before Richmond, there has been no such stubbornly contested fighting.

abstract: Timby's Revolving Iron Towers for Harbor Defence
snippet: Timby's Revolving Iron Towers for Harbor Defence
lead_paragraph: In all the history of the past, few revolutions have occurred so sudden and complete as that which was effected in the methods of maritime warfare by the contest between the Monitor and the Merrimac, and its accompanying incidents, in Hampton Roads. In an hour, as it were, the Great navies of the world, that have figured so much in human history, were blotted out of existence. Since that event, the maritime nations, by common consent, have ceased to construct merely wooden vessels-of-war. Iron-clad vessels have already become the recognized feature of future conflicts upon the ocean. The revolution, however effected by the memorable encounter, did not stop at this point. From the completely impregnable character of the Monitor, it was seen at a glance, that the ordinary means of harbor defence were altogether of no avail against assaults from vessels of this class. The various maritime nations of the world at once took the alarm; the erection and construction of ordinary forts was abandoned, and for a time the tide of public opinion set strongly in favor of armor-clad vessels of war as the chief reliance, even with regard to the protection of harbors. Time has, however, somewhat modified this opinion, and it seems now to be generally conceded that armor-clad vessels alone are unable to afford complete protection. A completely impregnable vessel, such as are now being constructed by our Government, could probably pass with entire safety any fortress in the world; and if two such vessels should meet in hostility, they could not seriously damage one another -- they might as well pass one another without firing, as to waste their ammunition by ineffective shots. Under these circumstances, it is clear that some other and more effective methods of harbor defence must be devised, or all our maritime cities are wholly at the mercy of the monsters of the deep. With this object in view, we take pleasure in presenting to the consideration of the readers of the TIMES the plans of Mr. THEODOE R. TIMBY, and invite special attention to them, believing that they present the strongest possible claims to favorable consideration at the hands of the Government and people. The plans of Mr. TIMBY have been drawn up and developed with unusual care, and evince a thorough appreciation on his part of the end to be gained, the difficulties to be overcome in securing it, and the best methods of accomplishing the general result. They are, moreover, indorsed by some of the best business talent in the country. The sketch at the head of this article will give a general idea of the plans proposed.
headline: {'main': "THE PROTECTION OF HARBORS.; TIMBY'S CORDON OF REVOLVING IRON TOWERS, FOR HARBOR DEFENSE.", 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': "THE PROTECTION OF HARBORS.; TIMBY'S CORDON OF REVOLVING IRON TOWERS, FOR HARBOR DEFENSE.", 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Monitor the, Loss of the; Democrats, Dilemma of the, in Wanting War and Peace
snippet: Monitor the, Loss of the; Democrats, Dilemma of the, in Wanting War and Peace
lead_paragraph: The returns of immigration to this country from Europe for the year just closed, show much higher figures than might have been anticipated. The gross number of immigrants reached seventy-six thousand, or some fifteen hundred more than during 1861. They came the past year, too, with a full knowledge of the war raging in the land, while the Spring current of immigration in the year preceding last had begun to flow from Europe before it was believed there that there would be any war here. Considering the stories that the British and Continental Press have published about the state of affairs in this country, it is odd, if people there believed them, that a single European should have dared to set foot on the soil of the North. They were not only coming to the dominion of that ferocious tyrant LINCOLN, where they would he deprived of every human right, but the moment they landed here, LINCOLN would seize them, force them into his armies, and compel them to spend the remainder of their natural or unnatural lives in fighting for him without even the remuneration of a shilling a day. Besides, who could tell but that BUTLER might at any time break loose, and come roaring and tearing from New-Orleans, and, after the fashion of Bluebeard, devour all these unfortunate foreigners before they landed? The explanation of the circumstance may, perhaps, be that, after all, there are a good many folks in Europe who do not believe the grotesque falsehoods of the English Press. At all events, during the last two years of war, something like a hundred and fifty thousand persons have come over here from Europe to see for themselves; and, when once here, very few of them ever go back to where they came from.
headline: {'main': "THE YEAR'S IMMIGRATION.", 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': "THE YEAR'S IMMIGRATION.", 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Monitor, The, Iron-clad, Foundered at Sea
snippet: Monitor, The, Iron-clad, Foundered at Sea
lead_paragraph: Late on Saturday evening, New-York was startled with the announcement that the iron-clad battery Monitor--the precursor of the great fleets now building in America and Europe--was lost; that she had foundered at sea. The most extravagant stories were at first circulated; all hands were said to be lost, and part of the Rhode Island's crew also, which vessel was towing her. In naval circles the excitement was marked, and many did not credit the rumor.

abstract: -When BURNSIDE  was repulsed at Fredericksburgh there were many persons who thought all was lost--and some were inclined to abandon at once all thought of suppressing the rebellion. Under the excited state of public expectation which ...
lead_paragraph: -- When BURNSIDE was repulsed at Fredericksburgh there were many persons who thought all was lost -- and some were inclined to abandon at once all thought of suppressing the rebellion. Under the excited state of public expectation which then prevailed, this feeling was natural. But we trust that the public have since seen reason to correct it.

snippet: Banks, Gen. Major-Gen., at New-Orleans
lead_paragraph: -- It is natural that there should be some feeling in New-Orleans, especially among those who have been most closely associated with Gen. BUTLER, at his supersession. But we regret exceedingly to see it taking the direction in some quarters of disparagement of Gen. BANKS and of censure of the Government. This is unjust to both, and cannot fail to be injurious to the public service.

abstract: --The accounts  from the battle-field near Murfreesboro reveal a new phase of rebel atrocity in the treatment of their late slaves. Every black teamster, or black follower of the Union camp, captured by the rebels, is immediately shot.
lead_paragraph: -- The accounts from the battle-field near Murfreesboro reveal a new phase of rebel atrocity in the treatment of their late slaves. Every black teamster, or black follower of the Union camp, captured by the rebels, is immediately shot. No less than twenty were found thus murdered, and lying along the Murfreesboro 'pike, after the recent rebel raid upon ROSECRANS' wagon-trains.

abstract: Bright, John, Speech at Birmingham
snippet: Bright, John, Speech at Birmingham
lead_paragraph: -- Our friends in England are as fast in their friendship as our foes there are persistent in their enmity. The speech of Mr. BRIGHT at Birmingham, which we publish this morning, gives vigorous expression to ideas which some people in this country are beginning to forget, and to noble hopes which some men here are beginning to lose. Though a peace man, he justifies this war, and though he is thoroughly informed on our military adversities, he sees no ground whatever for discouragement. On the contrary, he predicates for [???] an assured and glorious success the prophecies a restored Union, a regenc[???]d [???] and an unparalleled expansion of our boundaries and power. "I behold," says no, in a vein of American eloquence, "a far brighter vision than that civilization, in its journey with the sun, will sink into endless night to gratify the leaders of this revolt. I see one vast confederation stretching from the frozen North in one unbroken line to the glowing South, and from the wild billows of the Atlantic to the calmer waters of the Pacific main, and I see one people and one law, and one language and one faith, and over all that wide continent the home of freedom and a refuge for the oppressed of every race."

abstract: Congress; the Last Days of
snippet: Congress; the Last Days of
lead_paragraph: -- Congress resumes its sessions, to-day, under circumstances of a most stirring and exciting character. At Murfreesboro and at Vicksburgh, operations are in progress that will go far to terminate the war. If they result in Union victories, which there is so much reason to hope, the next sixty days will see the rebellion substantially ended. The rebel Confederacy, dissevered by our possession of the Mississippi River, and the rebels armies in Tennessee and Mississippi driven before the victorious columns of ROSECRANS, GRANT and SHERMAN, the President's Proclamation would do the rest in all the vast area that would at once come under our arms. We should have all west of the Mississippi, and all between Tennessee and the Gulf; and the rebellion would be suffocated in the States of Georgia, the Carolinas and Virginia.

abstract: A steamship Asia arrived at this port yesterday, with advices from Europe to the 21st ult.-- three days later than by the Etna. The news is not important. The report of the burning of the ship Harriet Spaulding by the Alabama proves to have been unfounded, she having arrived in safety at Havre.
lead_paragraph: A steamship Asia arrived at this port yesterday, with advices from Europe to the 21st ult.-- three days later than by the Etna. The news is not important. The report of the burning of the ship Harriet Spaulding by the Alabama proves to have been unfounded, she having arrived in safety at Havre. The impression that the British steamer Thistle had been captured by the Tuscarora after leaving Madera had been corrected by the statement, posted in Liverpool, that she had been allowed to proceed, her papers having been found all correct. The British steamer Connubia had also been stopped by the Tuscarora in a similar manner. The comments of the British Press on American affairs present nothing of sufficient importance to call for repetition. There was a report that another note by M. DROUYN DE L'HUYS, on the necessity of peaceful intervention, would soon be dispatched to the English and Russian Governments, but we have reason to believe that the report is at least premature. Messrs. SCHOLEFIELD and BRIGHT, members of Parliament for Birmingham, had been addressing their constituents, and the American question was discussed. Mr. SCHOLEFIELD took the part of the South, and contended that the North was not sincere in its efforts against Slavery. He was forced to bring his speech to a premature close, owing to the uproar made against him. Mr. BRIGHT then responded, and argued the cause of the North in his usually effective manner. A loan was spoken of to relieve the distress in the manufacturing districts of France. It is reported that the Italian Government has respectfully declined further negotiations with France at present, respecting the Roman question. Gen. CONCRA has resigned his position as Spanish Ambassador to France. The Liverpool Cotton Market was steady at a slight advance. Breadstuffs and Provisions are unchanged.

lead_paragraph: The day has come apparently for subduing this obstinate stronghold of the rebels on the Mississippi River. It is assailed by Gen. SHERMAN in the rear, and if its capture from this quarter be delayed ever so briefly, it will be assailed by Commodore FARRAGUT from the river; and between the fires of two such forces as these officers command, it is impossible for the rebels long to resist.

abstract: Bright, John, M. P.; Speech at Birmingham on American Affairs
snippet: Bright, John, M. P.; Speech at Birmingham on American Affairs
lead_paragraph: Messrs. SCHOLEFIELD and BRIGHT, members of Parliament for Birmingham, had been addressing their constituents, and the American question was of course their leading theme. Mr. SCHOLEFIELD considered the secession of the Southern States an act of folly, but argued that the Southerners had a moral, if not a legal right, to judge for themselves in the matter. Amid much uproar and confusion he contended that the North was not sincere in its efforts against Slavery, and would sacrifice Slavery in order to maintain the Union, which was a slave Power. He said the duty of England was for the Government to recognize the Southern States. Intervention meant war -- mediation meant failure. He was for neither; but for recognition, as a question of policy and prudence, on the ground that the South had shown ability to maintain its independence, and that the North could not subdue it. The North could not be more hostile in feeling toward England than it was now. Mr. SCHOLEFIELD was brought to a premature conclusion, owing to the uproar with which his American sentiments were received.
headline: {'main': 'Mr. Bright on American Affairs.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Mr. Bright on American Affairs.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The news from Tennessee is highly encouraging. We have advices up to Saturday afternoon, but, owing to the fact that the telegraph lines were last night down by a storm, we know nothing of yesterday's operations. The advantage on Saturday remained decidedly on our side The enemy had been repulsed and driven back in their two formidable demonstrations on our centre on Friday; and, but for the coming on of darkness, our advantage would that night have been pressed to a conclusion. The fighting on Saturday seems to have been light; but as the rebels were driven on that day to a point some nine or ten miles south of Murfreesboro, it would appear that ROSECRANS is following up his success.
lead_paragraph: The news from Tennessee is highly encouraging. We have advices up to Saturday afternoon, but, owing to the fact that the telegraph lines were last night down by a storm, we know nothing of yesterday's operations. The advantage on Saturday remained decidedly on our side The enemy had been repulsed and driven back in their two formidable demonstrations on our centre on Friday; and, but for the coming on of darkness, our advantage would that night have been pressed to a conclusion. The fighting on Saturday seems to have been light; but as the rebels were driven on that day to a point some nine or ten miles south of Murfreesboro, it would appear that ROSECRANS is following up his success.

abstract: National Intelligencer on
snippet: National Intelligencer on
lead_paragraph: -- The Washington Republican calls for the abolition of the Court of Claims, and states facts in relation to what is accomplished by the Court, and the expense of it, which make it clear that some change should be made. But in our opinion the remedy should be found not in doing away with the Court, but in enlarging its powers and making its decisions binding upon the Government. It could hardly be a matter of surprise that the Court was not crowded with business, when the business must be without result, because if a suitor gets a decree from the Court in his favor, he still has to apply to Congress to get his money -- and even the most litigious man is not fond enough of litigation to carry it on where he knows that he can derive no fruit from it whatever -- and, therefore, men who have claims against the Government prefer to avoid the useless trouble and delay of going through the Court of Claims, and carry them directly to the Department or to Congress.

abstract: Considerable curiosity has been manifested at the fact that no mention has been made in any of the dispatches relative to the movements of Capt. BANKHEAD. It is supposed that he was one of the first officers to leave the vessel on discovering the state of affairs, for when water once begins to flow into a craft almost on a level with the water it is out of the question to save her. And thus, it is feared, that those who had not the good fortune to be on deck speedily enough after the disaster, were drowned before they could get up through the hatchway. JOHN B. BANKHEAD is a full commander in the United States Navy. He is a native of South Carolina, and entered the navy in the month of August 1838, J.W.A. NICHOLSON, SAMUEL MARCY, C.M. FAUNTLEROY, and others, graduated with him. He was attached at various times to nearly all the ships of the old navy, and cruised on the Mediterranean, the Coast of Africa and Brazil. In 1861 he was temporarily attached to the Coast Survey, and rendered good service to the Government while acting in such capacity. He is credited with over twenty years of actual sea service. The bravery and chivalrous conduct displayed by him while commanding the steam gunboat Pembina, marked him out as the man to succeed WORDEN in command of the renowned Monitor. Although a native of South Carolina, Capt. BANKHEAD was appointed from Virginia. He is personally very popular. There are not many men in the navy superior to him in geographical knowledge, a fact that would seem to indicate his reliability in navigation, especially on a coast so familiar to him as that surrounding Hatteras. It must, therefore, be some other cause than bad steering which caused his craft to founder.

abstract: The opening of the opera season at the Academy, of Music tonight is, of course, the principal event of the present week. It is rendered more than ordinarily interesting from the circumstance that Miss KELLOGG makes her rentree on the occasion in a new role, and during the season makes her farewell appearances under Mr. GRAU'S management.
lead_paragraph: The opening of the opera season at the Academy, of Music tonight is, of course, the principal event of the present week. It is rendered more than ordinarily interesting from the circumstance that Miss KELLOGG makes her rentree on the occasion in a new role, and during the season makes her farewell appearances under Mr. GRAU'S management. It is a shame that London should snatch our best prima donna from us, at a time when we can lll afford to spare so good an artist. Miss KELLOGG's farewell performances -- commencing with "Il Poliuto" tonight -- will undoubtedly be ovations of the most gratifying kind to the lady and the public.

abstract: Having done so much for the country at large and for the State, we now ask that the political claims of the City of New-York and this section of State so long held in abeyance shall at last be recognized in the matter of United States Senator. Our friends in the State have impressed upon us the fact that Mr. Wood is "a representative man" of this City -while at the same time they have not spoken in the same terms of laudation of the leading men in Tammany Hall. Mr. Wood will be presented as the candidate of the United Democracy for the office of United States Senator. Every member of Assembly from this City will cordially sustain him, as will the two organizations of Tammany and Mozart Hall.

abstract: - The larges audience that Mr. JONES has yet addressed in Brooklyn, crowded every part of the Academy of Music, from the ceiling to the floor, on Saturday night, to hear his oration on "Garibaldi," the great Italian hero and patriot. Complete master of his subject; fully conversant with all the facts of his case; intimately acquainted with men and things in Italy, and inspired by a passionate admiration of her deliverer, Mr. JONES speaks to his hearers with authority, and from personal experience on the great European question of the day. He gives his audiences the, result, not of reading, hut of observation; not of hearsay, but of his own knowledge. Hence the interest felt in his accounts of the state of parties in Italy; his opinions of MAZZINI, RATAZZI and CAVOUR; his descriptions of battles, dungeons and hospital scenes; his delineations of the Italian people; his scathing denunciations of the Neapolitans; and above all, his comprehensive and exhaustive estimate of the moral character and military genius of the central figure in the drama -- GARIBALDI himself. That his eulogium on his hero was not dictated by a blind admiration, was proved by the candid exposure of GARIBALDI's deficiency in all talent for organization and discipline, and which rather startled the audience. The orator also severely blamed him for annexing the Two Sicilies before he had completed his programme of expelling the Austrians from Venice, and the French from Rome, which he described as worse than a crime -- a blunder. To the Republicans, or party of action, Mr. JONES awarded the merit of having begun and carried out all the movements which have aided to make Italy an united nation. To that party, under the guidance and direction of GARIBALDI, he looks for her final salvation and deliverance. In the course of his two hours' address the orator catered for every variety of taste: to the statist he gave figures; to the logician he gave arguments; to the imaginative he gave metaphors; to the humorous he gave anecdotes, and to the merry he gave wit. His stories of the Neapolitans convulsed the audience with laughter, and his picture of the dying boy drew tears from many an eye unused to the melting mood. The vast audience listened with profound attention to this most eloquent and instructive speech -- for lecture it was not -- and at the conclusion of his glowing peroration, the orator retired from the stage amid the loudest acclamations.

abstract: Vicksburgh, The Battle on rear of
snippet: Vicksburgh, The Battle on rear of
lead_paragraph: We have definite intelligence from the Battlefield of Murfreesboro up to the evening of Friday, and telegrams from Nashville as late as Saturday at 5 o'clock P.M., at which time everything looked favorable for the National cause. In fact, a telegram received at headquarters, in Louisville, from Col. ANDERSON, announced positively that the rebels had been decidedly whipped, and that our forces were at Christiana, which is ten miles below Murfreesboro, on the railroad. After the severe struggle of Wednesday, the enemy persisted in massing upon our right, with a view of cutting off our communications with Nashville, out failing in this, they made a sudden attempt upon our centre on Thursday morning, but were severely repulsed. Late in the day they made another attempt upon the centre, but were again repulsed. On Friday afternoon a third attempt upon the centre was similarly repulsed, a fierce demonstration at the same time being made against our left, which, after a terrific struggle, resulted in the discomfiture of the rebels -- the contest here being decided by a charge of NEGLEY's Division. Gen. ROSECRANS, quick to take advantage of these successes, immediately issued a general order, which was executed in fine style, and the left was fairly established on the east bank of the river. The centre advanced to a position previously held by the rebels, and the right again occupied the ground from which it had been driven on Wednesday -- thus insuring decided advantages for us, when the day's work was closed by darkness. Of the fighting on Saturday we have no details, though, from the tenor of our dispatches, we cannot doubt that it resulted in the defeat of the rebel forces. It will be seen by the dispatches received from rebel sources that a body of our troops has penetrated ninety miles into East Tennessee, through Pound Gap, and made a serious break in the East Tennessee Railroad, which it will take some time to repair, thus cutting off all reinforcements for BRAGG's army from Virginia.

lead_paragraph: The Tribune and TIMES are members of the Press Association, One of the rules of that body prescribes that whatever news may be received by telegraph, except from certain designated points, shall be shared in common--each paper paying its proportion of the expense. On Saturday morning, under this rule, we received from the Tribune certain dispatches from Nashville, in time to publish them in a small part of our edition of that morning. Early in the succeeding day we received a bill for the same -- which was promptly paid as the following document will show:

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- If Mr. GRAU were not proverbially fortunate, we might feel disposed to sympathize with him on the inauspicious opening of his season last night. Not that the weather was boisterous, or the attendance indifferent. Both were thoroughly satisfactory, but -- and here is the cause of his discomfiture -- Signor BRIGNOLI was sick. When we add to this calamity the fact that Signor MACCAFERRI was, at the last moment, thrust into the favorite tenor's role, it will be seen that the disasters of the evening were of no ordinary kind. In "Il Trovatore" and "Un Ballo in Maschera," Signor MACCAFERRI was fortunate enough last season to make a marked success. At a critical moment he was found to be ready in both operas, and the surprise of the public was only equaled by its satisfaction. DONIZETTI's "Poliuto" is a work not so well remembered, even by experienced artists, and hence Signor MACAFERRI was not so well prepared for the responsibilities that were so unexpectedly put upon him. Beyond mentioning this as a matter of fact, we have no desire to say more. Kindliness is well bestowed upon an artist who at the last moment volunteers to save the public from absolute disappointment.
lead_paragraph: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- If Mr. GRAU were not proverbially fortunate, we might feel disposed to sympathize with him on the inauspicious opening of his season last night. Not that the weather was boisterous, or the attendance indifferent. Both were thoroughly satisfactory, but -- and here is the cause of his discomfiture -- Signor BRIGNOLI was sick. When we add to this calamity the fact that Signor MACCAFERRI was, at the last moment, thrust into the favorite tenor's role, it will be seen that the disasters of the evening were of no ordinary kind. In "Il Trovatore" and "Un Ballo in Maschera," Signor MACCAFERRI was fortunate enough last season to make a marked success. At a critical moment he was found to be ready in both operas, and the surprise of the public was only equaled by its satisfaction. DONIZETTI's "Poliuto" is a work not so well remembered, even by experienced artists, and hence Signor MACAFERRI was not so well prepared for the responsibilities that were so unexpectedly put upon him. Beyond mentioning this as a matter of fact, we have no desire to say more. Kindliness is well bestowed upon an artist who at the last moment volunteers to save the public from absolute disappointment.

abstract: The battle of
snippet: The battle of
lead_paragraph: The fighting at Murfreesboro closed with the close of the last week. The serious work extended only over Wednesday, Thursday and Friday, though there was heavy skirmishing for several days preceding the general actions, as well as on the Saturday following them. The result of the engagements was an undisputed victory to our army. Though the rebels gained certain important advantages on the first two days during which the battle raged, and though on the afternoon of the third day they advanced in great force, and opened the attack, yet before nightfall they were driven from the ground with such serious loss that their whole army was compelled to fall back, and after a show of fight on Saturday, they fled southward, in the direction, it is said, of Tullahoma. On Sunday, ROSECRANS, with his victorious army, marched up to Murfreesboro, and yesterday occupied it. ROSECRANS, in his official report, says that part of his force had commenced a pursuit of the enemy, but of any results of this we as yet do not know. The losses are, happily, not as heavy as might have been inferred from the first accounts we had of the engagements. Gen. ROSECRANS states that his medical director estimates the wounded at fifty-five hundred and the killed at a thousand. The rebels admit a loss nearly as great during the first two days fighting.

abstract: We need not call attention to the very able message of Mayor OPDYKE, which we publish this morning. He touches upon national as well as local affairs, and with a few brief yet vigorous paragraphs upon the aspect of the war, gives credit to New-York for its liberal contributions of men and material resources to the Government. The City finances, its sanitary condition, its harbor defences, the Central Park, the Board of Education, the Department of Public Charities and Correction, the Fire Department and all other local interests are lucidly and effectively discussed; the defects of our Charter are pointed out, and many highly important suggestions made. No abler document has ever issued from the chief functionary of this metropolis.

abstract: Official dispatches from Gen. ROSECRANS, published this morning, put at rest all doubts of the fact that the rebels have suffered a defeat at Murfreesboro. At last accounts they were in full and disorderly retreat toward Tullahoma, thirty-nine miles below, and our forces were in pursuit. From Gen. ROSECRANS' dispatches it
lead_paragraph: Official dispatches from Gen. ROSECRANS, published this morning, put at rest all doubts of the fact that the rebels have suffered a defeat at Murfreesboro. At last accounts they were in full and disorderly retreat toward Tullahoma, thirty-nine miles below, and our forces were in pursuit. From Gen. ROSECRANS' dispatches it appears that the heavy fighting of Friday, in which the rebels were so terribly worsted, was sufficient to satisfy them that they had no hope of success. A heavy storm prevailed during Saturday, making it difficult to manoeuvre large [???]ies of troops, and nothing more than skirmishing took place. On Sunday morning [???]arly it was discovered that the rebels had retreated during the night, and soon afterward a brigade of our forces, under Gen. STANLEY, entered Murfreesboro. No general pursuit, however, was commenced until Sunday evening, the day being spent in preparations for the movement, in bringing in the dead and in distributing ammunition and subsistence. The Centre Grand Division was the first to start, and was followed with due promptness by the two others. The losses on our side, considering the length of time and the persistency with which the fighting continued before Murfreesboro, are much lighter than might be expected. Gen. ROSECRANS' Medical Director estimates the number of wounded in hospital at about 5,500, and the killed at 1,000. These figures are considerably less than those af Antietarn or Fredericksburgh.

abstract: THE METROPOLITAN POLICE AS RECRUITING OFFICER. -- It will be remembered that in July last Police Commissioner BOWEN offered a premium of $100, to be divided into shares of $50, $30 and $20 each, to be given respectively to three members of the force who should obtain the largest number of recruits for the regiments which were then in process of organization for the Metropolitan Brigade, from July 16 to Dec. 16, 1862. An accurate account has been kept of all the recruits so accepted, and Superintendent KENNEDY has just made his report to the Board of Commissioners. From this report, it appears that 2,500 men have been recruited and enlisted by the Police. The following are the awards of premiums: Officer TRENDE, Twenty-sixth Precinct, obtained 170 recruits -- $50; Capt. WOOLOM, Forty-fifth Precinct, (Brooklyn,) 122 recruits -- $30; Officer HOPKINS, Sixth Precinct, 80 recruits -- $20. The awards, as above, have accordingly been made. On the 29th of July last Commissioner BOWEN also offered a gold Police Captain's shield, to be presented to the Captain whose precinct would obtain the highest number of recruits from July 16 to Sept. 17. The Sixth Precinct having obtained 394 recruits, the highest number obtained by any one precinct, Capt. JOSEPH DOWLING has been awarded the gold shield.

abstract: AN AGREEABLE SURPRISE PARTY.--About 9 o'clock on Saturday evening, JOHN V. GRIDLEY, Esq.,  residing at No. 63 West Thirty-first-street, and a prominent Republican of the Twentieth Ward, was very suddenly but agreeably surprised. During his absence a large party entered the house, and by the consent of Mrs. GRIDLEY, took possession of the parlors. A full and massive silver tea set was soon displayed on the table, and at that moment Mr. GRIDLEY, quite
lead_paragraph: AN AGREEABLE SURPRISE PARTY. -- About 9 o'clock on Saturday evening, JOHN V. GRIDLEY, Esq., residing at No. 63 West Thirty-first-street, and a prominent Republican of the Twentieth Ward, was very suddenly but agreeably surprised. During his absence a large party entered the house, and by the consent of Mrs. GRIDLEY, took possession of the parlors. A full and massive silver tea set was soon displayed on the table, and at that moment Mr. GRIDLEY, quite unaware of what was going on, rang the door bell, and was ushered in amongst his friends. After partially recovering from his surprise, the service of silver was presented to him by Mr. JOHN MCKECHNIE, on behalf of the recipient's numerous friends of the the Twentieth Ward. Mr. GRIDLEY, in responding, made a few appropriate remarks, thanking his friends for the kind manifestation of their regards for him. Speeches were made by Hons. CHARLES S. SPENCER and TUCKER, Judge BULL. Ex-Alderman REED, Supervisor STEWART and others, and after partaking of a bountiful repast, the company dispersed. The surprise passed pleasantly to all concerned.

abstract: Colorado, Gold Production of
snippet: Colorado, Gold Production of
lead_paragraph: -- Probably half the people of New-York are yet unaware that there is a political territorial organism in the United States called Colorado, which is rapidly rising to the proportions of a State, and is even now contributing largely to the National wealth. Many of those who have heard of the Territory, have simply a cloudy and undefined idea that it is situated somewhere beyond the great plains and in the region of the Rocky Mountains.

abstract: Congress was again in session yesterday, the holiday recess being over. In the Senate, a joint resolution of the Legislature of Connecticut was presented, requesting a modification of the Internal Revenue law, so as to prevent the accumulation of taxes on the same article in different processes of maufacture.
lead_paragraph: Congress was again in session yesterday, the holiday recess being over. In the Senate, a joint resolution of the Legislature of Connecticut was presented, requesting a modification of the Internal Revenue law, so as to prevent the accumulation of taxes on the same article in different processes of maufacture. The Secretary of War sent in a communication, stating that no citizen, to his knowledge, or by his authority, had been required to take any oath or obligation not to bring any suit or action against those who arrested him. Bills were introduced to promote the efficiency of the army and navy. A bill taxing bank-bills and all fractional currency was introduced by Mr. SHERMAN, of Ohio. A resolution condemning Gen. GRANT's order expelling the Jews from his Department was introduced by Mr. POWELL, of Kentucky, and laid over. A resolution was adopted, making inquiry of the Secretary of War as to the number of deserters from the army, and the steps taken to punish them. The Military Committee was instructed to inquire into the expediency of so consolidating the regiments now in the field that their maximum number shall be at least 1,020 men. The Finance Committee was instructed to inquire into the expediency of modifying, or abolishing the duties on foreign paper. Two messages were received from the President -- one regarding the appointment of officers to all vacancies in the Departments, and the other calling attention to that part of the report of the Secretary of State relating to Consular pupils. The Bankrupt bill was considered, after which the Senate went into [???]ecutive Session, and afterward adjourned.
