abstract: Speech on the Emancipation Proclamation
snippet: Speech on the Emancipation Proclamation
lead_paragraph: Never in hot political campaigns, not upon any other occasion capable of attracting an immense crowd, were so many people bent upon forming a single congregation as those who last night strove to form the auditory in the spacious hall of the Cooper Institute, where joyous notes of jubilee echoed to the edict of negro emancipation. A living stream of people set swiftly toward the doors long before the hour appointed for commencing the exercises, and filling the body of the house with a rush, eddied into the lobbies, percolated into the aisles, dashed its spray upon the platform, and overflowed into the street, where, after surging and vexing itself in vain endeavors to find an outlet, it finally rippled into murmurs of dissatisfaction and meandered away in a counter-current of disappointment.

abstract: Intention of the Legislature to Interfere for Peace
snippet: Intention of the Legislature to Interfere for Peace
lead_paragraph: Interpose -- that is the word. The State of New-Jersey is called upon by a piebald squad of Know-Nothings and Democrats to "interpose to arrest the existing civi1 war." In this there is nothing surprising. It has long been known that the breed of New-York politicians which furnished two Major-Generals to the rebel army, is not extinct. They live, and so far as has been observable, retain every traitorous affinity. Nor is it very strange that individuals of similar instincts should be found in the New-Jersey Legislature. Probably there never yet was a legislative body altogether free from faithless men. But the story told to us that there is some chance that a majority of the Legislature in question will seriously undertake what is asked of them, is utterly incredible. It cannot be that any party majority dare so dishonor their State -- least of all a State so justly proud of its revolutionary history.

abstract: And the Police
snippet: And the Police
lead_paragraph: -- We have done injustice to Gov. SEYMOUR, and we hasten to correct it. We assumed that in summoning the Police Commissioners to appear before him on Saturday at 2 o'clock, to answer charges preferred against them, be intended to fix that time for hearing and deciding them. In this, it seems, we were mistaken. In his letter on the subject Gov. SEYMOUR says "the object of the hearing was to receive the answer of the Commissioners, and to decide when and where the charges should be investigated." They did not respond to his summons, -- and he has decided that the hearing shall take place in the City of New-York "at an early day."

abstract: Address on Opening of New-York Senate; Report; Taxation; Table of since 1842; Jan. 2
snippet: Address on Opening of New-York Senate; Report; Taxation; Table of since 1842; Jan. 2
lead_paragraph: The Annual Report of the Comptroller of the State, Hon. LUCIUS ROBINSON, has been received. It reviews briefly the financial policy of the State during the last four years; the enforced transition from prodigality to thrift in the management of the State works; the improvement of the toll rates; the parsimony of appropriations, and the resort to necessary taxation. Of these ameliorations the Government enjoys the benefit in the form of a higher credit; the payment of all just claims; the enlargement of the Canals, and the reduction of the funded debt by the sum of $2,100,000. The Comptroller offers a variety of reasons for persevering in the policy of retrenchment and prudence.

lead_paragraph: We have the important news from Mexico, by way of Havana, that the advance of the French troops against Puebla and the Capital had begun. This intelligence is brought by French vessels of war, from Vera Cruz on the 20th ult. It is stated that the main body of the army is to be pushed on immediately to the Capital, only sufficient troops being left at Puebla to guard the avenues leading from the city, to prevent the reception by the garrison of reinforcements or munitions of war. The whole story, as coming from the French, must be received with due allowance.

abstract: This morning, about 7 o'clock, an explosion took place in the percussion cap manufactory of Mr. GOLF, Sixty-second-street, between Tenth and Eleventh avenues, instantly killing one of the employes named WHIPPLE, and slightly injuring another of the workmen named ASTOR.
lead_paragraph: This morning, about 7 o'clock, an explosion took place in the percussion cap manufactory of Mr. GOLF, Sixty-second-street, between Tenth and Eleventh avenues, instantly killing one of the employes named WHIPPLE, and slightly injuring another of the workmen named ASTOR. The building, (a frame one,) was totally destroyed, the timbers being thrown in every direction and to great distances. The house adjoining the factory was also much shattered, leaving not a pane of glass unbroken. Owing to the early hour in which the explosion occurred, but few of those employed there had arrived, otherwise the loss of life must have been feathful.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, the bill to suspend temporarily the act to prevent and punish fraud on the part of officers making contracts for the Government, was reported from the Military Committee, and Mr. WILSON, of Massachusetts, moved to put it upon its passage. After considerable debate, the subject was postponed. Mr. WILSON reported from the Military Committee the House joint resolution for the payment of our soldiers and sailors, with an amendment authorizing the
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, yesterday, the bill to suspend temporarily the act to prevent and punish fraud on the part of officers making contracts for the Government, was reported from the Military Committee, and Mr. WILSON, of Massachusetts, moved to put it upon its passage. After considerable debate, the subject was postponed. Mr. WILSON reported from the Military Committee the House joint resolution for the payment of our soldiers and sailors, with an amendment authorizing the Secretary of the Treasury to issue $50,000,000 additional demand Treasury Notes. The bill was referred to the Finance Committee. The bill concerning the discharge of State Prisoners was taken up, and Mr. WRIGHT, of Indiana, addressed the Senate. He advocated the most vigorous policy in the prosecution of the war, and opposed any attempt to hamper the President in the full exercise of his prerogative as Commander-in-Chief of the Army and Navy. The bill was postponed until to-day. A bill to provide for the greater comfort of sick and wounded soldiers was introduce and referred. After an Executive Session, the Senate adjourned.

snippet: Ahead of other Papers in Publishing Porter's Dispatches, >amp;c.; Burnside and Napoleon compared; And the Police; Fredericksburgh and Bautzen; Intervention, the Rumors of
lead_paragraph: "NAPOLEON never, in all his bloody career, fought a hostile army intrenched in front of a fortified city, as McCLELLAN did at Richmond; or strongly fortified along a range of hills, with a non-fordable river a mile or so in front, like the position lately assailed by BURNSIDE at Fredericksburgh. He always found means to turn such defences, and compel their evacuation, as our Generals doubtless will in time."

abstract: The battle began at 7 o'clock this morning and raged with great fury all day. We drove the enemy from all their positions except on the extreme left, where he successfully resisted us. WILLICH and FRY, thirty-one pieces of artillery, and about two hundred wagons and teams.

lead_paragraph: Both branches of the Legislature met at 11 o'clock yesterday forenoon. In the Senate, Lieutenant-Governor JONES, on assuming his duties as President, made a brief address, after which he announced his appointments of Sub-Officers. Committees were then appointed to notify the Governor and the Assembly that the Senate was ready to proceed to business. The daily sessions were fixed at 11 o'clock A.M., and the Senate soon afterward adjourned.

lead_paragraph: A ROCHESTER MERCHANT CHARGED WITH FALSE PRETENCES. -- Mr. WM. H. MELLEN, of the firm of Messrs. CLAFLIN, MELLEN & Co., well-known merchants of this City, recently appeared before Justice CONNOLLY, and preferred a complaint for false pretences against THOMAS C. GILMAN, a merchant doing business in Rochester, this State. From the complainant's affidavit it appears that on the 20th day of February, 1861, Mr. GILMAN called on the firm and applied to purchase goods on credit, as the agent of his wife, MARY A. GILMAN. He represented that she had just commenced the wholesale boot and shoe business in Rochester, this State, that she was to sell for cash, and had invested $10,000 of her own money in the business, beside having $4,000 more which she intended to invest in four months from that time. GILMAN further represented that he then intended to purchase goods to the amount of $30,000, toward which be should pay $10,000 down; that his wife was nearly free from debt, and perfectly responsible. Believing these representations to be true, the firm sold and delivered to GILMAN a large bill of goods, and at intervals, up to a few months ago, continued to sell him goods as the agent for his wife, apparently fair and plausible representations being made by GILMAN at every sale. The total amount of his present indebtedness to the firm of CLAFLIN, MELLEN & Co. is $6,378 25. At length, becoming somewhat suspicious as to the pecuniary standing of GILMAN and his wife, Mr. MELLEN instituted an investigation, which resulted in satisfying him that all the representations made by Mr. GILMAN, and upon which he obtained the goods, were false and untrue, and, as complainant alleges, were feloniously made, with the intent to cheat himself and his partners out of their property. On the facts presented before Justice CONNOLLY, a warrant was issued for GILMAN's apprehension, and yesterday he was taken into custody by Officers CUMMINGS and BLUNT, of the Tombs Police Court, The accused was taken before the magistrate, and held in $5,000 to answer. Mr. WM. WALTERMEYER, of Sixty-fourth-street and Fifth-avenue, and HENRY DATER, Esq., residing at No. 78 West Forty-second-street, became his bondsmen.

abstract: Style of Fighting
snippet: Style of Fighting
lead_paragraph: If the general accounts of the battle of Murfreesboro, in the absence of special details, are to be relied upon, we should have had no victory but for the admirable leadership of Gen. ROSECRANS. He was the master-spirit of the occasion--discovering every exigency with eagle glance, and doing on the instant the right thing to meet it. Now rallying the wing broken by the overwhelming masses of the foe, and forthwith forming a new and firmer front -- now bringing up supports whenever his lines wavered -- now seizing the opportune moment to put himself in person at the head of his columns and charge home upon the enemy -- ever knowing just what to do, and ever flying to his mark, he was not only a chief, but he was everywhere an inspiration. Not only his mind directed, but his spirit fired. Probably not since this war began has a victory been wrested from the enemy by such plenitude of resource, and such unrelenting determination, on the part of the Commanding General, as was this. The rebels have seldom fought with such fury; never with such tenacity. They were handled by their Generals -- JOHNSON and BRAGG -- with consummate skill. They gave battle in their own chosen position, and with numbers certainly equaling, and probably much exceeding, our own forces. But nothing availed to save them from disastrous defeat.

lead_paragraph: The United States vs. The schooner Mary Teresa and her Cargo. -- This vessel was captured off Charleston Harbor by the gunboat Unadilla, on May 10, 1862. She was built in Wilmington, N.C., in 1852. She was provisionally registered on April 29, 1862, at Nassau, to Edward Gardner, a merchant of Charleston. The shipping agreement was for a voyage to Halifax and back to Nassau. A claim was filed in this suit by the Acting British Consul in behalf of British subjects having an interest, and afterward a claim was filed by Gardner. The master of the vessel set testified that she came from Charleston to Nassau with a cargo of cotton about a week before this voyage. C[???] was [???] and owned the cargo on that voyage, and [???] most of this present cargo. A [???] [???] [???] that [???] [???] the Cap[???] [???] [???] [???] that [???], & Co., of [???], who were the consignees of the vessel, owned her, and the mate owned the cargo. The vessel had no log. After she left Nassau she was kept to the northward close along the shore of the United States, and was captured about twenty miles from Charleston Bar.

abstract: THE REDEMPTION OF SOILED POSTAGE STAMPS. -- The redemption of soiled postage stamps is continued regularly at the Post-office, between the hours of 10 o'clock in the morning and 2 in the afternoon. The regulation of the Postmaster-General, which allows thirty days for the presentation of the stamps, has been applied so as to exclude Sundays and holidays; and in the 19 working days which have so far passed, more than $200,000 worth of antiquated and outlawed "gumbacks" have been offered for redemption, and the crowd of applicants has not decreased. It is observed, however, that the average amount of the packages is less than at first. Quite as much labor is involved, however, and it has been found necessary by Postmaster WAKEMAN, and by the Cashier, Mr. H.W. WHITING, in whose department the work of redemption is conducted, to increase the force which was employed in assorting and counting the stamps, and in paying the checks that were issued to persons presenting the same. The amount of money which has been given in exchange for the stamps is now about $40,000. Only eleven days yet remain of the thirty days originally allowed, and as the Postmaster-General has decided that all the stamps must be presented during that time, those of our fellow-citizens who have soiled stamps in their possession and desire to receive the money for them, ought to place themselves (or their stamps) in line at the Post-office, lest the crowd should become finally so great that their opportunities will be lost. No period of grace, it should be remembered, is promised.
lead_paragraph: THE REDEMPTION OF SOILED POSTAGE STAMPS. -- The redemption of soiled postage stamps is continued regularly at the Post-office, between the hours of 10 o'clock in the morning and 2 in the afternoon. The regulation of the Postmaster-General, which allows thirty days for the presentation of the stamps, has been applied so as to exclude Sundays and holidays; and in the 19 working days which have so far passed, more than $200,000 worth of antiquated and outlawed "gumbacks" have been offered for redemption, and the crowd of applicants has not decreased. It is observed, however, that the average amount of the packages is less than at first. Quite as much labor is involved, however, and it has been found necessary by Postmaster WAKEMAN, and by the Cashier, Mr. H.W. WHITING, in whose department the work of redemption is conducted, to increase the force which was employed in assorting and counting the stamps, and in paying the checks that were issued to persons presenting the same. The amount of money which has been given in exchange for the stamps is now about $40,000. Only eleven days yet remain of the thirty days originally allowed, and as the Postmaster-General has decided that all the stamps must be presented during that time, those of our fellow-citizens who have soiled stamps in their possession and desire to receive the money for them, ought to place themselves (or their stamps) in line at the Post-office, lest the crowd should become finally so great that their opportunities will be lost. No period of grace, it should be remembered, is promised.

abstract: We have intelligence from Vicksburgh one day later than proviously published, which brings the lighting up to Tuesday, Dec. 30. The information corresponds very nearly with that contained  in a rebel dispatch from Vicksburgh published in the Richmond papers, and reprinted in the TIMES ...
lead_paragraph: We have intelligence from Vicksburgh one day later than proviously published, which brings the lighting up to Tuesday, Dec. 30. The information corresponds very nearly with that contained in a rebel dispatch from Vicksburgh published in the Richmond papers, and reprinted in the TIMES day before yesterday. The fighting on Sunday, the 28th, it will be recollected, was apparently much in our favor, Gen. SHERMAN having fought his way to within two miles of the city. The struggle over the last line of rebel fortifications on Monday, it now appears, was of the most desperate character, and resulted in the temporary repulse of our forces with considerable loss. The rebels are said to have concentrated all their forces from Jackson and Grenada, and along the line of the railroad, numbering about 65,000 men, and this overwhelming force was thrown against Gen. SHERMAN, with the effect of pushing him back to his first line. There was some fighting also on Tuesday morning, but our forces were in a position to resist any attack, and were confident of ultimate victory. One account of our losses estimates them at three thousand, while another puts them at from four to five thousand. The fighting on Sunday is represented to have been of the most desperate character, much of it being hand to hand, over fortifications and batteries. Gen. HOVEY had been dispatched with 1,500 men on a special mission -- probably to destroy railroad communication -- but had not been heard from, and fears were entertained for his safety. Nothing had been heard of the forces below, under BANKS and FARRAGUT.

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. Although "La Traviata" was played here last evening as a hasty substitute for the "Sicilian Vespers" the change of programme being necessitated by the continued indisposition of Signor BRIGNOLI it was, we think, one of the best performances ever given under Mr. GRAU'S direction.
lead_paragraph: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- Although "La Traviata" was played here last evening as a hasty substitute for the "Sicilian Vespers" -- the change of programme being necessitated by the continued indisposition of Signor BRIGNOLI -- it was, we think, one of the best performances ever given under Mr. GRAU's direction. We were not prepared to expect from Mlle. CORDIER's previous efforts in "Dinorah" and "I Puritani," a degree of dramatic and musical intensity so perfect as she obtained in the role of Violetta. Thrust into the part at the last moment, it would have been proper, had she failed, to have extended to her all the friendly consideration that the critic could call to his aid, and even in view of her success, it is right to remember that she labored under the most adverse circumstances; but the lady's success was so perfect and deserved that we have nothing but the heartiest recognition to record of it. From the Brindisi of the first act to the Gran Dio of the last, she was all that could be desired; equaling, if not excelling, in execution, all her predecessors and giving to the dramatic bearings of the part a sufficient earnestness of emotion to carry the sympathies of the audience with her to the end. It is undoubtedly the best part in which Mlle. CORDIER has been heard.

abstract: There has been a good deal of talk in certain quarters about the Grand Jury of this County finding an indictment against EDWIN M. STANTON, Secretary of War, in connection with the alleged "arbitrary arrests," of which so much has been heard, and upon which Gov. SEYMOUR amplifies so largely in his Message.
lead_paragraph: There has been a good deal of talk in certain quarters about the Grand Jury of this County finding an indictment against EDWIN M. STANTON, Secretary of War, in connection with the alleged "arbitrary arrests," of which so much has been heard, and upon which Gov. SEYMOUR amplifies so largely in his Message. The Grand Jury of last month had the subject under consideration, and examined several witnesses in relation thereto, but failed to find an indictment. The Grand Jury impanneled in the Oyer and Terminer last week took up the investigation anew, and, among other witnesses, summoned United States Marshal MURRAY. Mr. MURRAY appeared before the jury yesterday, and gave a full and detailed account of the action of the Government in connection with these arrests, the mode of procedure, and the causes of complaint. At the conclusion of Mr. MURRAY's examination, the Grand Jury immediately dismissed the bill in the case under consideration, and several of the jurors expressed their regret that they had not the power to indict the complainants themselves. This will probably end the farce.

abstract: FATAL AFFRAY IS THIRTY-SIXTH-STREET--ANTE-MORTEM EXAMINATION OF THE VICTIM.--Coroner WILDEY was yesterday called to the house No. 272 Mott-street, to take the ante-mortem examination of JOHN CONNOLLY, who was dangerously beaten on the night of the 1st instant, while in a drinking-place in Thirty-sixth-street, near First-avenue.
lead_paragraph: FATAL AFFRAY IS THIRTY-SIXTH-STREET -- ANTE-MORTEM EXAMINATION OF THE VICTIM. -- Coroner WILDEY was yesterday called to the house No. 272 Mott-street, to take the ante-mortem examination of JOHN CONNOLLY, who was dangerously beaten on the night of the 1st instant, while in a drinking-place in Thirty-sixth-street, near First-avenue. On reaching the house, the injured man was found to be in a delirious state, and therefore his statement of the occurrence could not be obtained. Fortunately, however, for the ends of justice, 'he attendance of several persons who were with CONNOLLY at the time he received his injuries was secured, and their evidence taken. PETER KIERNAN, of No. 195 Allen-street, testified that, on New-Year's night his brother, the injured man and two others, stepped into a porter-house in Thirty-sixth-street, and there met EDWARD JONES, a cartman, with a party of friends. A conversation was opened between the two parties, when JONES remarked, "I can lick any d -- d man there is in the room," and directly afterward he struck the witness in the face with his fist, knocking him down. JONES then left, but returned in a few minutes, accompanied by about fifteen men, and, the quarrel being renewed, CONNOLLY was struck on the head with an iron wrench or hinge, about eighteen inches long, in the hands of JONES, felling him to the floor. JONES was then seized, and the weapon wrested from him before be could use it again. He and his party soon decamped, and CONNOLLY was taken home, where he has since been gradually growing worse. Dr. GEORGE B. BOSTON examined the victim, and found a scalp wound over the anterior portion of the left parietal bone one and a half inches in length, and about an inch to the right. Dr. BOSTON also found CONNOLLY suffering with brain symptoms, and, in his opinion, he is dangerously wounded. The jury round a verdict against JONES, who was subsequently arrested by Officer JOHNSON, of the Twenty-first Precinct, on Coroner WILDEY's warrant, and committed to the [???] to await the result of the injuries. The prisoners 22 years of of age, and resides at No. 159 East Thirty-seventh-street.

abstract: Invitation and Address of Citizens--His Reply
snippet: Invitation and Address of Citizens--His Reply
lead_paragraph: Maj.-Gen. BUTLER, the hero of New-Orleans, whom the people are delighted to honor, arrived in this City, from Philadelphia, yesterday noon, and took quarters at the Fifth-avenue Hotel. Gen. BUTLER is on his way to his home at Lowell, Mass., and accompanying him are his estimable wife and many members of the personal Staff. It is understood that the sagacity, firmness, and other eminent qualifications which have historically marked the career of Gen. BUTLER in his late command, will not long be permitted to remain inactive, but are to be brought again into the service of the country in a more exalted and important sphere of duty, which will call for the General's return to Washington in about two weeks.

abstract: ELOPEMENT, CONSPIRACY AND ROBBERY.--A short time since a young man, named WILLIAM HOWARD, a paroled naval prisoner, was paid off at Washington the sum due him, amounting to about $700. From thence he proceeded to Baltimore, and took lodgings at a sailor's boarding-house, kept by a good-looking young woman named BRIDGET BROWN, and her husband.
lead_paragraph: ELOPEMENT, CONSPIRACY AND ROBBERY. -- A short time since a young man, named WILLIAM HOWARD, a paroled naval prisoner, was paid off at Washington the sum due him, amounting to about $700. From thence he proceeded to Baltimore, and took lodgings at a sailor's boarding-house, kept by a good-looking young woman named BRIDGET BROWN, and her husband. BRIDGET took a fancy to HOWARD, or perhaps to his roll of green-backs, and the result was an elopement, the runaway pair coming to Jersey City, where they took board at No. 100 Bergen-street, as man and wife. After getting comfortably settled, Mrs. BROWN concluded to send her little daughter back to Baltimore, and HOWARD was prevailed upon to accompany the child there. Upon returning he discovered that his fair love had departed, taking with her the sum of $575 in green-backs, and his clothing, valued at about $40. HOWARD's love-dream was at once dispelled, and he cared not a fig where the false one might go, but he coveted the greenbacks for which he had fought and bled. Diligent inquiry brought him to a house in the rear of No. 10 Hamilton-st., N.Y., where he found that Mrs. BROWN had taken a dwelling and a partner named PATRICK PHALAN, for the purpose of keeping a sailor's boarding house. HOWARD told the woman that he cared nothing for her, but he did for his money and clothing, and that, if she would give them up he would depart in peace and happiness. Mrs. BROWN replied that she cared not for him, as she had a better man, and the sooner he left the better; and as to his money and clothing, she denied all knowledge of them. HOWARD straightway went and unburdened his sorrows to the kindhearted Mr. MARTINDALE, who sits in the halls of justice as Recorder, in Jersey City. A warrant was placed in the hands of Detective KILCAULEY, who proceeded to New-York early yesterday morning, and arrested Mrs. BROWN as the principal in the robbery, and PATRICK PHALAN as an accomplice. The prisoners were brought to Jersey City and placed in the lockup to await further developments. Officer KILCAULEY subsequently visited the apartments of the accused parties in New-York, but was unable to obtain any trace of the money or clothing. They had had sufficient time after HOWARD discovered their abode, to take good care of it. It is alleged that PHALAN resided with Mrs. BROWN, in Baltimore, and it is probable that they concocted the plan for robbing HOWARD, and the child was brought on for the purpose of carrying out their designs.

abstract: In the Senate yesterday, after some business of minor importance, the bill to raise volunteers for the defence of Kentucky was reported back from the Military Committee, with a substitute as an amendment. A joint resolution, giving the thanks of Congress to Gen. ROSECRANS and his army, was referred to the Military Committee. The bill to tax bank bills and fractional currency was called up by Mr. SHERMAN, who proceeded to address the Senate in favor of its passage. The bill for the discharge of State prisoners was considered, and Mr. SAULSBURY, of Delaware, made a long speech, denunciatory of the Administration. He was followed by Mr. ANTHONY, of Rhode Island, and Mr. POWELL, of Kentucky, when the subject was postponed, and, after an Executive Session, the Senate adjourned.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate yesterday, after some business of minor importance, the bill to raise volunteers for the defence of Kentucky was reported back from the Military Committee, with a substitute as an amendment. abstract: ROBBERIES. -- The house of Mr. JOHX CARPENTER, in Lafayette, near Franklin-avenue, was feloniously entered yesterday morning and robbed of silver-ware amounting to $60 in value. Some clothing was also taken. The evening previous some thieves, with a wagon, drove up to the dry-goods store of CHARLES RONDER, No. 753 Pacific-street, and took six pieces of flannel and six pieces of woolen plaid goods from the sidewalk, where they were exposed for sale, and, after placing them in their vehicle, drove off. They were out of sight before the proprietor discovered the theft. The property is valued at $120.
lead_paragraph: ROBBERIES. -- The house of Mr. JOHX CARPENTER, in Lafayette, near Franklin-avenue, was feloniously entered yesterday morning and robbed of silver-ware amounting to $60 in value. abstract: President LINCOLN, in his Proclamation, declares that emancipated slaves "of suitable condition will be employed in the armed service of the United States." This declaration, made by the highest military authority, and announcing a policy which the Government has decided to adopt, renders it desirable that the public should look at the matter a little more attentively than it has yet done. In the first place, let us say that there are in-...
lead_paragraph: President LINCOLN, in his Proclamation, declares that emancipated slaves "of suitable condition will be employed in the armed service of the United States." This declaration, made by the highest military authority, and announcing a policy which the Government has decided to adopt, renders it desirable that the public should look at the matter a little more attentively than it has yet done. In the first place, let us say that there are insuperable objections to raising a negro army for the mere purpose of proving that negroes can fight, and if such be the object of the supporters of the project, they should think twice before they push it any further.

abstract: A dispatch from Gen. PEMBERTON, commanding the rebel forces at Vicksburgh, to the rebel War Department, announces that the National forces, finding all efforts unavailing to make any inroad upon the rebel position, had reembarked on the 2d inst., leaving a considerable quantity of intrenching tools and other property behind, and apparently relinquishing the design upon Vicksburgh.
lead_paragraph: A dispatch from Gen. PEMBERTON, commanding the rebel forces at Vicksburgh, to the rebel War Department, announces that the National forces, finding all efforts unavailing to make any inroad upon the rebel position, had reembarked on the 2d inst., leaving a considerable quantity of intrenching tools and other property behind, and apparently relinquishing the design upon Vicksburgh. We shall, of course, have to wait for our own reports before we can tell how much reliance to place on this one. It may be true that Gen. SHERMAN has been temporarily repulsed, but the supposition that the job of capturing Vicksburgh is given over, is simply absurd. The rebel General does not take into account the force under Gen. BANKS and Admiral FARRAGUT, which has probably before this time arrived in the vicinity. The rise in the Mississippi had commenced at the date of our latest advices from New-Orleans, and FARRAGUT's bull-dogs may even now be barking at PEMBERTON's heels.

abstract: on State Prisoner's Discharge Bill--Senate
snippet: on State Prisoner's Discharge Bill--Senate
lead_paragraph: Senator LITTLE's bill, amendatory of the Act for punishment of crimes, provides that any person convicted of offences punishable by imprisonment in the State Prison, who is over 16 and under 25 years of age, may, in the discretion of the Court, be sent to the Penitentiary, without charge being made against such county for board. It empowers the Governor to appoint an Inspector of Penitentiaries, who shall receive no salary.

abstract: French Consul at New-Orleans, dismissal of
snippet: French Consul at New-Orleans, dismissal of
lead_paragraph: The French Minister, at Washington, has given the most acceptable evidence of the just intentions and friendly sentiments of his Government toward the United States, in the dismissal of Count MEJAN, the French Consul at New-Orleans. This Count MEJAN, from the commencement of the secession movement, distinguished himself as an enemy of the United States Government. He led the entire foreign element at New-Orleans, fomented treason wherever he had influence, induced the representatives of other foreign Governments to back him up in all sorts of offensive and iniquitous proceedings calculated to promote the Confederate rebellion, and finally, after the capture of New-Orleans by our forces, failing to find any past cause of complaint against Gen. BUTLER on his own account or on account of the French citizens of New-Orleans, he indicted a long list of infamous charges against him, on behalf of Germans, Spaniards and Greeks "Jews, Turks and Infidels" -- and sent it directly to his Government at Paris. This paper did more, perhaps, than all else to blacken the name of Gen. BUTLER in the eyes of Europe. But justice overtook the MEJAN at last. His scandalous extra-official conduct was shown up to his masters, the falsehood and malice of his charges made evident, and he gets his deserts in dismissal from a service he had disgraced.

abstract: While we are all supposed to be more or less in a state of anxiety in relation to the cause of the Union at the present time, there may possibly be some confidence derived from the fact that on the occasion of the first "hop" of the season given by the LELANDS of the Metropolitan, there was a larger and more richly dressed assemblage than on any former occasion. There were not, certainly, less than seven hundred persons present and participating, not only in the dance, but in all the other festivities of the evening. Among them, many officers of the army and of the navy, Judges in our Courts, and other prominent men. The dresses of the ladies were the admiration of all -- the most superb (said WARREN) of any he had ever seen in his house before. The dancing commenced soon after 9 o'clock, and with the exception of the intermission for supper, at midnight, was continued until 2 o'clock this morning. It was certainly, in all respects naturally pertaining to such an occasion, one of the most recherche and enjoyable that has been held in the Metropolitan Hotel. White observing the glee and general enthusiasm for the dance, it was very difficult to realize that we are (progressing) in a terrible civil war. There was nothing in the music to remind us of the call to arms, (in the military acceptation of the term;) neither was there anything in the movements of those "who occupied the floor" to remind us of the tramp of armed men.

abstract: Factious Character of his Message
snippet: Factious Character of his Message
lead_paragraph: It is curious, that of the six columns of Governor SEYMOUR's Message, four should be devoted to a single purpose -- alienation. By dilating with emphasis upon State rights -- by denouncing arbitrary arrests -- by elaborately arguing against the rightful possibility of martial law outside of the military lines -- and by stigmatizing the Emancipation Proclamation of the President as "impolitie, unjust, and unconstitutional," he has done his best to diminish confidence in the General Government. And, on the other hand, he has sought to stir up jealousy and bitterness between the larger States and the smaller ones, by dwelling upon their inequality of population and equality of representation in the Senate; and between the lower and the upper Free States, by asserting again and again, in different forms, that it was "the passions and the interests" of the latter that, in conjunction with the secession spirit of the extreme South, occasioned the war.

abstract: mutiny on eve of battle
snippet: mutiny on eve of battle
lead_paragraph: A troop of Pennsylvania cavalry, known as the "Anderson Troop," refused to go into action at Murfreesboro; and they now attempt to justify this treason and mutiny by informing the public that "they had no confidence in their officers, and were disappointed in not having been selected for Gen. ROSECRANS' body-guard." Their notions of discipline and subordination are exactly the same as those of the officers who resigned on the Potomac in consequence of Gen. MCCLELLAN's removal, and of those orators and writers who have ever since been reviling the Government for the liberty it took in depriving him of his command. Between holding that the President has no right to exercise his own judgment in the choice of a Commander-in-Chief, and holding that every private has a right to decide on the day of battle whether he shall fight or not, or if he does, who shall command him, there is no logical stopping-place. So, if Gen. MCCLELLAN be a martyr, by all means let us have a military mass meeting before every engagement, in order to give the down-trodden privates and Corporals an opportunity of telling the General how they feel about his strategy and his tactics, and of discussing what they had better do under the circumstances. We beg to inform the "Anderson Troop," however, that if their lot had been cast a little further South, and they had but to transact business with Gen. FOREY, a very large portion of them would long ere this be relieved, both from obnoxious officers and disagreeable duty, by being shot to death for cowardice and misconduct; and it is a pity and a shame that Gen. ROSECRANS cannot afford them the same consolation.

abstract: At about 7 o'clock last night flames were discovered issuing from the windows on the second floor of No. 29 Barclay Street. The alarm was promptly given, and steam and hand engines were speedily on hand. The stock in the building where the fire originated was, however, almost wholly destroyed by fire and water. The first floor was occupied by HENRY A. SWIFT, domestic dry goods merchant. The second floor by Messrs. BARRIE, DEER & Co., manufacturers of silk trimmings, and the upper stories by several other parties. The aggregate loss on stock in this building will amount to over $40,000. The stock in No. 31, occupied by D. & J. SADLIER, as a bookstore, was seriously damaged by water. The Messrs. SADLIER are fully insured in City Companies. The stock in No. 27 Barclay-street, occupied on the first floor by JAMES ROBINSON, dealer in domestic dry goods, and on the second floor by Messrs. CLIFF & AGEARE, dealers in hosiery, was also largely damaged by water. Their loss is estimated at over $5,000.

abstract: Battle, and some Northern journals
snippet: Battle, and some Northern journals
lead_paragraph: A certain class of Northern journals -- we need not name them -- cannot be comforted on the result of the Murfreesboro battles. If the telegraph tells us BRAGG has been beaten and forced to retreat, "Ah!" those journals respond, "it was a terrible repulse we got in Wednesday's fighting." If ROSECRANS reports the enemy's flight precipitate, and his pursuit of the flying foe active and destructive to their rear guards, we are met with mournful allusions to the few wagons the rebels destroyed in ROSECRANS' rear. If the Murfreesboro Rebel admits a loss of 5,000 Confederates in Wednesday's and Thursday's fights, we are reminded that 4,000 Nationals were reported to be prisoners in rebel hands, and all the guns captured from ROSECRANS safely withdrawn to no one knows where -- where the rebels will make a stand.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, the President announced a Special Committee of three to investigate the alleged frauds in engrossing the Militia bill last year. Wednesdays were fixed upon for holding Executive Sessions. The Standing Committee on Cities and Villages was increased from five to seven. A bill to confirm the official acts of Gov. MORGAN in relation to the payment of bounties to volunteers, was introduced. The Senate then adjourned. In the Assembly, the 26th ballot for Speaker was reached, with no variation of the votes, 63 being cast for Mr. DEAN, and 63 for Mr. SHERWOOD, each time. The Assembly then concluded to adjourn.

abstract: THE NEW ASSESSORS OF BROOKLYN. The city members of the Board of Supervisors met in the Common Council Chamber, City Hall, yesterday af- ternoon, for the purpose of confirming a list of five gentlemen nominated for Assessors by the Mayor, in accordance with the provisions of the amended charter of the City of Brooklyn. Mr. GEORGE G. HERMAN, of the Ninth Ward, was called to the chair. A communication from the Mayor, recommending the following...
lead_paragraph: THE NEW ASSESSORS OF BROOKLYN. -- The city members of the Board of Supervisors met in the Common Council Chamber, City Hall, yesterday af- ternoon, for the purpose of confirming a list of five gentlemen nominated for Assessors by the Mayor, in accordance with the provisions of the amended charter of the City of Brooklyn. Mr. GEORGE G. HERMAN, of the Ninth Ward, was called to the chair. A communication from the Mayor, recommending the following candidates for confirmation, was read: JOHN F. HENNESSEY, of the Eleventh Ward; MARTIN BREEN, of the Sixth Ward; ROBERT J. LUCKEY, of the Third Ward; THOMAS T. GRIFFEN, of the Eighteenth Ward; HENRY E. RIPLEY, of the Thirteenth Ward. A motion to confirm the list as a whole was lost for want of a two-thirds vote, when each name was taken up separately, and every one having received the requisite number of votes was declared elected. The Board then adjourned. The number of Assessors under the old Charter was 19 -- one for each Ward -- and elective, the same as Aldermen and Supervisors. Under the provisions of the amended Charter the number is reduced to five, and appointed by a two-third vote of the City members of the Board of Supervisors.

snippet: New-York, on Foreign Mediation; the Tribune on
lead_paragraph: We regret to perceive that the Tribune persists in its advocacy of foreign mediation, as a just and proper mode of ending the war which the Government of the United States is compelled to wage for the preservation of its own existence. We are glad, however, to find that the Tribune modifies somewhat the position which it originally took on this subject.

abstract: The Confederacy cut in twain by the battle of
snippet: The Confederacy cut in twain by the battle of
lead_paragraph: Like all other great events in time, the battle of Murfreesboro grows in importance as we study its details and pursue the results that flow immediately and prospectively from it. At first, our interest was wholly absorbed in the severity and doubtfulness of the conflict. When the popular apprehension of disaster was relieved, the admiration of the country was fastened upon the valor and endurance of the soldiers, and the omnipresent inspiration and heroism of Gen. ROSECRANS, who snatched a victory from the very dust of defeat. And after the suspense and uncertainty as to the result, and the admiration for the skill and courage that redeemed the once lost fortunes of the day, came the proud joy of a great National victory for our arms, and the salvation of the capital of a great, State, if not the redemption of the entire State, from the presence and power of the rebel despotism.
headline: {'main': 'The Confederacy Cleft in Twain.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Confederacy Cleft in Twain.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: We publish this  morning two orders issued by Gen. HALLECK yesterday One of them announcing "the gratitude of the country and the admiration  of the world" to Gen. ROSECRANS, and the other propounding "the thanks of the country" to Gen. CARTER. The first public bulletin of thanks and praise to our troops during the war was issued by Secretary STANTON to the ...
lead_paragraph: -- We publish this morning two orders issued by Gen. HALLECK yesterday One of them announcing "the gratitude of the country and the admiration of the world" to Gen. ROSECRANS, and the other propounding "the thanks of the country" to Gen. CARTER. The first public bulletin of thanks and praise to our troops during the war was issued by Secretary STANTON to the heroes of Mill Spring; and the last one preceding the present two of HALLECK was to BURNSIDE's army from the President. Congress also has this matter of gratitude and applause in its hands. There is a resolution of thanks to Gen. ROSECRANS now before a Committee of the Senate, and another of thanks to Gen. BUTLER hangs fire in the House. Thus, the Commander-in-Chief, the General-in-Chief, the Secretary of War and Congress have all tried their hands in the matter -- some of them only with moderate success, as regards rhetoric and so forth.

abstract: Displeased with the Emancipation Proclamation
snippet: Displeased with the Emancipation Proclamation
lead_paragraph: -- The Legislature of Kentucky met on Thursday, and Gov. ROBINSON yesterday sent in his Message to the body. It will be seen by the telegraphic mention of it, that the Governor utters his emphatic displeasure with the Emancipation Proclamation of President LINCOLN, and calls on the Legislature also to put on record its protest against the Proclamation. It was not expected that the people of the Border Slave States would yield the same cordial support to the Emancipation edict that the rest of the loyal States have done. The force of law, education and habit retards the development of a war policy based on the emancipation of slaves in States where Slavery has been an institution for generations. The Border Slave States have held on remarkably well to their loyalty, considering the pressure internal and external that has been applied to them by the rebels. They have conquered their prejudices in many particulars, and may yet conquer their present repugnance to the Proclamation. The truly loyal men of the Border States have long since reached and proclaimed the doctrine that if the Union and Slavery became incompatible they would surrender Slavery rather than the Union. They do not believe that the necessity for one or the other to be overthrown yet exists. But the President does, and so do the vast majority of the loyal people of the country. The question with the Kentuckians now is, will they yield to a result which they have repeatedly avowed they are ready for in a certain contingency, -- the overthrow of Slavery to preserve the Union -- or will they, by rebelling, destroy the Union because they do not think with the great majority, that the crisis demanding the choice between the two is at hand? We confess we have strong hope that the reasonableness and loyalty of the State of HENRY CLAY will gloriously be sustained in this last and hardest test of its patriotism.
headline: {'main': 'KENTUCKY AND THE PROCLAMATION.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'KENTUCKY AND THE PROCLAMATION.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: By the arrival at Halifax of the steamship Africa, we have advices from Europe to the 28th ult., -- three days later. The political news is unimportant, and the commercial advices are meagre. The steamship China, from this port, arrived out on the 27th. The news received by her of the National defeat at Fredericksburgh, was the universal topic on Saturday. The friends of the North were greatly disappointed. The general deduction drawn in Liverpool was unfavorable to an early peace. Business was suspended by the holidays, but there was talk of quiet transactions in cotton at a further advance. Breadstufts were quiet, but firmer. The Stock Exchange resumed business on Saturday, when Consols were quoted at 92 1/2@92 [???] for money. Erie shares 42@43. Illinois Central shares 42@41 discount.

abstract: The "postal currency," as it is called, issued by the General Government, is very abundant, and makes change more abundant than it has been for a long time. If anyone has doubts on this subject, we shall be glad to supply him with such fractional currency as he may require. There is not the slightest necessity or excuse for shinplasters, either of corporations or individuals. And yet they are becoming more and more abundant every day.

abstract: The steamer Marion, Capt. JOHNSON, from New-Orleans on Jan. 2, arrived at this port this morning. She brings very little news. The capitol at Baton Rouge was burned on the night of Dec. 30. Fire was discovered early in the evening. It was apparently subdued about 9 o'clock, and it was supposed that the danger was past, but the flames soon after broke out with renewed violence, and the whole structure was consumed. No loss of life is mentioned. The Baton Rouge Comet, of Dec. 31, says:

abstract: On Tuesday last, a respectable and intelligent-appearing man applied at No. 9 Bayard-street for lodgings. He gave his name, but stated he wished to engage a room for a short time only. Being satisfied with the room shown him, the stranger brought his luggage at once and took possession. He had very little to say to any one, and passed in and out of the house noiselessly, and in a manner disturbed no one. Yesterday it was observed that he did not go out, and in the afternoon the lady of the house sent her little daughter up to clean the room. She came running back, saying the room had a strange appearance, and that there were balls and powder scattered about on the table. The mother immediately went up, and found the unknown lying on his face across the bed. Upon examination be was found to be dead, life appearing to have been extinct some hours. A bullet wound in the head, and a discharged pistol lying near his hand told the story of his death. The mother then recollected hearing the report of a pistol about 8 o'clock the evening previous, and thinks the man must have shot himself about that time. The Coroner has been notified, and will investigate the case to-day. Deceased has left some luggage and a large number of papers behind him, some of which will undoubtedly disclose his history. At present, nothing is known concerning him.

abstract: George Cris???old Sailed with Relief for Lancas??? Operatives
snippet: George Cris???old Sailed with Relief for Lancas??? Operatives
lead_paragraph: -- Yesterday afternoon the new and splendid ship George Griswold, laden with gifts of food for the famished operatives of Lancashire, was towed down the Bay of New-York, and this morning she will spread her sails, and start on her voyage across the wide ocean, for the shores of England. As she moved down the Bay yesterday, she was saluted by several British vessels in the harbor; and the crowd of sailors and citizens on her deck, as well as on the steamer which towed her out, and on the other vessels in the vicinity, exhibited their generous enthusiasm by the most vociferous shouts and cheers. A nobler spectacle was never seen in our beautiful Bay. In a few weeks she will arrive in Liverpool, and, perhaps before the close of the month, her stores will have been distributed to the hungry, and the blessings of those who are ready to perish will have been called down upon America.

abstract: Delano vs. American Insurance Company of Boston; Construction of Policy; Chubb vs. 7,800 bushels of oats; cargo on deck lost
snippet: Delano vs. American Insurance Company of Boston; Construction of Policy; Chubb vs. 7,800 bushels of oats; cargo on deck lost
lead_paragraph: John H. Chubb et at. vs. About 7,800 bushels of Oats. -- This was a libel filed to recover freight on these oats, which were carried on the libelant's boat Mary Eva from St. Antoine, Canada East, to NewYork, and demurrage for the detention of the boat, in New-York. The evidence showed that a larger quantity of oats were shipped on board, a portion of them being shipped in binns on deck. While the boat was passing through Lake Champlain in tow of a steamer, the usual mode of going through the lake, a gale arose, and as the boat turned Cumberland Head, to go into Pittsburgh, to avoid the violence of the gate, the boats were dashed against each other, and one of the binns gave way and a portion of the oats were lost overboard. The bill of lading was a clean bill of lading, with the usual exemption from perils of the seas. The claimant sought to set off against the libelous demand the value of the oats so lost overboard. The libelant proposed to meet this by proving that it was the usage of that particular trade to carry oats thus, in binns on deck. To this evidence the claimants objected, as being contrary to the terms of the bill of lading.

abstract: In the Senate yesterday, Mr. WILSON, of Massachusetts, introduced a bill for the construction of a  ship canal between the Mississippi River and Lake Michigan, and to enlarge the locks of certain canals in New-York, to allow the passage of gunboats. It was ordered to be printed. Notice was given of a bill to aid Western Virginia in emancipating her slaves.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate yesterday, Mr. WILSON, of Massachusetts, introduced a bill for the construction of a ship canal between the Mississippi River and Lake Michigan, and to enlarge the locks of certain canals in New-York, to allow the passage of gunboats. It was ordered to be printed. Notice was given of a bill to aid Western Virginia in emancipating her slaves. Mr. POWELL, of Kentucky, called up his resolution censuring GRANT's order expelling the Jews from his Department, when it transpired that the order has already been revoked, and the resolution was laid on the table. The bill for the punishment of persons convicted of crime in the District of Columbia was passed. A bill was introduced by Mr. COLLAMER, of Vermont, to regulate judicial proceedings in certain cases. It relates to the so-called arbitrary arrests, and the cases arising out of them. It was referred to the Judiciary Committee. The bill for the relief of the Norwegian bark Admiral P. Tadenskiold was passed. The joint resolution for the prompt payment of our soldiers, sailors and marines, was reported back from the Finance Committee, with an amendment as a substitute. A bill to suspend the sale of land on the islands on the coast of South Carolina and Georgia, was referred to the Military Committee. The credentials of Mr. JAMES A. BAYARD, reelected Senator from Delaware, were presented. The bill providing for the raising of volunteers for the defence of Kentucky was debated at considerable length, but was not disposed of when the Senate went into Executive Session.

abstract: New-York; collision, Hudson, ferry-boat, and W.O. Brown, propeller; Hudson ferry boat and propeller W. O. Brown--collision
snippet: New-York; collision, Hudson, ferry-boat, and W.O. Brown, propeller; Hudson ferry boat and propeller W. O. Brown--collision
lead_paragraph: FEARFUL COLLISION ON THE NORTH RIVER -SINGULAR AND FATAL ACCIDENT TO A PILOT. -- About 8 A.M. yesterday a fearful collision occurred between the ferryboat Hudson, of the Jersey City and Desbrosses-street Ferry, and the propeller towboat Wm.O. Brown, belonging to the New-Jersey Lighter and Transportation Company, which resulted in the death of a young man named JOHN GADDIS, son of Mr. GADDIS, Paymaster of the New-Jersey Railroad Company. The particulars were as follows: The boats were crossing the river in opposite directions, at which time the pilot of the towboat was in the cabin eating his breakfast, and the deceased, Mr. GADDIS, was at the wheel in the pilot-house. The pilot, JOHN KEARNEY, heard the bell ring to slow, and a moment after to stop. He then went outside, and as he did so the bow of the tug-boat struck the ferry-boat just aft of the wheel with such tremendous force that she was thrown on her beam ends. Mr. GADDIS was thrown against the pilot-house door with such force that the hinges and fastenings were broken away, and his body went overboard and was picked up by a revenue boat, but life was extinct. The ferry-boat escaped with but slight injury. The deck planks on the tug boat were started and the water tank below broke loose and sprung aleak, which at first caused alarm, as it was supposed the tug was sinking. Mr. GADDIS' body was brought to the ferry depot, foot of Chambers-street, where an investigation was held by Coroner COLLIN, of New-York. The testimony showed that it was the determination of the pilot on the ferryboat to cross the bows of the propeller; that the former had ample time to go behind the latter, and thereby the collision might very easily have been avoided. Several witnesses were examined, and all concurred in the above state of facts. At the conclusion of the testimony the Jury rendered the following verdict: "We find that the deceased came to his death in consequence of injuries produced by a collision between the propeller William O. Brown and the Jersey City ferryboat Hudson, on on the 9th day of January, 1863; and we believe that the pilot of the Hudson could have avoided a collision, and we think he censurable for neglect of proper caution and care." The deceased was 26 years of age, and resided in New-Jersey. A man named S.V.P. BENTLEG, employed on the propeller, was thrown overboard at the time of the collision, and barely escaped with his life.

abstract: Disturnell, J.; Register of Army and Navy; Prince de Joinville; History of the Army of the Potomac; thud notice; History of the Army of the Potomac; Third Notice
snippet: Disturnell, J.; Register of Army and Navy; Prince de Joinville; History of the Army of the Potomac; thud notice; History of the Army of the Potomac; Third Notice
lead_paragraph: In our last notice of this work, we followed the author to the battle in front of Williamsburgh, where the retreating rebels made a stand mainly for the purpose of delaying pursuit. This object they accomplished completely. The main body of the Confederate army had passed through the town on Friday and Saturday, the 2d and 3d of May. On Sunday, the evacuation of Yorktown was discovered by Gen. MCCLELLAN, who thereupon, in a tone of exultation, proclaimed his purpose to "push the enemy to the wall." On Monday, the rebel rear guard engaged our advance in front of Williamsburgh with so much success, though finally forced to yield, that Gen. MCCLELLAN moderated his expectations considerably, and confined himself to saying that his forces were "inferior to those of the enemy," but that he should "venture to hold him in check." His purpose of a rapid pursuit seems to have been at once abandoned. Gen. FRANKLIN left Yorktown for West Point on Tuesday, and on Wednesday, attempting to land to attack the retreating column of the rebels in flank, was repulsed -- the main body of Gen. MCCLELLAN's army failing to support turn by attacking the enemy on the rear. Indeed, instead of pushing forward in rapid pursuit and to the aid of Gen. FRANKLIN, Gen. MCCLELLAN, with his whole army, remained at Williamsburgh three days, "looking up the wounded who were scattered through the woods, and burying the dead."

abstract: A most ingenious fraud in regard to New-Orleans Bank Notes, has been perpetrated by a money broker upon one of the most respectable banking firms in Wall-street, under the following peculiar circumstances. It is a shrewd swindle, and has created much talk among those who have heard of it. GEORGE D. ARTHUR & CO., of No. 34 Wall-street, are the victims. It appears by the affidavit of GEORGE H. LE HURAY, one of the firm, upon which Judge MCCUNN issued his warrant, and the party was arrested by Officer RICHARD DOUGHERTY, that on the 14Th of last November, a person named JOSEPH A. LEVY, doing business in Nassau-street as a money broker, hastily went into GEORGE D. ARTHUR & CO's., and inquired what they would give for the notes of the Bank of New-Orleans. Mr. LE HURAY said they would give 90 per cent for them. LEVY thereupon produced five $100 bills of the Bank of New-Orleans, and said he would take 90 cents. Mr. LE HURAY took them, and after giving them a careful examination, said he did not feel quite satisfied that they were all right. LEVY said there could be no doubt about the bills; that he knew the source they came from, and that they were good. Mr. LE HURAY, not knowing anything positively against the bills, and believing the representations of LEVY to be true, thereupon paid LEVY $450 cash for them. ARTHUR & CO. then sold them to a Mr. H.F. MILLER, with the firm of P.C. & WM.B. BAKER, of this City, who are in the New-Orleans trade, and as Mr. MILLER was about to proceed to New-Orleans, ARTHUR & CO. received 95 cents on the dollar for the bills. Upon MILLER's arrival in New-Orleans, he discovered that the bills were entirely worthless, being the old notes of the Bank of New-Orleans, which had long since been canceled, and deposited with the State Auditor at Baton Rouge. The Bank having its securities filed with the Auditor, upon which their circulation depends, is compelled, in taking these securities up, to cancel their bills, which is done by cross-cutting them on each of their corners and across their faces, by what is called a canceling hammer, used by banks for this purpose. They are thus effectually destroyed for the purpose of circulation, and become then the vouchers of the State Auditor for the protection of his department and the bank that its securities have been canceled. The notes thus bring in the Auditor's office, were stolen from it when our army took possession of Baton Rouge, and the manner the bills were afterward prepared and patched up by those who got possession of them, for circulation, is most curious and skilfully ingenious. Pieces of the most delicate imaginable tissue paper had been pasted over the backs of them, and the edges of the cross cut carefully brought together and so admirably united that the keenest eye, unless probably that of an expert's, could not detect the crosscuts upon the faces of the bills, and most any one would be deceived by them, until by constant circulation and handling, the tissue paper becomes worn out and breaks over the cuts, permitting the edges to turn up. Even then a person used only to ordinarily handling money would take them without suspicion. It is not known what amount of these notes were taken from the Auditor's office, but it is supposed to be a very large quantity, and sent North, as speculators going to New-Orleans would readily buy them, if such a firm as ARTHUR & CO. could be deceived by them. As soon as ARTHUR & CO. were informed of the fraud, they immediately redeemed the notes here, and caused the arrest of LEVY, who was brought before Judge MCCUNN, where the matter is still pending. It is to be hoped that not many of these bills have yet been offered here as they are a most dangerous fraud. It appears that the Bank of New-Orleans some time since cautioned the public against them, but it is quite probable that but few have seen the notice, especially brokers and Southern dealers. The following is the notice published in the New-Orleans Be[???]:

abstract: Bickerings Between
snippet: Bickerings Between
lead_paragraph: We think that the men and the newspapers who are trying to stir up a spirit of animosity between the West and the East, had better cease their labors. Those journals in the Western cities, and in this City, who are beginning to make attacks upon New-England, and threatening to expel it from the Union, and those journals in New-England who are replying feelingly to these assaults, would do well to mutually ground arms, lest these stray shots lead to skirmishes, and end in close quarters and a general hullaballoo. There is and can be no geographical quarrel in this country. The present war is not a struggle between two points of the compass, North and South, but, as we are often enough told, between the principles of aristocracy and slavery on the one hand, and democracy and freedom on the other. There is and can be no such contest of fundamental political principles between the Free States of the East and those, of the West. Nevertheless touch bad blood may be stirred up between any two sections or any two or more States by bad and designing men playing upon popular prejudices; and the peace, happiness and permanent unity of the country may thus be constantly threatened. There are no two sections, nor two States, nor two villages, nor hardly two men in the land, but could make up plausible grounds of dissatisfaction or quarrel, or battle, with each other. But the beauty of our political system is that it furnishes means of removing all just causes of dissatisfaction, and adjusting peacefully all quarrels. The charges in the present case seem to be, on the one hand, in general, that New-England is fanatical; and, on the other, that the assailants of New-England are something worse even than that. Both charges may be perfectly true, and yet so long as the constitutional rights of each section and every State are respected, we do not see why they should not live together forever on terms of amity and in political fraternity. So let the bickerings be stopped, we would like to say, before they are begun.
headline: {'main': 'EAST AND WEST.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'EAST AND WEST.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Effect of on the South; Effect of the War on the
snippet: Effect of on the South; Effect of the War on the
lead_paragraph: We have been reminded lately of the description which RUSSELL sent to the London Times of his visit to the trenches and encampments of the South Carolinians before Fort Sumter. We recollect it as presenting a very rose-colored view of not only the pomp and circumstance, but of the comfort and even the luxury of "glorious war." The picture of those high-mettled scions of Southern chivalry, whose main occupation appeared to be popping champagne corks and manufacturing claret punch, was enough to set even the dull imagination of John Bull on fire. But how terribly changed all that has been in two years. Now any account of the condition of the rebel soldiers is only a statement of raggedness and filth, and brings up only visions of things "both common and unclean" -- and instead of the foaming beakers of champagne and the cool draughts of claret which were then apparently the "steady drink" of the rebel private soldiers, we have from the Richmond papers the melancholy statement that apple brandy, at $20 a gallon, is now the best and cheapest liquor in that market, while "the vilest whisky, which, before the war, a gentleman would not give to his negroes, is now eagerly sought after and bought at from $25 to $30 a gallon." What a terrible state of destitution these statements exhibit. It is enough to excite the sympathy of all the liquor-dealers in the world.

abstract: Adrian Janes and others vs. Danl. C. Van Norman and Chos. C. North.--This was an action on a promissory note made by Van Norman and indorsed by North, for $665, dated Jan. 3, 1861. The answer alleged that the note was given in pursuance of a con
lead_paragraph: Adrian Janes and others vs. Danl. C. Van Norman and Chos. C. North. -- This was an action on a promissory note made by Van Norman and indorsed by North, for $665, dated Jan. 3, 1861. The answer alleged that the note was given in pursuance of a contract by which the plaintiffs agreed to furnish materials, and make and construct three hot water furnaces in the house Nos. 3 and 5 West Thirty-eighth-street, known as the "Van Norman Institute," a seminary for young ladies, and to construct said furnaces so that the same would well and sufficiently warm said two houses, and require no more fuel than hot-air furnaces; and so that the same should and would give satisfaction to the defendant Van Norman, for the price of $2,287 55, and alleging bleaches of said agreement in the three respects, and alleging also that in consequence of the defective construction of the furnace, the same did not warm the house, although a greater amount of fuel was used than was required by hot-air furnaces; and that in consequence thereof the school was broken up for a considerable period of time, and the same could not be used, and the defendant Van Norman demands judgment in his favor for damages.

abstract: Ionian Islands Ced??? to Greece by Great Britain; Ionian Islands, Cession of to Greece
snippet: Ionian Islands Ced??? to Greece by Great Britain; Ionian Islands, Cession of to Greece
lead_paragraph: The Ionian Islanders have at last apparently carried their point, as England has offered to turn them over to Greece, with the consent of the other great Powers. For many years past they have been in a condition of discontent, not far removed from rebellion; and during Sir HENRY WARD's Administration, twelve years ago, there was an actual outbreak, which was repressed with great severity. Since then they have confined themselves to paper hostilities. At the opening of every session of the Legislature, an address was presented to the Governor, informing him of the desire of the people to be annexed to Greece, and he as regularly replied that their prayer would not be granted; and they then, refusing to do any further business, were regularly prorogued or dissolved. Mr. GLADSTONE was sent out as a Commissioner or pacificator, soon after the publication of his pamphlet on the Neapolitan prisons, and it was supposed that his well-known philhellenism would give weight to his counsels. It did nothing of the kind. He was met by the stereotyped request for emancipation from British control, and as he had no authority to negotiate on this basis, he came home a sadder and wiser man, having accomplished nothing. Since then Ionian politics have been marked by a monotony for which there is no parallel in the annals of discontent. The islands suffered greatly from the want of all legislation. Everything which depended on parliamentary action tell into decay very soon, and there appeared to be no help for it, as the Parliament would not legislate unless notice were taken of its petitions, and the Executive invariably sent them back unnoticed.

abstract: F.L. OLMSTED, Esq.--Sir: The report of the "Battle of Fredericksburgh," Dec. 13, was brought to us by telegraph the night of the battle. lead_paragraph: F.L. OLMSTED, Esq. -- Sir: The report of the "Battle of Fredericksburgh," Dec. 13, was brought to us by telegraph the night of the battle. The next morning a propeller was chartered, laden with stores, and with a special relief party, consisting of Dr. H. G. CLARK, Dr. S.C. FOSTER, Dr. SWALM, Dr. HOMISTON, Mr. ELLIOTT, Mr. ABBOTT and Mr. WALTER, all connected with the Commission, and, with Rev. Mr. CHANNING, Mr. PAGE, Mr. HALL and Mr. WEBSTER, volunteers, I started at evening for the front.

abstract: Message of; Burton, Gov., of Delaware, Message of; Message of
snippet: Message of; Burton, Gov., of Delaware, Message of; Message of
lead_paragraph: The Message of Gov. YATES, of Illinois, is very long, and discusses many measures of general interest. The total real and personal wealth of the State is estimated at $1,000,000,000--the census of 1860 having placed it at $871,860,282. In population, Illinois has increased from the rank of seventh state in 1850, to a fourth in 1860, being then 1,711,951. In railroads, it is really the first, though nominally the second State in the Union, having now 3,000 miles, a ainst 95 m[???]es ten years since. The cost of these roads was $104,944 561. They delivered in 1862 at Chicago 70,000,000 bushels of grain, more than 900,000 hogs and over 170,000 head of beef cattle.

abstract: Army Loafers in New-York
snippet: Army Loafers in New-York
lead_paragraph: -On walking up Broadway one of these Winter afternoons, one would imagine there were enough United States soldiers in the City to overthrow and overrun the whole rebel Confederacy. Officers and soldiers swarm on every square, and in every shop. It is very easy to believe the statement made in the Senate on Wednesday last, by WILSON, of Massachusetts, that there are now seven thousand eight hundred officers absent from the army, with or without leave, and 411 have deserted from the front. Those in the City are of course mostly from the Army of the Potomac; and we do not wonder that they prefer the City to the camp -- the saloons, theatres and family firesides to the tents and huts along Aquia Creek and the Rappahaanock. The Metropolis is a very nice place to loaf in; and when the army is doing nothing, the men doubtless can't see but what they might as well enjoy themselves. They seem all to have got their pay, too, along with their leave of absence.

abstract: The steamship Jura passed Cape Race yesterday, with advices from Europe five days later. She left Liverpool on the 1st inst., and Londonderry on the 2d. The workingmen of Manchester had held a meeting to express their sympathy with the North, at which an address to President LINCOLN, congratulating him on his course, was adopted.
lead_paragraph: The steamship Jura passed Cape Race yesterday, with advices from Europe five days later. She left Liverpool on the 1st inst., and Londonderry on the 2d. The workingmen of Manchester had held a meeting to express their sympathy with the North, at which an address to President LINCOLN, congratulating him on his course, was adopted. It is announced that the English revenue accounts show an increase during the year of £2,392,000. The London Times argues from this increase that Cotton is not King, and that it would be far better for England to keep all her cotton operatives on public pensions until they are absorbed in other trades, than to vary one point in her National policy. Additional French troops are imperatively called for in Mexico, to the extent of ten thousand men. Cotton had a downward tendency in the Liverpool market, owing to the stock being largely in excess of the estimates. Breadstuffs were steady and unchanged. Provisions were very dull. Consols were quoted at 92 1/2@92 5/8 for money.

abstract: The steamer Marion, Capt. JOHNSON, from New-Orleans on Jan. 2, arrived at this port yesterday morning. She brings very little news. The capitol at Baton Rouge was burned on the night of Dec. 30. Fire was discovered early in the evening.
lead_paragraph: The steamer Marion, Capt. JOHNSON, from New-Orleans on Jan. 2, arrived at this port yesterday morning. She brings very little news. The capitol at Baton Rouge was burned on the night of Dec. 30. Fire was discovered early in the evening. It was apparently subdued about nine o'clock, and it was supposed that the danger was past, but the flames soon after broke out with re[???] violence, and the whole structure was consumed. No loss of life is mentioned. The Baton Rouge Comet, of Dec. 31, says:

abstract: An inquest was held, yeserday, by Coroner WILDEY, upon the body of JOHN A. MORRIS, late Quarermaster in the United States Navy. We gave an account of the manner of his death, and such further acts as could then be learned about the deceased, in the evening edition of the TIMES yesterday.
lead_paragraph: An inquest was held, yeserday, by Coroner WILDEY, upon the body of JOHN A. MORRIS, late Quarermaster in the United States Navy. We gave an account of the manner of his death, and such further acts as could then be learned about the deceased, in the evening edition of the TIMES yesterday. The inquest, however developed some further facts in regard to the unfortunate victim. It appears that on Tuesday last, MORRIS applied at a boarding-house, No. 9 Bayard-street, for lodgings. He gave his name as JOHN A. MORRIS, and stated that he wished to engage a room there for a few days. A room was shown him, with which he expressed himself satisfied, and his baggage was accordingly taken to the apartment. He had little to say to any one in the house, and passed in and out very noiselessly; indeed he behaved himself in such a manner that during the short time he was there all in the establishment were induced to regard him as a sober and respectable gentleman. On Thursday it was observed that he did not go out, as he had previously been in the habit of doing, and the landlady sent her daughter, toward evering, to see if the gentleman wanted anything. The girl shortly returned with the report that his room had a very strange appearance, and that there were balls and powder scattered on the table and floor. The mother then went up, and found MORRIS lying on his face across the bed, entirely lifeless -his cold and stiffened limbs indicating that he had been dead some hours.

abstract: FIRE DEPARTMENT ELECTIONS.--The annual elections for officers of the companies in the Newark Fire Department takes place to-morrow evening. The Chief Engineer holds his office by appointment of Common Council, and during their pleasure, the Department being a paid one. The companies,
lead_paragraph: FIRE DEPARTMENT ELECTIONS. -- The annual elections for officers of the companies in the Newark Fire Department takes place to-morrow evening. The Chief Engineer holds his office by appointment of Common Council, and during their pleasure, the Department being a paid one. The companies, however, have the privilege of electing their own officers, subject to the ratification of the Common Council. There has been during the past year a considerable division of feeling in the Department upon the question of the election of Chief Engineer; one party favoring a change in the present mode, so as to give the companies the right to elect, and the other holding to the present plan. It is probable a majority of the Department are in favor of a change. An application to the Legislature was warmly urged at the last session for a law to effect such change, but the project was defeated, being strongly opposed by the City Government. We do not learn that it is proposed to renew the application this Winter, although the feeling runs as high as ever.

abstract: His Confession of Failure
snippet: His Confession of Failure
lead_paragraph: The rebels have a chastened spirit at last, and freely acknowledge that some things are impossible to their arms. It is a good sign. The greatest enemy of wisdom is conceit. And the greatest enemy of loyalty has been conceit -- conceit on the part of the Southrons of their military prowess, which they deemed invincible. They believed that the rest of the nation stood in awe of Southern chivalry. They did not think the largest "Yankee army" that could ever be drawn together, would stand five minutes in battle-front before a division of rampant Southern Hotspurs, all of whom were of the "half-horse, half-alligator" type. They never expected to fight a battle on Southern soil, but confidently predicted to us and to all the world that they would wage their war in Northern States, forage on Northern farms, and sack Northern cities.

abstract: ANNUAL MEETING OF THE STOCKHOLDERS OF THE ACADEMY OF MUSIC.--The annual meeting of the stockholders of the Brooklyn Academy of Music was held last evening. R.H. LOWRIE, Esq., occupied the Chair. The financial statement shows that the entire
lead_paragraph: ANNUAL MEETING OF THE STOCKHOLDERS OF THE ACADEMY OF MUSIC.-- The annual meeting of the stockholders of the Brooklyn Academy of Music was held last evening. R.H. LOWRIE, Esq., occupied the Chair. The financial statement shows that the entire income was $21,530 67, less $328 13 cash on hand. Of this the actual income for rent last year was $13,430 50. The expenses were $9,722 20, leaving a surplus or $3,708 30. The cost of making improvements, altering the seats, &c., was $5,422 96, paid by extra assessment. The following gentlemen were elected Directors for the ensuing year: Edward Whitehouse, Alexander McCue, Edward Lambert, Gordon L. Ford, Ethelbert S. Mills.
