abstract: His Grand Remedy for Sectionalism
snippet: His Grand Remedy for Sectionalism
lead_paragraph: Gov. SEYMOUR's grand remedy for sectionalism is, that the North and South should not only respect each other, but speak respectfully of each other. He acknowledges at the same time that "the subject of the controversy" in which the hard words which have led to all our present wars were spoken, was Slavery; and that out of this controversy arose all that mutual contempt, and that disregard for the constituted authorities, which he alleges to have been the direct cause of the civil war. And it is clear, from the general tenor of his Message, that his idea of a perfect, indissoluble Union is one in which nothing shall be said at the North which shall hurt the feelings of people at the South, and vice versa. In this he but expresses the sentiments of the greater portion of the Democratic Party. With them no picture of national happiness and prosperity is complete in which there is any writing, or preaching, or talking against Slavery, or in which Slavery is ever mentioned except in praise. The South, they say, is on this subject extremely sensitive. Its people are excitable, and will not submit to these attacks on their social organization. So if we wish to preserve the Union, there must be an end to them.

abstract: Telegraph, Atlantic, New Projects of an
snippet: Telegraph, Atlantic, New Projects of an
lead_paragraph: The first attempt to establish telegraphic communication between Europe and America was net entirely a failure. If, owing to the defective construction of the cable, and other causes, the undertaking could not be carried out, its feasibility and importance were nevertheless demonstrated. More than three hundred messages had been transmitted over the wires, during the brief period of their operation; and by some of these, interesting political intelligence was communicated, large sums of money were saved, the fears of merchants and ship-owners, touching the fate of vessels and cargoes, were set at rest, and the anxiety of individuals and families for friends at sea allayed.

abstract: An Unlucky Rebel General
snippet: An Unlucky Rebel General
lead_paragraph: The braggart BRAGG has been one of the most unlucky Generals in the rebel service. His first station was in Western Florida, at Pensacola, where he made several efforts to take Fort Pickens, but all his operations and efforts there ended in our capturing Pensacola and the fortifications he had erected with such vast labor. From Florida he moved his army Northward, and for the last year he has been campaigning in the Southwest, with almost invariably bad success. On the Cumberland he was driven hack, at Shiloh he was badly beaten, and in East Tennessee he did nothing. When, three or four months ago, he marched at the head of a great army into Northern Kentucky, and from the Capital of the State issued his high-sounding Proclamation to the People of the Northwest, it was only that he might fight a useless fight at Perryville, wheel round again with his force to the South, and travel back with a disorganized army into Tennessee. From the Eastern part of the latter State he moved to its centre, and took up a position at Murfreesboro, from whence he announced his purpose first to capture Nashville, and then follow up his assured victory by planting his flag on the banks of the Ohio. He remained stationary at Murfreesboro for over two months, when ROSECRANS, weary of waiting for his assault, marched out and gave him battle in his chosen position, with results now known to all the world. It is a wonder, after such a record of disaster, that JEFF. DAVIS don't break BRAGG. Bragg is not a good dog.

abstract: then, and a secure oceanic bed to rest it on, what danger of failure can there be? And when once the cable is laid, and in successful operation, the speculation is sure to turn out not less profitable than glorious. There are 150,000 miles of telegraph in the Eastern Hemisphere, and 40,000 miles of it in our Western World, which can only intercommunicate through the Transatlantic line, and hence that line will have a virtual monopoly of business intercourse between America and Europe and Asia. But this is far from being the sole advantage which the Atlantic Telegraph Company will enjoy. By virtue of the agency of our enterprising countryman, Mr. FIELD, a bonus of 40 per cent. is to be allowed it by the New-York and Newfoundland Company, for all matter transmitted from Europe which shall be sent over their line; while the United States Government is still willing to sustain it to the same extent as will that of Great Britain; and, as it is not very likely that the British Government will suffer itself to be outdone in liberality by the American, the Atlantic Telegraph Company is pretty sure to have the support and patronage of both. Every circumstance, in fact, will tend to promote the success and prosperity of this second experiment, for the consummation of which the nations of two hemispheres are anxiously awaiting.

abstract: The, and the National Income
snippet: The, and the National Income
lead_paragraph: -- The value of the taxable property in New-York is officially stated at $571,967,345. This magnificent accumulation of wealth, which constitutes the glory of the third City in the world, is said to be about equal in value to one year's net profits of the loyal States, after paying the cost of the war. This estimate is approximately correct. There is no fear that our people, when possessed of such prodigious resources, will be unable to raise among themselves, without foreign aid, all the funds necessary for the suppression of the rebellion. The ordinary amount of capital continually produced and continually seeking employment, will more than suffice for the supply of the National wants. The census returns show that the real and personal property of the loyal States, which in 1850 was five thousand millions of dollars, had in 1860 accumulated to twelve thousand millions. At this ratio of yearly growth, the loyal States would be gaining one thousand and fifty millions of dollars a year, after paying for the subsistence of the people, and deducting the loss of productive laborers for the army. The rest of our exuberant productive forces -- our steam engines, our multiplying machinery, our labor-saving inventions, our fertile land -- are as busily employed as ever in the work of enriching the nation. The aggregate products this year will probably be not less, but greater, than in 1860.

abstract: We knew nothing further of affairs at Vicksburgh at the time of going to press this morning. In the absence of anything later, we give elsewhere, from the Western papers, such information regarding the conflict there as has not already been given in our brief dispatches.
lead_paragraph: We knew nothing further of affairs at Vicksburgh at the time of going to press this morning. In the absence of anything later, we give elsewhere, from the Western papers, such information regarding the conflict there as has not already been given in our brief dispatches. It appears that Gen. SHERMAN as was met by an overwhelming force on Sunday. He captured the first battery or outwork of nine guns. On Monday afternoon, about 2 o'clock, he took the second battery on Walnut Hill, at the point of the bayonet. He held it forty minutes, when PRICE's whole army charged upon and retook it. The fighting was terrible. The Fourth Iowa went into action with 752 men, and came out with 120. It was believed, at last accounts, that the enemy was evacuating Port Hudson, as boats from below could be seen busily engaged in front of Vicksburgh.

abstract: Adams, Nehemiah, D. D.; Broadcast; Boyd's Graver Thoughts of a Country Parson; Andrews, Henry; Eclogues and Georgics of Virgil; Burton, J. H.; The Book Hunter; Abbey, H. L.; May Dreams; Phelps, S. D., D. D.; Holy Land and Europe; American Presbyterian and Theological Renew
snippet: Adams, Nehemiah, D. D.; Broadcast; Boyd's Graver Thoughts of a Country Parson; Andrews, Henry; Eclogues and Georgics of Virgil; Burton, J. H.; The Book Hunter; Abbey, H. L.; May Dreams; Phelps, S. D., D. D.; Holy Land and Europe; American Presbyte...
lead_paragraph: -- The republication of Mr. BOYD'S Essays in this country was not very happily heralded in the beginning. The first volume was put forth as The Recreations of a Country Parson. Naturally enough, the idea occurred to all apprehensive minds that what was recreation for a country parson would be anything but fun for his audience. At least it was with some such impression that we turned over the pages of that first book. This wore away, however, as successive chapters unfolded themselves, until finally the author revealed himself to our surprised senses as one of the most pleasing essayists of the age. It is urged against him that he never rises above a certain level; but it must be borne in mind that that level is in itself considerably above that of the common sea of literature, and also that he very seldom falls below it. He tells a great many simple truths -- truths that are generally recognized by the popular mind without dispute; but he tells them in an unostentatious, conversational way, and not with the important air of one who fancies he has discovered new continents in the wake of other explorers. There is a certain sameness about his writings; but to find fault with an author for this would be about as reasonable as to find fault with a cherry tree for bringing forth each successive season nothing but cherries. If the cherries are good, we should be content, and willing to look for peaches and pears on other trees. Each human mind is to be regarded as a piece of machinery specially adapted to the performance of some particular work, and not to the turning out with equal excellence of things as different and varied from each other in mould and nature as horn buttons and silver spoons. The Graver Thoughts of a Country Parson are published by TICKNOR & FIELDS. In this volume the Parson puts on his gown, and speaks to his parish of readers in something of an ex cathedra style. In no respect does this collection of essays differ from his preceding ones, save that formerly he spoke of trifles, and now he discourses of eternal interests. He preaches a cheerful religion, adapted to human needs and human capacity. With the chapter on "Christian Self-Denial" we are especially pleased. The Parson takes a sensible, manly stand against the too-prevalent idea that self-torment is one of the surest and most acceptable means of praising and pleasing God.

abstract: We have at last authentic advices from Vicksburgh, a dispatch-boat having arrived at Cairo from the mouth of the Yazoo. It appears that the repulse of Gen. SHERMAN was complete, and the entire force under the direction of Gen. MCCLERNAND, reembarked on transports, closely pressed by the enemy -- who, however, coming too near the gunboats, were driven back with heavy loss. At last accounts, the expedition had arrived at Island No. 82, on the way to Napoleon. The fighting at Vicksburgh has evidently been much exaggerated, as our losses are now stated at only 600 killed, 1,500 wounded, and 1,000 missing.
lead_paragraph: We have at last authentic advices from Vicksburgh, a dispatch-boat having arrived at Cairo from the mouth of the Yazoo. It appears that the repulse of Gen. abstract: Keyes's Raid on the; The Operations Against
snippet: Keyes's Raid on the; The Operations Against
lead_paragraph: With the best disposition in the world to be satisfied with Western war movements, in view of their general gratifying success, we confess we find it impossible to regard the result of our operations against Vicksburgh without strong disfavor. The country has been grievously disappointed in that quarter. We were promised a speedy success, and had a right to expect it. The strongest combination of the war was to be brought to bear against Vicksburgh. SHERMAN, with a powerful armada and army on transports, was to move down upon it from the north, and GRANT, with his formidable army, was to threaten it from the rear. Betwixt these heavy forces, amounting to near 100,000 men, to say nothing of the fleet of gunboats, it seemed that Vicksburgh would speedily be captured.

abstract: At Tullahoma
snippet: At Tullahoma
lead_paragraph: Gen. BRAGG'S army, when it occupied Murfreeshore, was exactly in the geographical centre of the State of Ten nessee. It was a capital position for offence or defence. From there he guarded East Tennessee, the most important strategic region in the Southern Confederacy; he menaced ROSECRANS at Nashville; he threatened GRANT'S army in the rear, and could reinforce Vicksburgh, as is proved by the fact that, just before the late battle, he sent ten thousand men there; he guarded the States of Alabama and Georgia on the north; and in case he defeated ROSECRANS, he would gain control of the Tennessee and Cumberland Rivers, and probably of the whole State of Tennessee; and he would also be in an admirable position to march up to the northern line of Kentucky, from which he retreated before Gen. BUELL, three months ago. Murfreesboro itself had been chosen by BRAGG, for its natural and artificial advantages, and had been well fortified during the two months he occupied it. It had railroad connections with the Charleston and Memphis road, and the lines connected therewith, running south and east as far as Richmond. It was in the centre of a region which abounded with provisions and forage -- if any part of the South may be said to do so. In all military aspects, Murfreesboro was a good position. It was a point from which the rebel commander would never have retreated if it had been at all possible for him to hold it.

abstract: Proposed Enlargement
snippet: Proposed Enlargement
lead_paragraph: The steamship Jura passed Cape Race on Saturday, with advices from Europe five days later. She left Liverpool on the 1st inst., and Londonderry on the 2d. The workingmen of Manchester had held a meeting to express their sympathy with the North, at which an address to President LINCOLN, congratulating him on his course, was adopted. It is announced that the English revenue accounts show an increase during the year of £2,392,000. The London Times argues from this increase that Cotton is not King, and that it would be far better for England to keep all her cotton operatives on public pensions until they are absorbed in other trades, than to vary one point in her National policy. Additional French troops are imperatively called for in Mexico, to the extent often thousand men. Cotton had a downward tendency in the Liverpool market, owing to the stock being largely in excess of the estimates. Breadstuffs were steady and unchanged. Provisions were very dull. Consols were quoted at 92 1/2@92 5/8 for money.

abstract: A FIRE IN LIBERTY-STREET. -- Near 1 o'clock on Sunday morning, flames were discovered issuing from the windows of the fourth story of the brick building known as No. 18 Liberty-street. Owing to the prompt action of the firemen, the fire was confined to the premises where it originated. Mr. GEORGE EULL, manufacturer of imitation coral beads, occupied the fourth floor. His loss to stock and fixtures is estimated at over $1,000; he is fully insured. The first fibor, which is connected with No. 20 Liberty-street, is occupied by Messrs. WM. DEMUTH & CO., importers and dealers in tobacco and cigars. Their loss is estimated at about $500 -- damage mostly by water. This firm are insured on their stock as follows: In the Irving Insurance Company, $2,000; Continental, $2,000; Home, $2,000; Central Park, $1,000; Etna of New-York, $1,000; Relief, $1,000; Excelsior, $1,000; and Exchange, $1,000. The fifth floor was occupied by Messrs. BARNES & MARTIN, printers. Their stock was damaged by water to the amount of $200 -- said to be insured. The fourth floor over No. 20, occupied by C.F. DURANT, book-ruler, was slightly damaged by water. The third floor was occupied by A.B. BENNETT, book-binder. His loss on stock will be about $200 -- fully insured. On the same flour were two furniture offices, occupied by S. MCBEAN and C.A. LEVERIDGE. Their stock was considerably damaged by water. Mr. LOUIS BEESE occupied the basement as a restaurant; his stock was much damaged by water. Mr. B. is fully insured in City companies. The building is owned by HALLECK & CO. It is damaged to the amount of about $500, and is fully insured. The origin of the fire is at present unknown. It is the intention of Fire Marshal BAKER a to investigate the matter to-day.

abstract: An arrival to-night from the mouth of the Yazoo brings suthentic accounts from Vicksburgh. Gen. SHERMAN'S repulse was complete. The entire force, under the direction of Gen. MCCLERMAND, reembarked Saturday on transports, closer pressed by the rebel advance, which, coming to range of the gunboats, were driven back with severe loss. At the last accounts the entire fleet of transports with troops, had arrived at Island No. 82, on the way to Napoleon.

abstract: New-York; Transport Tillie, boiler at San y Hook; four killed; Tillie, Transport; Boiler Explosion
snippet: New-York; Transport Tillie, boiler at San y Hook; four killed; Tillie, Transport; Boiler Explosion
lead_paragraph: Avery serious catastrophe occurred at about 3 1/2 o'clock yesterday morning, on board the Government steamer transport Tillie, at or near Sandy Hook, whereby four men were instantly killed. The particulars are as follows: A small steam propeller, named the Tillie has been built very recently in this City. She is owned by Messrs. N.L.&G. GRISWOLD and Messrs. B.P.&G.D. LUNT, shipping merchants of South-street. We have no accurate information about her tonnage, but it does not probably exceed 300 tons. The boiler and other parts of her machinery were constructed at the well-known from works of DELAMATER, foot of Thirteenth-street. Recently, and very soon after her completion, she made a trial trip, and everything in and about her was then pronounced sound, safe, and in fine working condition.

abstract: the Scare in Over
snippet: the Scare in Over
lead_paragraph: -- The scare into which the country was thrown by the exciting news from Springfield, Mo., has happily passed away. We were led to fear the capture of the place by the rebel band of 5,000 under MARMADUKE, who attacked it so fiercely on Thursday and Friday last. Gen. BROWN, the commandant, was badly wounded, and disabled from conducting the defence. The rebels had got possession of and destroyed part of the town, and at a late hour on Friday afternoon, when pressing their assault most vigorously, they cut the telegraph wire to St. Louis, and Gen. CURTIS and the country were left in the dark as to the end of the struggle.

abstract: An officer of the navy informs us that, from certain information in his possession, he is enabled to state, somewhat reliably, that the pirate Alabama
lead_paragraph: An officer of the navy informs us that, from certain information in his possession, he is enabled to state, somewhat reliably, that the pirate Alabama has gone, or will soon go, to the eastern hemisphere. SEMMES' orders, according to the officer referred to, were "to, do as he pleased;" but the bold privateer recently determined, it is said, to leave the Western Hemisphere when all our fastest cruisers would be concentrated there to chase him, and go to the North Atlantic or Indian Ocean. It was a great object of his to draw the Tuscarora and Kearsage from Europe, for the double purpose of diminishing the sentinels watching blockade runners, and other privateers fitting out in British ports. SEMMES is known to have contemplated a cruise on the coasts of Africa and Southern Asia, and a certain person suspected of being in his confidence recently stated that "if the waters bounding America were covered with Yankee men-of-war on the 1st of February, Capt. SEMMES might defy them all." Another fact in the same direction is the circumstance that coals for the Alabama were engaged in advance, in the neighborhood of Madagascar.

abstract: What means this terrible eruption of wrath from the Kentucky Governor against the President's Proclamation? What are we to make of the constant fulminations of the Kentucky senators and Representatives at Washington against the Executive policy? How
lead_paragraph: What means this terrible eruption of wrath from the Kentucky Governor against the President's Proclamation? What are we to make of the constant fulminations of the Kentucky senators and Representatives at Washington against the Executive policy? How happens it that of the three slaveholding Border States, Maryland, Missouri and Kentucky, the last alone should be kindled into rage? Missouri, five years ago, was as extreme in its devotion to Slavery as South Carolina itself, and even more furious. Its slave population, in the decade between 1850 and 1860, increased thirty-one and a half per cent., while that of Kentucky increased less than seven per cent. And yet we find Missouri promptly and cordially endorcing the emancipation propositions of the President, by a large majority of its popular vote. We see, too, the leading men of Maryland, and the ablest portion of its Press, taking the same bold stand; and there is no longer a question that the State will, not long hence, concur formally in the plan of compensated emancipation. If Gov. GAMBLE and Gov. BRADFORD can yield so pleasantly to the new necessities of the day, why should Gov. ROBINSON storm so fearfully? If the present Congressmen from Missouri and Maryland, opposed to emancipation as most of them personally are, can submit with such quiet grace to the new policy, why should the neighbors and followers of HENRY CLAY -- the great Kentuckian, who always declared Slavery to be a great misfortune to Kentucky -- why, we ask, should Mr. WICKLIFFE and his colleagues blaze with such indignation because the Government has at last opened a way by which their State may be cleared of Slavery? What peculiar principle or interest has Kentucky in the matter, that Missouri and Maryland have not?
headline: {'main': 'Kentucky and Emancipation.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Kentucky and Emancipation.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: We have a dispach, dated off the mouth of the Yazoo River, 3d inst., which states that the Expedition was withdrawn from the river, on the day previous, in safety--a single attack from the enemy being repulsed by the gunboats. It is announced that the yazoo is abandoned as a base of operations--the enemy's position being ...
lead_paragraph: We have a dispach, dated off the mouth of the Yazoo River, 3d inst., which states that the Expedition was withdrawn from the river, on the day previous, in safety -- a single attack from the enemy being repulsed by the gunboats. It is announced that the yazoo is abandoned as a base of operations -- the enemy's position being impregnable, on the front facing that river, to a force no stronger than the one which made the attempt to carry it -- the enemy having been reinforced to the number of 60,000 men. Our losses are between 2,500 and 3,000. After leaving the Yazoo a council of war was held, at which it was determined to abandon the attempt against Vicksburgh at present, and to operate against some other place -- a point of attack being decided upon, which the rebels will, no doubt, soon inform us of

lead_paragraph: -- The journals of the country are dwelling with a good deal of indignation on the announcement that very strenuous and formidable efforts are in progress, on the part of merchants and manufacturers in England, to break our blockade of the Southern coast. abstract: The Board of aldermen met at 1 o'clock yesterday afternoon. Resolutions were adopted directing the Corporation Counsel to memorialize the Legislature to legalize all the Commissioners of Deeds appointed by the Common Council; to
lead_paragraph: The Board of aldermen met at 1 o'clock yesterday afternoon. Resolutions were adopted directing the Corporation Counsel to memorialize the Legislature to legalize all the Commissioners of Deeds appointed by the Common Council; to refer the various portions of the Mayor's Message to the appropriate committees; to have the Street Commissioner report to the Board the present state of the Battery enlargement difficulty, with the view of taking steps to complete the improvement; to have the Corporation Manual compiled for 1863; and to have an inspection of the piers and wharves made, and their condition reported upon by the Committee on Wharves, Piers and Slips. A report from the Finance Commitee, in favor of issuing $50,000 worth of Central Park stock, was laid over under the rule. The report, together with the annual report of the City Inspector, which was received and ordered to be printed, will be found entire in the official proceedings. Other annual reports of heads of departments were received, and ordered to be printed. The Comptroller reported $2,047,484 40 to have been the balance in the City Treasury on last Saturday. The Board adjourned till Monday next at 1 o'clock P.M.

abstract: Kentucky and the Emancipation Proclamation
snippet: Kentucky and the Emancipation Proclamation
lead_paragraph: In the Senate yesterday, a bill was introduced to aid Western Virginia in the more speedy and final abolishment of Slavery in that State. It was referred to the Judiciary Committee. The President was requested to inform the Senate what measures have been adopted to enforce the provisions of the Confiscation act, &c. The Committee on the Conduct of the War had a similar inquiry directed to them, especially regarding the District of Columbia. Notice was given of a bill to consolidate regiments in the field, and to facilitate the return of absent soldiers to the army. The bill to provide for the further issue of bonds and United States Notes was passed. The House joint resolution for the prompt payment of soldiers was then postponed -- the bill just passed making ample provision for them. The bill for the reorganization of the Court of Claims was considered until the expiration of the morning hour, when the bill for the discharge of State prisoners was taken up, and Mr. WILKINSON, of Minnesota, made a speech, principally in reply to the speech made by Mr. SAULSBURY, of Delaware, last week. A personal colloquy followed, in which Mr. SAULSBURY was declared out of order. The bill was postponed until to-day. The bill to raise volunteers for the defence of Kentucky was passed, 23 to 13. After some further business of no special importance, the Senate adjourned.

abstract: Hunter, Maj.-Gen., and the Southern Department
snippet: Hunter, Maj.-Gen., and the Southern Department
lead_paragraph: -- Having con cluded his labors as presiding officer of the military Commission occupied with examining the charges preferred against Gen. FITZJOHN PORTEA by Maj.-Gen. POPE--Gen. HUNTER is now in New-York on his way to as sume command of the Department in which his course has already attracted such widespread and diversified comment. That Gen. HUNTER is a brave and able officer, even those who differ from him most widely in questions of political opinion are ready to admit; and we hope that, on the occasion of his second assumption of command in the Southern Department he will be supplied with all the troops necessary to carry out that comprehensive plan of campaign upon the mainland which he is known to have elaborated during his previous regime. It must be evident that Government should either withdraw all troops from the Southern coast, or send enough there to make the enemy feel the terror of our arms. That this is the intention of the authorities at Washington, we have reason to believe, and in their selection of a commanding officer, they certainly have shown that it is not their expectation any longer to have a rosewater administration of the affairs of this Department.

abstract: We publish this  morning the annual report of the City Inspector. It is taken up with the usual subjects, discussed in pretty much the old way.
lead_paragraph: We publish this morning the annual report of the City Inspector. It is taken up with the usual subjects, discussed in pretty much the old way. The only conclusion that one can come to, in reading the reports of this Department from year to year, is that things are all wrong. The City is in bad condition: its streets, with the exception of Broadway, are filthy; it has a bad system of sewerage and drainage; thousands of its people live in cellars whose atmosphere is death; slaughter-houses, livery stables and fat-boiling establishments are scattered all over it; barrels of abomination and heaps of ashes line its sidewalks and block up its gutters; some of its piers are used as permanent depots for the accumulation of street manure, and the air is "poisoned with the stench emitted by these reeking and pestiferous mounds of uncleanliness." And yet, notwithstanding the fact that these nuisances, and a hundred others, are patent to every eye, and recognized by every sense, the officers whose duty it is to attend to the sanitary condition of the City can take no cognizance of them, nor adopt any measures to remove them. According to the City Inspector, they have no power to do so. The streets and all their dirt are in the hands of Contractor HACKLEY, who neglects his work, assigns his duties to sub-contractors, and only secures for himself enormous profits; and Mr. DELAVAN can only hope that the newly chosen Counsel to the Corporation may find something in the contract making it possible to carry into effect its proposed objects, and thereby secure a cleanly condition of the City. "But," says he, "should such effort be, as is apprehended, a fruitless one, there will be no other remedy at hand than to promptly put an end to the contract, the provisions of which have been so often misconstrued, perverted or violated, to the detriment of the City." About the other innumerable public offences in the City, the City Inspector's Department can say nothing; or, rather, it can do nothing but annually say a little about them. It is evident that the functionary should either have more authority -- with greater responsibility -- in certain matters, or his costly department should be altogether abolished, and the sanitary condition of the City put in charge of men who have both capacity, knowledge and power. We hope the new Common Council will take speedy action upon this question, whose bearings upon the greatness and well-doing of New-York are more important than any other.

abstract: The Monument Bank; in Charlestown, has come to the rescue of the suffering laborers of the Boston Navy-yard, and have cashed due bills for 3  per cent. The pey-roll for the month of December was
lead_paragraph: The Monument Bank; in Charlestown, has come to the rescue of the suffering laborers of the Boston Navy-yard, and have cashed due bills for 3 per cent. The pey-roll for the month of December was completed to-day and given over to the paymaster. It is the largest one ever made out in the yard, the number of men employed during that month being 3[???]26, and the amount of money that will be required is $176,306 90. The footing of the November payroll was $1[???],000, which, added to that of December, makes about $322,307 now due the workmen. The Navy Department is preparing to pay off these men, [???] [???] [???] [???] [???].

abstract: McCunn, Judge J. H., on illegal arrests
snippet: McCunn, Judge J. H., on illegal arrests
lead_paragraph: -- The Grand Jury which sat in this City in December, had the subject of "arbitrary arrests" by the Administration before it, but failed to find any indictment. The Grand Jury impanneled is the Oyer and Terminer, which sat in the first week of this year, took up the subject anew, but immediately dismissed the bill in the case under consideration. For a third time these arrests were brought before a Grand Jury yesterday in the charge of Judge MCCUNN. Judge MCCUNN took very independent and logical ground on the subject. He is opposed to bringing it up in this manner and in "these times of trouble and of heated political passions." He reminded the Grand Jurors that they could only indict public officers for offences which are alleged to have been committed within the limits of the jurisdiction of that court; and if the offense was not committed here, no indictment could be found at all. He, moreover, advocated giving such cases the widest latitude of a preliminary examination before a proper magistrate, so that the accused might have the benefit of confronting the witnesses against him, and the privilege of cross-examining them, before being compelled to meet them at the bar of a criminal court.

abstract: Hon. S. P. Chase, Secretary of the Treasury, has been in this City since last Friday, and will remain until to-morrow. His presence here has given rise to many speculations as to the object of his visit, and the Anti-Administration journals generally have busied themselves to circulate most incorrect and even calumnious reports relative to his views, operations, and intentions. His private and social meeting with
lead_paragraph: Hon. S.P. CHASE, Secretary of the Treasury, has been in this City since last Friday, and will remain until to-morrow. His presence here has given rise to many speculations as to the object of his visit, and the Anti-Administration journals generally have busied themselves to circulate most incorrect and even calumnious reports relative to his views, operations, and intentions. His private and social meeting with the financial men of New-York, which took place at the residence of Mr. JOHN J. CISCO, United States Treasurer of this district, on Saturday evening, has been referred to by the aforesaid journals in statements full of misrepresentations and inaccuracies. The gathering alluded to was, it is true, partly of a business character. But it was not, nor was it intended to be formal. Neither was it expected that immediate practical results would flow from it. It was designed to bring together the Secretary and the moneyed men of our city in order to secure a full and free interchange of opinions -- which could not be obtained so advantageously in a formal public meeting. It was much the same species of gathering which took place a year and a-half since between the same gentlemen, at the same place, and which it will be recollected resulted in the prompt taking of the hundred and fifty million loan, and the issue of the 7-30s. On that occasion, as on this, the preliminary meeting was of a partially social character, resulting in the call of a subsequent formal meeting, at which the practical results desired were attained. It is not at all improbable that the meeting of Saturday will partake of much the same nature. Mr. CHASE took occasion to converse with all present, including Mayor OPDYKE, Mr. A.A. Low, and the managing officers of our leading Banks. It was evident from his remarks, that the Secretary fully appreciated the support which the moneyed men of New-York have given to the Government in its hour of need; that he comprehended the critical condition of the nation's finances; that he was keenly alive to the necessity for promptly discharging the Government indebtedness to the army, and the many other just claims awaiting settlement. He took occasion to reiterate his confidence in the banking scheme already proposed by him.

abstract: Mr. Ed. MOLLENHAUER gave a very agreeable concert, at Irving Hall, on Tuesday evening, at which several morceaux, from his opera, the "Corsican Bride," were performed. They were rendered, in German, by Mrs. ROTTER, HERR LOTTI, HERR WEINLICH, and other members of the German Opera Company. The opera is written in the modern German
lead_paragraph: Mr. ED. MOLLENHAUER gave a very agreeable concert, at Irving Hall, on Tuesday evening, at which several morceaux, from his opera, the "Corsican Bride," were performed. They were rendered, in German, by Mrs. ROTTER, HERR LOTTI, HERR WEINLICH, and other members of the German Opera Company. The opera is written in the modern German style, being heavily instrumented, and requiring action to make it intelligible. We cannot judge of such a work from a concert-room rehearsal of it, but there is no doubt that such an important addition to our limited repertoire of local music deserves the heartiest recognition at the hands of managers.

abstract: Yesterday was another exciting day in naval circles here. A dispatch from the Richmond papers -announcing the arrival at Beaufort, in a disabled condition, of the iron-clad battery Passaic-which appeared in a morning journal, was circulated among naval people, and arriving so quickly after the Monitor disaster, caused the most dismal feellings.
lead_paragraph: Yesterday was another exciting day in naval circles here. A dispatch from the Richmond papers -- announcing the arrival at Beaufort, in a disabled condition, of the iron-clad battery Passaic -- which appeared in a morning journal, was circulated among naval people, and arriving so quickly after the Monitor disaster, caused the most dismal feellings. The fact of a New-Bedford paper having previously published a correspondent's letter giving a thrilling account of the dangerous condition of the iron-clad in the gale off Hatteras, lent an air of probability to the story, which almost neutralised the absurdity of the canard about the turret being lost. The public having a great interest in the matter, inquiries were made, by telegraph, of a well-informed person in Washington, known to be in the confidence of the Navy Department. His reply is subjoined, as are two subsequent telegrams.

abstract: P sition of the not Cheering
snippet: P sition of the not Cheering
lead_paragraph: The Army of the Potomac has received a larger share of the attention of Government, and a much larger share of the attention of the public Press, than any other army that the nation has put in the field. There have been good reasons for this, unquestionably. In the first place, the Army of the Potomac has, at different times since its organization, outnumbered our other armies, by great odds. In the second place, it has been charged with graver duties than any other -- at least, with duties absorbing more of the interest and exciting more of the sensibilities of the people, to wit: 1. The defence of the National Capital, when menaced at different times by the rebels. 2. The capture of Richmond, and the dispersion of the rebellious Government holding its defiant councils there. It might be added, perhaps, that the Army of the Potomac is the first created great army of the country -- that its organization was attended with extraordinary commotions and some serious dangers, such as the deep excitement that continued so long after the first battle of Bull Run, and the intense passion, bordering on popular phrensy, at the North, following the murder of Massachusetts troops by the mob in Baltimore. The Army has, from these causes, drawn around itself much of the interest that, by a law of nature, always attends the "first-born;" and the dangers that attended its birth, and cling to its career, have given it a hold on the popular sympathy, and kept alive an interest in its fate that no other army of the Republic can boast of.

abstract: The envoy of Gen. THUMB has returned with the joyful information that Miss WARREN's kind parents have consented to grant their daughter's wish. She will withdraw from public life immediately after the close of her present engagement, and with her dearest THUMB travel through Europe, and the rest of this vale of tears. Their wedding is to be a rich and recherche affair. In fact, it promises to be the great fashionable event of the season. They are to be married on Tuesday, Feb. 10. The nuptial ceremonies will take place at one of the most fashionable churches in the City. Cards of invitation will be issued to the relatives and friends, and to some of the first families of the City. As the number of tickets will correspond with the number of seats in the church, no person will be admitted except those invited. The bridal party will proceed to one of our leading hotels immediately after the marriage ceremonies, where they will hold a brief reception for those only who have cards of invitation to the wedding. The following morning they will go to Philadelphia, and remain there several days, after which they may extend their journey to Baltimore and Washington. They will then visit Boston, and subsequently spend several weeks at the bride's home, at Middleborough, Mass., and at the bridegroom's, at Bridgeport, Conn.

abstract: the Senatorial Contest in
snippet: the Senatorial Contest in
lead_paragraph: The very excited contest for the Pennsylvania Senatorship, closed yesterday at Harrisburgh, as the contest at Springfield (Ill.) had closed the day previous, by the election of a Democratic Senator vice the sitting Republican member. Mr. BUCKALEW, the new Pennsylvania Senator, succeeds to the seat of Hon. DAVID WILMOT, and his opponent in the contest was Hon. SIMON CAMERON. The Democracy claimed a majority of one in the Legislature on joint ballot, but their candidate was finally elected by a majority of twenty Mr. LAPORTE, a Republican member, transferring his vote to an irregular nominee.

abstract: The steamship Jura arrived at Portland yesterday, and some additional news is telegraphed, including a summary of the intelligence put on board the steamship City of Baltimore, which left Liverpool on the 31st ult., and which has not yet arrived. Late advices from Japan show that that country is in a state of revolution, and that important reforms are being inaugurated which...
lead_paragraph: The steamship Jura arrived at Portland yesterday, and some additional news is telegraphed, including a summary of the intelligence put on board the steamship City of Baltimore, which left Liverpool on the 31st ult., and which has not yet arrived. Late advices from Japan show that that country is in a state of revolution, and that important reforms are being inaugurated which will be of much advantage to foreigners. The steamer Sumter, formerly the rebel pirate, had been sold at auction at Gibraltar for $19,500, and is to be engaged in the Liverpool and Mediterranean trade. The English papers indulged in extended comments on the Fredericksburgh disaster. The French Financial Minister had made a statement showing that the Government deficit for the year was 35,000,000 francs -- the Mexican expenses being stated at 83,000,000 francs. O'DONNELL had made a speech on Mexican affairs in the Spanish Senate, which had created considerable excitement. He characterized the claims of France as excessive, and said the real cause of rupture between France and Spain was ALMONTE, who deceived France. A plot for a rising in Poland in January had been discovered.

abstract: Richmond Dispatch on the "Tyranny" in West Virginia
snippet: Richmond Dispatch on the "Tyranny" in West Virginia
lead_paragraph: A letter to a gentleman of this city, from Mr. J. D. PARSONS, of Tucker County, who has been an especial object of the persecutions of the Yankee Gen. MILROY, states that the Yankee General is assessing heavily the citizens of that section who are friendly to the South, after he has stripped them of all means of paying tha assessment. " W.E. PARSONS is assessed at $707 ; N. & G.M. PARSONS, $450; ABRAHAM PARSONS, $340; JAMES R. PARSONS, $170; and others in accordance with their principles. They robbed W.S. PARSONS of all his property previous to the assessment, and had him in prison at the time." Since the time when Pharoah required the Israelites to make bricks without straw, we have never heard the parallel of the tyranny which deprives men of their property and then levies heavy assessment upon them.

abstract: Coroner NAUMANN yesterday concluded the inquest in the case of the four men who were scalded to death on Sunday morning last, by the explosion of a boiler on board the steam transport Tillie, at or near Sandy Hook. It mill be remembered that we published a pretty full account of the accident in the...
lead_paragraph: Coroner NAUMANN yesterday concluded the inquest in the case of the four men who were scalded to death on Sunday morning last, by the explosion of a boiler on board the steam transport Tillie, at or near Sandy Hook. It mill be remembered that we published a pretty full account of the accident in the TIMES of Monday last, and the testimony given upon the inquest throws no light whatever upon the causes which led to the sad catastrophe.

abstract: Rowe vs. Thompson; Statute of Limitations
snippet: Rowe vs. Thompson; Statute of Limitations
lead_paragraph: Rowe vs. Thompson. The plaintiff held three notes of the defendant, dated respectively March 8, April 1 and May 5, 1852, and each payable six months after date, upon which this action was brought. The defence was that the action was barred by the statute of limitations. Upon the trial it appeared that defendant had requested one Hodges to aid him in obtaining an agreement from his creditors that they would not molest him for two years, so that he could go into business; and that Hodges called upon the plaintiff in respect to it, and he consented. Before the two years expired, the plaintiff's right of action was cut off by the statute of limitations unless the contract made with the defendant should defeat the operation of that statute.

abstract: on the Finances of the Country; Treasury; Finances of; Mr. Spalding's Speech
snippet: on the Finances of the Country; Treasury; Finances of; Mr. Spalding's Speech
lead_paragraph: We publish this morning Mr. SPAULDING's speech on the public finances -- the necessities of the Treasury, and the best mode of meeting them. No more important topic can engage public attention. The Government and the country are in a condition of extreme financial peril. An immense amount of money is wanted at once; and Congress must decide promptly how it shall be raised. It is of the utmost importance, also, that the decision should be wise as well as prompt.

abstract: MEETING OF THE MARINE SOCIETY OF NEW-YORK. -- The annual meeting of the New-York Marine Society was held on Monday evening, at the United States Hotel, Fulton-street, Capt. MARSHALL, the President of the Society, in the chair. After the reading of the minutes for the year 1862, the Secretary, Capt. JOSEPH TINERAM, read his report for the past year, in which it was shown that the funds of the Society amounted to $61,744 64, which is invested in bon[???]s and mortgages on real estate in this City and Brooklyn, bearing interest at 7 per cent. per annum, payable semi-annually. The widows now receiving pensions from the funds of the Society number 56, viz.: 23 on the highest grade, 13 on the second grade, and 19 on the lowest grade, receiving respectively $90, $80 and $70 per annum -- making a grand total of $4,240, payable semi-annually in advance. By the Treasurer's report it was shown that the receipts during the year amounted to $6,365 25, and the disbursements for pensions and donations $5,802 44. A ballot for the election of officers for the current year was then taken, which resulted as follows: President, C.H. Marshall; First Vice-President, J.M. F[???]; Second Vice-President, Thomas Dunham; Secretary, Joseph Tinkham; Treasurer, James Copland; Attorney and Counselor, Daniel Lord. After a few remarks from Capt. MARSHALL, congratulating the [???] b[???] of the Society upon its prosperity, and thanking them for the honor done him by his reelection, the various officers for the ensuing year were sworn into power, some business of a routine nature was transacted, and the meeting adjourned till the second Monday in April.

abstract: LAWRENCE KELLY, au intelligent looking man, about 35 years of age, was placed on trial in this Court yesterday under an indictment for manslaughter, in causing the death of JOHN SLATTERY on the 13th of July last. It appeared from the testimony that the prisoner and deceaded were near neighbors, to Fiftyninth yet, near First-avenue, and on the night of...
lead_paragraph: LAWRENCE KELLY, an intelligent looking man, about 35 years of age, was placed on trial in this Court yesterday under an indictment for manslaughter, in causing the death of JOHN SLATTERY on the 13th of July last. It appeared from the testimony that the prisoner and deceaded were near neighbors, to Fiftyninth yet, near First-avenue, and on the night of the homicide, between 11 and 12 o'clock, deceased entered the house of the prisoner in a state of intoxication, when he abused both the prisoner and his wife. He was finally ejected from the house and from thence out of the yard. As the prisoner was pushing him out of the yard gate, he fell, and soon after died, whether from the effect of the fall or from some other cause is not known. The evidence showed that deceased was a very quarrelsome man to his family and neighbors, when intoxicated, and that he had been on a drunken spree for two or three days previous to the homicide. The prisoner proved an excellent character for industry and sobriety by several respectable witnesses. The examination of witnesses in the case occupied the entire day, and the Court adjourned to 10 o'clock this morning, when the case will be summed up by CHARLES S. SPENCER, on behalf of the prisoner, and by O.L. STUART, Esq., for the people.

abstract: Speech on How to Raise Money for the Government--House
snippet: Speech on How to Raise Money for the Government--House
lead_paragraph: Mr. CHAIRMAN: The immediate requirements of the Treasury are not less than $100,000,000. Before you can pass this bill through both Houses, have it approved by the President, and get bonds and notes engraved, printed and issued, at least $50,000,000 more will be required. The pressing demands upon the Treasury, between this and the 1st of next month, for the pay of soldiers and other creditors may be put down at $150,000,000. The gold and silver in the banks in New-York, Boston, and Philadelphia, on the 1st of this month, probably did not exceed $50,000,000; to which you may add the gold and silver in all other banks in all the loyal States, as will appear in official reports to the 1st of January, 1863, and the whole sum will not exceed $86,000,000. All this coin is necessary for the banks to take care of their own liabilities; but even if the Secretary of the Treasury could, on the credit of the Government, by a sale of bonds at any sacrifice, or by the aid of the military power, visit every bank in the country, and by force compel all this coin to be paid into the Treasury, it would not pay fifty cents on the dollar of the demands due from the Government, and which ought to be paid in the next twenty days. It is, therefore, perfectly plain, that even the small sum of $150,000,000 now due, cannot be paid in gold. It would be a great gratification to me, and, I doubt not, to every other loyal citizen, if it were otherwise. It is no fault of the Secretary or of Congress, that gold cannot now be paid to the soldiers and other creditors. It is simply an impossibility, by any plan, to get enough for that purpose. There never was a more pertinent application of the old maxim than when applied to our present condition," when we cannot do as we would, we must do as we can."

abstract: Richmond Enquirer on Confederate Finances and a Truce
snippet: Richmond Enquirer on Confederate Finances and a Truce
lead_paragraph: The Confederate States have revived the French assignat system as the financial scheme for conducting war, and its results will prove as disastrous in this country as in France. Taxation is the only means of supporting war. The sooner Congress realizes this fact the sooner shall we see the beginning of the end of the evils that now embarrass the Government as well as people.

abstract: Secretary CHASE visited Wall-street yesterday, having business to transact at the office of United States Treasurer CISCO, and at the Custom-house. His presence soon became known on the street, and some of our prominent men of finance took occasion to see him. He leaves to-day for Washington, having, it is hoped, spent four days to some purpose in the Commercial Metropolis of the country. Doubtless the Anti-Administration journals will raise a howl of triumph, on the assumption that Mr. CHASE's visit has been without practical result. Such an assumption, however, would be grossly incorrect. The absurd stories as to the purpose of Mr. CHASE's visit, and the misstatements of the results attending his interview with the bankers at the residence of Mr. CISCO, have been exposed to the public. To men acquainted with monetary affairs, no such explanations were needed, as, whatever may on the opinion as to the Secretary's views or scheme of finance, he is generally acco[???] the credit of doing the utmost of his ability to advance the financial interests of the country. His visit to the City has been undertaken with this view, and has been by no means fruitless. He has accomplished in a quiet way all that could be expected from a public meeting with the bankers. And they are much better acquainted with each other's views than they could have been in any other way. MAHO[???]ET came to the mountain. Let us hope that the mountain will not bring forth a mouse.

abstract: Our telegraphic correspondent at Nashville sends us information of an extremely important character. The rebel Generals CHEATHAM and McCOUN are said to be at Shelbyville with their divisions, and expecting to be reinforced by LONGSTREET and his corps from the Richmond army,...
lead_paragraph: Our telegraphic correspondent at Nashville sends us information of an extremely important character. The rebel Generals CHEATHAM and McCOUN are said to be at Shelbyville with their divisions, and expecting to be reinforced by LONGSTREET and his corps from the Richmond army, numbering thirty thousand men. It will be remembered that we have had several reports from Federicksburgh that the rebel army, or a portion of it, was apparently leaving the line of the Rappahannock and going in the direction of Richmond, and it is possible that this transfer of LONGSTREET's Corps to strengthen BRAGG's Army has been made, as the line of railroad communication through North and South Carolina and Alabama is still open. It would appear, in this case, that another desperate effort to defeat the National army under Gen. ROSECRANS is to be made, even at the risk of weakening the rebel army under LEE, which disputes Gen. BURNSIDE's way to Richmond. Our correspondent states, also, that four thousand rebels, with two full batteries of artillery, under FORREST, WHEELER and STARNES, have marched toward Charlotte, forty miles west of Nashville, with the view of destroying the transports in the Cumberland River with supplies for Gen. ROSECRANS' army. Eight regiments of our troops -- four cavalry and four infantry -- have, however, been sent in pursuit. One of our transports, loaded with Commissary and Quartermasters' stores, has already been captured and destroyed. It is reported, also, that the guerilla MORGAN is again in Kentucky, medicating damage to the Louisville and Nashville Railroad. With the Cumberland properly patroled by gunboats, however, Gen. ROSECRANS cannot suffer for supplies.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, a petition from thechiefs of the Wyandotte Indians, asking for reimbursement for losses influence upon them by the rebels, was presented. The petition of WILLIAM CORNELL JEWETT, for mediation by Switzerland, was reported back from the Committee on Foreign Affairs, with a recommendation that it be...
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, yesterday, a petition from thechiefs of the Wyandotte Indians, asking for reimbursement for losses influence upon them by the rebels, was presented. The petition of WILLIAM CORNELL JEWETT, for mediation by Switzerland, was reported back from the Committee on Foreign Affairs, with a recommendation that it be indefinitely postponed, which was agreed to. Mr. WILSON, of Massachusetts, introduced his bill for the consolidation of regiments in the field. The President was called upon for the correspondence between the State Department and the British Government relative to the capture of British vessels sailing from one port to another, having on board articles contraband of war, intended for the use of the rebels. The President was also called upon for the correspondence with the Mexican Minister at Washington, relative to the exportation of contraband articles for the use of the French army in Mexico. The death of Mr. PEARCE, of Maryland, was then announced, and, after the customary proceedings, the Senate adjourned.

lead_paragraph: -- DESERTERS TO BE SECURED. -- By General Order from the War Department, dated Jan. 3, the Military Department of the East was created, consisting of the New-England States and the State of New-York. The Headquarters are in this City. Gen. WOOL, has been assigned to the command of this Department. He has arrived and entered upon his duties, as will be seen from a series of orders published in another column of the TIMES of to-day.

abstract: Young vs. Isaacs; Recovery of Stolen Property from Pawnbroker
snippet: Young vs. Isaacs; Recovery of Stolen Property from Pawnbroker
lead_paragraph: Hiram Young vs. Joseph E. Isaacs. -- This was an action brought by the plaintiff to recover the possession or value of thirty-five gold watches which he claims to have purchased by bill of sale from Alfred St. Laurent, in March, 1860, and which said St. Laurent stated at the time had been pawned or pledged by his clerk or servant, and without his authority, to the defendant, who is a pawnbroker. The plaintiff demanded the possession of the property, and offered to pay and discharge the defendant's claim or lien, for advances made on the watches; but the defendant said he had not the watches in his possession, and knew nothing about any such watches. The plaintiff then caused the defendant's iron safe to be opened by the sheriff and there found and took possession of the watches.

abstract: United States vs. Various Vessels; Prize Cases
snippet: United States vs. Various Vessels; Prize Cases
lead_paragraph: The United States vs. The Schooner Napoleon. -- This vessel was captured by the naval forces acting in cooperation with the land forces at the capture of Newbern. The schooner was totally adandoned when taken possession of by the United States vessels. The evidence is from reports prevalent at the time and place, that rebel troops had been stationed on her until driven out by the United States forces, leaving her without any crew, papers or equipment, but with several pieces of artillery on board. The vessel was loaded with captured stores and sent to this port and libeled. D.C. Murray, a citizen and resident of this State intervened and answered, setting up that he was always opposed to the rebellion, and gave no consent to the employment of the vessel by the rebels.

abstract: a Necessity
snippet: a Necessity
lead_paragraph: The commerce of the United States is a creation rather than a growth. It could not have had existence but for the provision made for it by the construction of artificial highways. The extent of such highways consequently exactly measure its volume, although the ratio of its increase is much greater than that of our public works. The railroads of New-York transport say 2,000 tons of merchandise to each mile of road; those of Massachusetts a still larger quantity. The tonnage of all the railroads in the country, or rather of those of the loyal States, is fully 1,250 tons to the mile. The aggregate mileage being 23,000 miles, the total tonnage will be 27,600, exempting, of course, such articles as coal. The value of merchandise at $100 the ton is fully $2,760,000.

abstract: The French Protestant Episcopal Church, "Du Saint Esprit," was duly dedicated yesterday morning, by Bishop POTTER, of this Diocese, assisted by various clergymen of the Episcopal communion. The congregation have worshiped for many years in the elegant edifice on the corner of Church and Franklin streets, but, as the location was too far down town, it...
lead_paragraph: The French Protestant Episcopal Church, "Du Saint Esprit," was duly dedicated yesterday morning, by Bishop POTTER, of this Diocese, assisted by various clergymen of the Episcopal communion. The congregation have worshiped for many years in the elegant edifice on the corner of Church and Franklin streets, but, as the location was too far down town, it was determined to erect a new building in a more convenient place. A suitable lot was obtained on the south side of Twenty-second-street, between Fifth and Sixth avenues, and the corner stone laid some six months ago. This church is now entirely completed and ready for occupation. The carpets are down, the seats cushioned, and the building presents none of that lack of finish so often observable in new ecclesiastical edifices. The style of the church is Gothic; the front is of yellow stone, provided with three entrances, and surmounted by a spire. The interior is very neat and elegant. The walls are of a light yellow color, and painted so as to imitate stone. A gallery of dark oak extends around three sides of the church, and is supported by the pillars rising from the nave. The windows are of painted glass in light, cheerful colors, and the chancel is roofed with glass, imitating in brilliant golden hues the rays of the sun extending down to a field of blue dotted with stars. On the rear wall of the apsis, in which is the chancel, are aflixed three tablets, on which are inscribed the Lord's Prayer, the Decalogue and the Creed. The pulpit is at the right hand, in the old-fashioned half-barrel style, and is surmounted by a heavy and handsomely carved sounding board. The pews in the church are of oak, without doors, and comfortable for setters. The organ loft is slightly elevated above the gallery, is furnished with an elegant oak screen, and contains an organ built by ERBEN -- the case of which is in Gothic style, and in design a copy of that in Ascension Church in Fifth-avenue. The church will seat about a thousand persons.

abstract: WINTER GARDEN. There are theatres in London where the virtues thrive, and nothing more carnal than tripe and onions to ever permitted to be mentioned on the stage. Mr. ROBSON a famous eccentric comedian occupies one of these chaste temples. Month after month and year after year he plays a little round of characters depicting, with a good deal...
lead_paragraph: WINTER GARDEN. -- There are theatres in London where the virtues thrive, and nothing more carnal than tripe and onions to ever permitted to be mentioned on the stage. Mr. ROBSON -- a famous eccentric comedian -- occupies one of these chaste temples. Month after month and year after year he plays a little round of characters depicting, with a good deal of minuteness and, we may add, an equal degree of prolixity, the trials, tribulations and triumphs of the lower grades of society. An experienced habitue of the theatre can say at such and such a time Mr. ROBSON will wipe his poor bald old head with a red cotton pocket "handkercher," and at such a time he will sit down radiantly to an occult feast of stewed cowheel contained in a basin, and in the manner of his eating convey to the attentive mind the healthful lesson that contentment and a religious frame of thought can be obtained by pursuing that diet as a steady service of life. These things are as sure to happen as Mr. ROBSON is sure to light a long pipe at a later period of the evening, and after pulling frantically at it, and finally putting the bowl in his mouth, to collapse and choke from the intensity of his emotions, occasioned by the tobacco or his feelings.

abstract: JOSEPH TAYLOR, a native of Switzerland, 27 years of age, was put on trial in this Court, yesterday, upon an indictment for arson in the third degree, in setting fire to the premises, No. 606 Grandstreet, occupied by himself as a dining saloon, on the 1st of August last.
lead_paragraph: JOSEPH TAYLOR, a native of Switzerland, 27 years of age, was put on trial in this Court, yesterday, upon an indictment for arson in the third degree, in setting fire to the premises, No. 606 Grandstreet, occupied by himself as a dining saloon, on the 1st of August last. The prisoner is defended by H.L. CLINTON, Esq., and the prosecution is conducted by Assistant District-Attorney, S.V. GARVIN. The evidence of Fire Marshal BAKER tended to show that the premises were set on fire by the prisoner for the purpose of getting the insurance. The fire was extinguished before it bad fairly got under headway, and the Fire Marshal, on examining the premises, found piles of kindling wood and paper, saturated with camphene, in two different places in the building. He also ascertained that a large quantity of the goods and wearing apparel of the prisoner, who, with his family, occupied a portion of the upper part of the house, had been removed the day before the fire to a house in Orchard-street, over a mile distant. A large number of witnesses were examined on behalf of the prosecution, and at the close of the testimony for the people, the Court adjourned to 10 o'clock this morning, when Mr. CLINTON will open the case for the defence.

abstract: Emperor Napoleon, the New-Year's Day Speech
snippet: Emperor Napoleon, the New-Year's Day Speech
lead_paragraph: -- The fears of those who imagined that the Emperor of the French, at his diplomatic reception on New Year's Day, would announce or hint his purpose of making war on this Government in favor of the rebels, as on a similar occasion, four years ago, he foreshadowed his war with Austria, may now be allayed. The Emperor received the diplomatic body on New Year's day as usual; he listened to a complimentary speech of half a dozen lines from their mouth-piece, the Papal Nuncio; and he replied in a speech of equal brevity, in which his only general remark was an expression of his "desire to live with all the Powers in relations of friendship, so necessary to the security of the present and of the future." We are obliged to his Majesty for the opiate he thus enables us to administer to those in this country who are gifted with weak nerves.

abstract: In the Senate yesterday, the credentials of Hon. THOMAS H. HICKS, as United States Senator from Maryland, in place of Hon. JAMES A. PEARCE, was presented, and he appeared and took the oath of office. The House bill, granting aid to Missouri in emancipating her slaves, was reported back from the Judiciary Committee, with an amendment. The bill to consolidate regiments in the field was reported back from the Military Committee; also a bill relative to employes in the Quartermaster-General's office; also a bill for the better organization of the Subsistence Department. The Committee on the Conduct of the War was instructed to make inquiry relative to the transportation of disloyal persons, male and female, in vessels under the control of the War Department. The joint resolution to annul the treaties and forfeit the lands and annuities of the Sioux Indians, was made a special order for Wednesday, the 21st inst. The bill for the reorganization of the Court of Claims was then debated until the Senate went into Executive session.

abstract: Howls of Secessionism Against; War-Whoop Against New-England
snippet: Howls of Secessionism Against; War-Whoop Against New-England
lead_paragraph: Hon. S.S. COX, Congressman from Ohio, on Tuesday evening, before the Democratic Association, sounded, to the best of his small capacity, a regular war-whoop aganist New-England. In itself the demonstration was too senseless to deserve notice -- a piece of sound and fury, signifying nothing. But it is a notable fact that the late utterances of many of the Democratic leaders, both on the platform and through the Press, have been pitched on precisely the same key, and that much of even Gov. SEYMOUR's message was in a similar strain, though of course subdued in tone. The rebel spokesmen too, of late, have opened anew against New-England. We do not say there is any concerted plan between the rebel and the Democratic leaders, but it is plain that there are chords in the breasts of both which vibrate very much alike. For a certain range, at least, they are incomplete sympathy.

abstract: We are past new-Year's, with weather like April. There has not been a frost to stiffen the mud, and overcoats are a burden. lead_paragraph: LONDON, Saturday, Jan. 3, 1863.

abstract: Workingmen's Address to President Lincoln
snippet: Workingmen's Address to President Lincoln
lead_paragraph: A large and enthusiastic meeting was held in the Free Trade Hall, Manchester, on Wednesday evening, Dec. 31, which had been called by a Committee of workingmen, to enable the working classes of Manchester and Salford to express their sympathy with the cause of union in America, and to pass resolutions in support of the emancipation policy of President LINCOLN. The proceedings commenced shortly after 7 o'clock, and lasted till near 11, the enthusiasm being very marked throughout, and the sentiments of the different speakers were loudly cheered.

abstract: Russell, W. H., on the Battle of Fredericksburgh
snippet: Russell, W. H., on the Battle of Fredericksburgh
lead_paragraph: Mr. RUSSELL, in the Army and Navy Gazette for Jan. 3, expresses a good deal of surprise at the "inactivity of the Confederates" on the night after BURNSIDE's attack on Fredericksburgh had been repulsed. He refers to instances in the history of European wars, where similar neglects have been committed. "A little energy, some daring, and ordinary outpost and patrolling," he says, "must have led to the consummation of the Federal deteat by the capture of their artillery and the mass of their army." He adds:

lead_paragraph: The steamship China arrived at this port yesterday, from Liverpool on the 3d and Queenstown on the 4th inst., with advices from Europe two days later. There is nothing new relative to the American question, if we except a report that the rebel Government had appointed an agent in England to obtain a loan. The London Times favors the idea of receiving emancipated slaves in the West Indies. The French Emperor, at his reception on the 1st inst., made no allusion to American affairs. There was very little change to note in the Liverpool cotton market. Breadstuffs and Provisions remained about the same as before reported. The latest quotation for Consols was 92 5/8@92 3/4.

abstract: Gen. Wool's Order
snippet: Gen. Wool's Order
lead_paragraph: In Gen. WOOL's "Order No. 3," relating to deserters, which we published yesterday, an earnest appeal is made to patriotic citizens "that they will use their utmost endeavors to apprehend and hand over to the nearest authorities all soldiers who are deserters from their regiments or corps." We understand that this order produced quite a flutter among some of our military visitors yesterday. Some of them fell suddenly sick; others doffed their soldier clothes and reappeared in citizens' costume; some tried to change their countenances by shaving off whiskers, moustache, imperial or goatee; some discovered all at once that their furloughs had expired, and hied away to join their regiments; others reported at headquarters, in hope of clemency; and some, doubtless, burrowed into deeper cellars or crawled into obscurer garrets, to conceal themselves.
headline: {'main': 'UNION AND REBEL DESERTERS.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'UNION AND REBEL DESERTERS.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Paper Duty and the Dealers' Monopoly
snippet: Paper Duty and the Dealers' Monopoly
lead_paragraph: The paper-makers are encouraged by the vote in Congress laying on the table Mr. COLFAX's motion to discharge the Committee on Ways and Means from further consideration of the petitions to reduce the duty on imported paper. They foresee in this a prolongation of the monopoly they have established, and are drawing still tighter the bonds of the combination by which they hold it. The price of paper is likely to go up again. For the last few weeks it has been stationary, with a downward tendency.

abstract: funeral sermon on Dr. Lyman Beecher; Beecher, Lyman, D. D.; Funeral Ceremonies
snippet: funeral sermon on Dr. Lyman Beecher; Beecher, Lyman, D. D.; Funeral Ceremonies
lead_paragraph: That Rev. Dr. LYMAN BEECHER, whose dead was announced in the TIMES of Sunday, must have held a prominent place in the affections of the people among whom he had ministered during his many years' service as a Gospel preacher -- and that he also was second to none in the esteem of the citizens of Brooklyn, was fully evinced yesterday, by the spontaneous outpouring of the people, who filled Plymouth Church on the occasion of his obsequies. Long before the time appointed for the commencement of the funeral ceremonies, large crowds had gathered in Orange street, eager to gain admission into the church, and when the doors were opened, the throng of humanity that commenced to pour in appeared to be endless. It was not long thereafter when the edifice was packed to density -- every nook and corner having an occupant -- and the entire assemblage presenting a coup d'oeil seldom equaled, and never excelled. Meanwhile, numbers continued to swell the crowd outside, which had been unable to obtain admittance. The clergy had, by special invitation, assembled in the lecture-room in the rear of the church, whence they proceeded to join in the procession, which started from the residence of the deceased and arrived at the church at 2 o'clock P.M. Among the clergymen present, we noticed the Rev. Drs. Hitchcock, A.D. Smith, Hatfield, Floy, Canfield, Cuyler, Cox, T.A. Hills, and Rev. Messrs. Henry Belden, S. Bliss, Foss, Baylis, Gloucester, Baldwin, Holme, and numerous others of this City and Brooklyn, besides clerical representatives of nearly all evangelical denominations from Connecticut, Massachusetts and New-York State. The principal mourners were Mrs. Lyman Beecher, widow of the deceased, and his sons Rev. H.W. Beecher, Rev. Chas. Beecher, Rev. Wm.H. Beecher, Rev. Thomas K. Beecher, and his daughters Miss Catharine E. Beecher, Mrs. H.B. Stowe, Mrs. Hooker and Mrs. Perkins, who were followed by a long train of distant relatives and intimate personal friends of the deceased. On the arrival of the cortege the remains were placed immediately in front of the pulpit, the near relatives taking front seats, and the ministers occupying the news which had been reserved for them on each side of the north aisle. The coffin was of rosewood, having six silver handles for the pall-bearers, and on the lid a cross, two wreaths of evergreen, and a silver plate bearing the following inscription:

abstract: Clark vs. Kelly; Sheriff's Return
snippet: Clark vs. Kelly; Sheriff's Return
lead_paragraph: Edward P. Clark vs. John Kelly, [???]. -- This was an action brought by plaintiff against defendant to recover $316,89 and interest, for an alleged false return made by defendant on an execution issued by plaintiff, in an action against one Vroman, Dec. 18, 1861. The Sheriff made his return "no personal or real property on which to satisfy said executions." Plaintiff introduced an order of attachment, granted by Justice Ingraham, of the Supreme Court, against Vroman, for his default in not appearing on supplementary proceedings, and also the attachment issued to the defendant, as Sheriff, together with his return "that he had arrested the defendant, who had deposited $500 in lieu of trial for his appearance, which return bore date Jan. 6, 1862, (at which time the attachment was discharged,) but the return did not state when the arrest was made, nor whose money was deposited.

abstract: Attacks on Public Credit
snippet: Attacks on Public Credit
lead_paragraph: There is no man, who has a particle of public spirit or of patriotic feeling, who does not, in a crisis of such magnitude as that in which we now find ourselves, experience a good deal of pain in calling down public reprobation even upon those faults and follies of the Government of which it has been undeniably guilty. No Government, and, above all, no popular Government, has ever carried on a contest such as this, without committing every day a thousand blunders; and as popular Government derives all its strength from the popular support, he who excites or endeavors to excite one jot more popular distrust of it, or popular reprobation of its acts, than is plainly necessary to correct its errors, or increase its vigilance, affords just as effectual aid to the enemy as though he got up a panic in the ranks on the day of battle.
headline: {'main': 'Attacks on the Public Credit.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Attacks on the Public Credit.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, the credentials of Mr. BUCKALEW, as Senator from Pennsylvania, were presented. A bill concerning military Courts was introduced by Mr. WILSON, of Massachusetts. A resolution was adopted, asking the Secretary of the Treasury for information regarding compensation of Collectors of Customs. The Secretary of the Navy was asked for information regarding the accident to the steamer Ossipee. The papers relating to the French spoliation claims were referred to the Committee on Foreign Relations. The House joint resolution to provide for the payment of the army and navy, was reported from the Finance Committee, without amendment, and passed, only two members voting against it -- Messrs. POWELL, of Kentucky, and SAULSBURY, of Delaware. It provides for the issue of a hundred millions of Treasury Notes, should that amount be necessary. The bill making appropriations for the support of the Military Academy at West Point was taken up, debated at great length and finally passed, 29 to 10. The Senate then adjourned.

abstract: the Eventful of 1863
snippet: the Eventful of 1863
lead_paragraph: New-Year's Day this year looked very quiet in New-York, and it seemed to us, then, rather dull all over the country. We knew that there had been skirmishing in the latter days of the old year in Middle Tennessee, and we even read that a battle there was imminent, but the public paid no great attention to the announcement. Yet it turns out to have been one of the most eventful days since the war began; and it will be a remarkable day of this year which surpasses in incident its first day.

abstract: Free Labor Experiments
snippet: Free Labor Experiments
lead_paragraph: The letter which we publish this morning concerning the experiments with Free Labor in Louisiana, will repay perusal. It is from one of our Southern correspondents who has had good opportunities of watching the practical results of such experiments as have been made. Gen. BUTLER, finding a great many freed negroes on his hands, and the plantations suffering for lack of their labor, entered into an agreement with the planters, the text of which is embodied in our correspondent's letter. Provision is made for guarding the negroes and preventing crime, and the planters were to pay certain stipulated prices per month for their labor. The general result, according to the testimony of the planters themselves, was highly favorable; and Gen. BUTLER had no hesitation in inferring from it that free labor would be far more profitable in Louisiana than slave labor.
