abstract: Late on Wednesday night a well-known gang of counterfeiters, the most of whom belong in this City, made a determined effort to flood this City and Brooklyn with well-executed counterfeit $5 bills on the Bank of Lyons, Wayne County, this State.
lead_paragraph: Late on Wednesday night a well-known gang of counterfeiters, the most of whom belong in this City, made a determined effort to flood this City and Brooklyn with well-executed counterfeit $5 bills on the Bank of Lyons, Wayne County, this State. As soon as it became known that the rogues were operating, the Police Telegraph was put to work, and all Stations within the Metropolitan District were notified, and the Patrolmen were directed to go from store to store and give notice of the dangerous fraud. But for the facilities thus afforded of notifying the public, the people of the two cities would last night have been swindled out of many thousands of dollars. Notwithstanding all these precautions, there were a large number of arrests made by the Police of the Sixth. Eighth. Twentieth, Twenty-sixth and Twenty-ninth Precincts.

abstract: what will he do with it
snippet: what will he do with it
lead_paragraph: Beyond the fact that the expedition under Gen. SHERMAN against Vicksburgh has been withdrawn by Gen, McCLERNAND, and the whole force reembarked and moved up the Mississippi River, we know nothing definite about it. One report says that the attack on Vicksburgh has not been abandoned, but is about to be made from another direction. We are at a loss to conjecture on what side that stronghold could be approached more feasibly than on the one selected by SHERMAN. Another report says that a council of war was held on board of the fleet after Vicksburgh was given up, and a new place decided on for attack. And following this report is an account of part of the expedition moving up White River. The inference on the face of these statements is that some point in Arkansas is to be attacked. But we apprehend this is not the case; or if there be truth in it, only a partial occupation will be found for MCCLERNAND's army up White River. There is a battery, it is well known, at or near St. Charles, on White River, which once before checked the progress of our gunboats up that stream. The horrible tragedy to the steamer Mound City occurred there, and the rebels disgraced humanity by shooting our scalded seamen, who threw themselves into the river while writhing in horrible torture from the steam of an exploded boiler. It would be well enough, if Gen. MCCLERNAND has an adequate force and nothing else for it to do, to send a detachment up White River, and destroy the fortifications near St. Charles; and he may have done so. But it is hardly probable he would take his entire force, or the half, or the fourth of it, to perform that insignificant job. If the attempt be made and the work done, there would be nothing in the region beyond to employ the army. At the little town of Des Arc, still further up, there is said to be some rebel manufacturing establishments started, including one for powder. It may be worth while to penetrate to Des Arc and put an end to that enterprise. But the Army that assails Vicksburgh is not needed for these trifling achievements. If MCCLERNAND wishes to meet and fight an enemy, he need not turn his army toward Arkansas at all. He will find no considerable force of Rebels, and no strongholds now in that State. If he wishes to go into the Cotton trade, he can not do better, perhaps, than occupy the towns on the White and the Arkansas rivers. The planters will cheerfully do as they did in all the region round about Helena -- sell cotton freely on consideration of having their slaves kept out of the Union camps and forced to stay on their plantations. But this army, we hope, will be put to no such base uses.

abstract: Congress; Galleries; Soldiers Applauding in; Should be at the Front
snippet: Congress; Galleries; Soldiers Applauding in; Should be at the Front
lead_paragraph: -- Two members of Congress had a political gladiatorial display in the House on Wednesday. The galleries were crowded with spectators of all classes, who made noisy manifestations of their feelings as the debate progressed. Our Washington telegraphic correspondent, in mention of the occurrence, observed yesterday, that it was "significant that the soldiers in the galleries -- a large proportion of the audience" -- listened in displeased silence to one side in the debate, but "rapturously applauded" the other.

abstract: London Times' Cor. at Richmond Wishes Payment in Greenbacks
snippet: London Times' Cor. at Richmond Wishes Payment in Greenbacks
lead_paragraph: -- The Richmond correspondent of the London Times, in his recent letters, insists that the Government of the United States has lost all credit and that its utter and hopeless ruin is impending. It is possible that he belives this. But if so, how does it happen that he quite recently instructed the bankers in this City, through whom he receives payment from the Times, to forwerd the amount in greenbacks to him at Richmond? Which affords the best index of his real opinions, this order to his bankers or his letters to the Times?

abstract: FOG AND COLLISION. A fog has hung over the North River for two days past, and during yesterday was very dense. About 9 o'clock yesterday forenoon the Jersey City ferry-boat Gregory ran into the steamship...
lead_paragraph: FOG AND COLLISION. -- A fog has hung over the North River for two days past, and during yesterday was very dense. About 9 o'clock yesterday forenoon the Jersey City ferry-boat Gregory ran into the steamship Talisman, of Liverpool, which anchored the day previously in the stream directly in the track of the ferry boat. The pilot of the ferry-boat had requested the officers to ring a bell or sound a horn, but they paid no attention to the request until after the collision occurred. The vessels came together with great force, so much so that some of the iron plates of the steamer were broken above the water line. Some of the ferry passengers found themselves suddenly prostrated on the deck, but no one was injured to any extent, and the boat was not damaged. The trips were quite irregular throughout the day and evening.

abstract: Arrangements for Immediate Payment
snippet: Arrangements for Immediate Payment
lead_paragraph: The army will not be any better pleased than the country to learn that Congress has at last made adequate provision for the immediate payment, of the troops. The bill authorizing the Secretary of the Treasury to issue for this purpose one hundred million dollars of non-interest-bearing legal tender demand notes, which passed the Senate on Wednesday, went through the House yesterday by a vote almost unanimous; and we presume was signed by the President before he wrapped the drapery of his couch about him and lay down to pleasant dreams last night. The notes are to be in denominations of not less than one dollar, and are to be issued in such form as the Secretary of the Treasury may deem expedient. We presume that Mr. CHASE decided upon the proper form before the bill was introduced; and we hope he will see to it that all the engravers in the country are at once put to work on the plates, and all the presses set running printing them. By this means the soldiers will get their greenbacks, and their destitute families will be enabled to buy victuals and pay rents, in a few days.

abstract: Hamilton vs. Brooklyn City Railroad Co.; Verdict of $2,779 for injuries
snippet: Hamilton vs. Brooklyn City Railroad Co.; Verdict of $2,779 for injuries
lead_paragraph: ROAD COMPANY. -- Mrs. MARIA HAMILTON brought an action in the Brooklyn City Court against the City Railroad Company for damages, laid at $5,000, on account of injuries sustained. It appears that on the 20th of August last plaintiff entered one of the cars of the Company and rode to the corner of Cranberry and Fulton streets. The conductor stopped the car, and plaintiff proceeded to get off. She was told by the conductor to get off on the other (the left) side, and she requested him to wait a minute to enable her to do so. The conductor said he could not wait; he was in a hurry. While in the act of getting off, and one foot still on the step, he rang the bell, and the cars moved on. Plaintiff's dress was caught on a nail, and she ran along for some distance, and being unable to extricate herself, was thrown violently upon the pavement. A crowd was attracted and the car stopped. Her clothes were completely torn from her person. She was conducted to a neighboring drug-store, where she was attended to. She was badly bruised and unable to leave her room for three or four days, and is still laboring under the effects of the injuries sustained. The jury brought in a verdict for plaintiff; damages, $2,779 16.

abstract: On Property in War, and Hanging White Officers of Colored Troops
snippet: On Property in War, and Hanging White Officers of Colored Troops
lead_paragraph: JEFFERSON DAVIS, after having issued a proclamation, in which he declares his intention of hanging all white officers taken in command of negro soldiers in the Union service, or, as he calls them, "seditious negroes," has once more denounced Gen. BUTLER for having stolen millions of dollars from private citizens in New-Orleans, "although the usages of war exempt private property from taxation." We regret on his own account that he should have made this statement, because, in the first place, he ought to be the last man in the world to appeal "to the usages of war;" and in the second, because it is not true that those usages "exempt private property from taxation by an enemy." So far from it, that one of the great objects of wars of invasion, and especially of all attempts to seize the enemy's capital, is to acquire the power of taxing his citizens.

abstract: NIBLO'S GARDEN MR. BANDMANN'S DEBUT.  The impulse that was given to the accurate study of SHAKESPEARE by GOETHE and SCHILLER, aided by the researches and analytic acumen of SCHLEGEL, exercised so marked an influence upon the German stage that its impersonations of the great dramatist's creations may be said to be free from the ordinary hampering traditions of the sock and buckskin, and to depend almost exclusively upon the generally superior, because usually independent, suggestions...
lead_paragraph: NIBLO's GARDEN -- MR. BANDMANN's DEBUT. -- The impulse that was given to the accurate study of SHAKESPEARE by GOETHE and SCHILLER, aided by the researches and analytic acumen of SCHLEGEL, exercised so marked an influence upon the German stage that its impersonations of the great dramatist's creations may be said to be free from the ordinary hampering traditions of the sock and buckskin, and to depend almost exclusively upon the generally superior, because usually independent, suggestions of a high order of literary mind. An English actor, whatever his standing, can hardly fail to borrow something from his predecessors. Experience is always the bully of Genius, until it becomes its slave. It is the red tape of life, finding what can be, by what has been done. With us the flimsiest tradition concerning SHAKESPEARE is a matter of awful concern. The Germans, freed from these restraints, and being destitute of veneration for anything except intellect, have succeeded better than any other people in bringing a cool judgment to the consideration of works that are, for the most part, immured in histrionic rubbish, and involved in the comments of common-place commentators. It must be admitted that the revival inaugurated by the three great names we have mentioned never progressed very far as a means of public amusement and instruction. Its best fruits reverted to the literary source whence they emanated. No literature can boast a more careful and kindly regard for the English Bard than the German. Without any trivial respect for details and moot points, it illuminates vividly and comprehensively the best characteristics of SHAKESPEARE's genius.

abstract: Army Reform Bill of; Mr. Wilson's Bill to Reform
snippet: Army Reform Bill of; Mr. Wilson's Bill to Reform
lead_paragraph: Senator WILSON, of the Military Committee, has introduced a bill which deserves the immediate consideration of Congress. If liable to no constitutional objection, it should become a law. It is a bill for the consolidation of regiments and companies. It provides that when the numerical force of any two regiments of volunteers from the same State, in the United States service, shall be less than the maximum prescribed by law for one such regiment, the President may direct the consolidation of these two regiments. And that when a single regiment of volunteers from any State is reduced to one-half the maximum required by law, the President may direct the consolidation of the companies of such regiment -- giving to no company, however, a number beyond the maximum of a company required by law.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, a communication was received from the Secretary of the Interior, asking for appropriations for the Capitol extension and the new dome. A memorial from the widow of the late Col. BAKER, asking for a pension, was presented.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, yesterday, a communication was received from the Secretary of the Interior, asking for appropriations for the Capitol extension and the new dome. A memorial from the widow of the late Col. BAKER, asking for a pension, was presented. The bill to suspend the sale of lands in the Department of the South, was reported back from the Military Committee, with an amendment as a substitute. A bill to prevent and punish fraud on the Government, was introduced by Mr. WILSON, of Massachusetts. The Finance Committee was directed to inquire into the expediency of making an appropriation to encourage emigration from Europe to the United States. A resolution was adopted directing an inquiry as to the force raised in Missouri for local defence. The Military Committee was directed to report upon the practicability of widening and deepening the Fox and Wisconsin rivers, so as to improve their navigation. A resolution offered by Mr. MCDOUGALL, of California, directing an inquiry into the construction and capabilities of our iron-clad vessels, was rejected by a tie vote. A bill giving authority to the heads of Departments to appoint persons temporarily to discharge their duties, was reported from the Judiciary Committee. The resolution relative to the transportation of certain papers through the mails was adopted. Another petition from WM. CORNELL JEWETT, asking for the adoption of the peace policy of Louis NAPOLEON, HORACE GREELEY and Mr. VALLANDIGHAM, was presented and laid on the table. The bill making appropriations for deficiencies in the civil service was passed. The bill providing aid to Missouri to emancipate her slaves was called up by Mr. HENDERSON, of that State, who made a speech advocating its passage. It was then postponed, as was also the bill for the consolidation of regiments in the field, after some debate. The bill to increase the clerical force of the Quartermaster's Department was debated until the adjournment, which was until Monday.

abstract: Their Fewness and Indecisiveness; The Only Four of the War; Casualties of Great Battles in the United States and Europe
snippet: Their Fewness and Indecisiveness; The Only Four of the War; Casualties of Great Battles in the United States and Europe
lead_paragraph: It is extraordinary that, though it is now over a year since the National and the rebel forces under arms have each comprised many hundreds of thousands, the number of firstclass battles by which we mean battles wherein at least fifty thousand are engaged on each side have not exceeded four all told. These are Shiloh, Antietam, Fredericksburgh, and Murfreesboro. There was severe fighting on the Peninsula, during the memorable seven days; but at no time was there what could rightly be called a general engagement. At Gaines' Mills, the heaviest action of all, only 35,000 of our forces were engaged. No other example can be found in modern history of such great armies, with so few great collisions. Of minor fights there has been no lack. They number scores. It is of the great effective conflicts alone that the list is so strangely meagre.

abstract: Colenso, Bishop J. W.; The Pentateuch and the Book of Joshua Critically Examined
snippet: Colenso, Bishop J. W.; The Pentateuch and the Book of Joshua Critically Examined
lead_paragraph: The ludicrous side of the experience of good Bishop COLENSO, who went to the Cape to convert the Zulu Kaffirs and came back converted by them, is too palpable to have escaped the popular eye; and the reading public on both sides of the Atlantic have heartily enjoyed a joke which is all the more enjoyable in that it springs from a soil not hitherto supposed capable of that kind of yield. It is not the first time that missionaries have met with the like discomfiture. HENRY MARTYN, who labored among the Persian Mahometans, records that he found no difficulty in making them believe all he told them of the Scripture miracles; but they directly paralleled them by wonders of their own. They were proof against any argument from the resurrection because they held that their own sheiks had the power of raising the dead! Who knows, if missionaries were wont to emulate the candor of COLENSO, how frequent such experiences would be seen to be? For ourselves, we are free to confess that we willingly overlook any violation of the conventional dignity of the Episcopal office, whereof the Bishop of Natal may have been guilty in his naive narrative of how he was floored in his first wrestle with the "Zulumind," for the value of the experience itself. If it is lawful, in the spirit of the Apostolical injunction, to be all things to all men to the end to "win some," the good Bishop may be pardoned for having, (though quite unbeknown to himself, we may be sure) caught the ear of our frivolous age by making even the Pentateuch the subject of a "sensation." The source of the book, and the circumstances of its publication, have led many who certainly would never otherwise have been tempted to look into biblical exegesis, to consider the weighty matters it suggests. It has had a wide currency, both in Europe and America. Rejoinders and replications are already published and publishing, and the great argument is reopened for discussion before the bar of the public conscience. If we thus assign to The Pentateuch and Book of Joshua Critically Examined an important mission in awakening many to thought on the highest subjects of human speculation, we may be allowed to say that its scientific significance is absolutely null -- that it treats only of topics already exhaustively treated, and that it adds nothing to the vast fabric of biblical criticism raised by the labor of continental, and especially of German scholars.

abstract: Requiem Mass at New-York for the Dead
snippet: Requiem Mass at New-York for the Dead
lead_paragraph: In accordance with public notice previously given, a grand Requiem Mass was performed at St. Patrick's Cathedral, in this City, yesterday morning, for the repose of the souls of all the dead of the Irish Brigade since the beginning of the war. The Mass of the occasion was MOZART's Short Requiem. The famed band of the receiving-ship North Carolina, was present, and incidentally performed, in masterly style, the following music: Aria from "S[???]abat Mater," selections from "Tannhausser," grand march from "Gabrielle," and cava[???]na from "Masnad eri." A guard of marines detailed for the occasion, under command of Sergt. R.J. ALEXANDER, occupied the centre aisle during the services, standing on either side of the representative coffin of the deceased. Rev. Father OUELLET, Chaplain of the Sixty-ninth Volunteers, or Father WILLETT, as he is sometimes called, sang the Mass, Father MAGUIRE was the Deacon, Father WOODS Sub-Deacon, Father STARR performed the absolution, and Father MCNEIRNEY was Master of Ceremonies. Fathers LAFONT, CURRAN, DONNELLY, FARRELL, NELLIGAN, MALONE and KILLEEN assisted. The en [???]e services were exceedingly imposing, and were witnessed by as many as could crowd within the spacious edifice. Indeed, the cathedral his seldom been the scene of more imposing ceremonies. Brig.-Gen. MEAGHER, accompanied by many officers of his brigade, occupied prominent seals, and the General particularly was the object of much observation, as he was in the course of the sermon addressed several times from the pulpit.

abstract: Removed by Jeff, Davis; Bonds of Political Union; On Negroes Competing with Northern Laborers
snippet: Removed by Jeff, Davis; Bonds of Political Union; On Negroes Competing with Northern Laborers
lead_paragraph: In the celebrated stumping tour which Mr. FERNANDO WOOD made in Connecticut, during the canvass prior to the last Presidential election, he assured the electors of that benighted State that the Southern negroes were so lazy, stupid, ignorant and unfit for freedom, that, if liberated, they would all start North, and compete in the labor market with such skill, energy and eagerness for work, that they would throw white mechanics out of employment. His friends, COX and VALLANDIGHAM, are now engaged in proving a proposition of equal lucidity and much greater terrors, viz.: That the Western States are so opposed to secession, and so devoted to the Union, that if the New-England fanatics do not soon consent to peace and compromise, they (the Western States) will themselves secede. The theory of these gentlemen is, that if the South succeeds, the West will join it, out of love for the Mississippi River; and if it does not succeed, it will make common cause with it in ousting New-England, out of dislike to the opinions of Yankees on the subject of Slavery.

abstract: The large troop of United States Marines, which were captured on board the Ariel, by SEMMES, of the Alabama, have been exchanged, and are now at the service of the Government. Their officers too, among whom are Capt. D.M. COHEN, Maj. GARLAND, Lieut. MCELRATH, and others, will repair to their original destination, at Mare Island Navy-yard, California, where a permanent marine garrison is to be established for the first time. Arms and equipments have been furnished the men from one of the United States armories in the Pacific.

abstract: We have this morning a full confirmation of the report of the victory at Arkansas Post, one hundred miles up the Arkansas River. While an attack was made on the rebel fortifications in front by the gunboats, the land forces debarked two miles below, and marched to their rear, thus forcing a speedy surrender. Six rebel regiments were captured in the earthworks, and two Texas regiments, marching to reinforce the place, being ignorant of its capture, were also captured. A large amount of ammunition and stores were taken. Our loss was not so heavy as at first reported.

abstract: ARREST OF A NOTED FORGER A very highly important arrest was made on Friday by Detectives McCORD, ROSEFORD and ELDER, in the person of CHARLES PELL, an extensive operator, who for a series of years has eluded the vigilance of the authorities. PELL, who is an Englishman, was arrested at Binghamton, Broome County, on suspicion of having...
lead_paragraph: ARREST OF A NOTED FORGER. -- A very highly important arrest was made on Friday by Detectives McCORD, ROSEFORD and ELDER, in the person of CHARLES PELL, an extensive operator, who for a series of years has eluded the vigilance of the authorities. PELL, who is an Englishman, was arrested at Binghamton, Broome County, on suspicion of having been concerned in two forgeries, one on the 4th of September, 1862, for $4,370; and one on the 8th of September, 1862, for $4,700, the same purporting to be checks drawn by F.P. JAMES, a banker of No. 36 Wall-street, on the Bank of North America. The one drawn on the 4th of September was certified at the Bank of North America and paid at the Grocers' Bank. The second forgery was not so successful. It was presented at the Seventh Ward Bank and Grocers' Bank, and refused at both places. It afterwards turned up at the North River Bank, where it was deposited, and a certificate of deposit taken for it. This certificate of deposit was taken to Chicago and negotiated, and afterwards came back to the North River Bank for payment. From certain information received by the officers, suspicion rested upon PELL as being the guilty party, and they immediately went upon his track. Sheriff BOWEN, of Broome County, afforded the officers such facilities as to render the task of arresting PELL a comparatively easy one, and he was, on Friday evening, brought to this City, and locked up. The accused, it is alleged, is an extensive operator, and has pursued his practices for a series of years. He was taken into custody about a year since, on charge of presenting a forged check at the Bank of the Republic for $2,000. He is supposed to have been concerned in a forgery upon the Newark City Bank on the 17th inst., for the sum of $3,207, and upon the Mechanics' Bank, of Newark, for $1,000, and upon the State Bank at Newark for $2,400, all of which were paid in good money. PELL answers the description of the man who presented the checks. He was taken before Justice CONNOLLY yesterday morning for examination.

abstract: Order Expelling All Jews from Dep't of the Tennessee; Expelling Jews from Department of the Tennessee; Gen. Grant's cruel order expelling from Department of the Tennessee
snippet: Order Expelling All Jews from Dep't of the Tennessee; Expelling Jews from Department of the Tennessee; Gen. Grant's cruel order expelling from Department of the Tennessee
lead_paragraph: One of the deepest sensations of the war is that produced among the Israelites of this country, by the recent order of Gen. GRANT, excluding them, as a class, from his Military Department. The order, to be sure, was promptly set aside by the President, but the affront to the Israelites, conveyed by its issue, was not so easily effaced. It continues to rankle, and is leading to sharp controversies and bitter feuds in the ranks of the Faithful. It seems that a committee of Jews, in this City, took it upon themselves to thank the authorities at Washington for so promptly annulling the odious order of GRANT. Against the conduct of this committee the bulk of the Jews vehemently protest. They say they have no thanks for an act of simple and imperative justice -- but grounds for deep and just complaint against the Government, that Gen. GRANT has not been dismissed from the service on account of his unrighteous act. The matter has been made to assume an importance that requires a mention of it in our columns, as constituting an exciting chapter in our current history. We therefore present the order of Gen. GRANT, that the public judgment in the premises may rest on a clear perception of the facts:

snippet: Resolution of Booksellers' Meeting; Smith, Hon. E. D., on Oratory
lead_paragraph: The redemption of soiled postage stamps, which has been in progress at the New-York Postoffice about a month, will positively close on Tuesday afternoon. All those who have any soiled postage stamps must avail themselves of the opportunity to have them redeemed on Monday of Tuesday as no more stamps will be redeemed after those days. Postmaster WAKEMAN has given the most liberal construction to his order concerning the redemption, and has not counted in the holidays and Sundays. During the last two days he has detailed an extra force of clerks to wait upon all applicants, and the line has been exhausted several times. All who apply on Monday or Tuesday will be attended to, if it takes a force of a hundred clerks. There need, therefore, be no excuse for any one to complain of the Government for not redeeming its postage stamps in this City. All packages under five dollars are redeemed immediately, and all over that sum are receipted for, and, when counted and pronounced good, are redeemed in turn. Already about a quarter of a million dollars' worth of soiled stamps have been redeemed. At least twenty thousand dollars worth of stamps have been rejected as having been used on letters and subsequently washed. Only a day or two since a package of stamps was received, the backs of which were neatly gummed. Minute investigation, however, developed the fact that every stamp in the package had been used for postage, and subsequently washed. Of course the enterprising stamp-washer did not profit by the speculation. Unfortunately there is no punishment for this species of swindling -- or attempt at swindling.

abstract: On Friday afternoon, the attention of Mr. Comptroller BRENNAM, of this City, was called so the fact that an attempt was about being made by certain parties in Liberty and Fulton streets, to flood the country with a spurions issue of New-York City shinplasters; and such was the source and nature
lead_paragraph: On Friday afternoon, the attention of Mr. Comptroller BRENNAM, of this City, was called so the fact that an attempt was about being made by certain parties in Liberty and Fulton streets, to flood the country with a spurions issue of New-York City shinplasters; and such was the source and nature of the information conveyed to him, that he promptly, and with commendable zeal, took measures to have the guilty parties brought to justice, and a seizure made of the worthless paper. The Comptroller at once communicated with Capt. DOWLING, of the Sixth Precinct, and the latter official, aided by Sergeants JOURDEN and GOLDEN, of the same Ward, yesterday morning began the work -- ferreting out the den where these notes were made, and the general rendezvous of the persons believed to be implicated in the swindle. The officers first went to a place in Liberty-street, where they lay in wait for some evidence which would enable them to trace the matter a little further than they had yet advanced. They had not long to wait, for soon a boy appeared coming down the stairs of the Liberty-street House, bearing in his arms a large bundle. So certain were the officers that they had now got hold of something tangible, that the boy and bundle were seized in a summary way. The bundle was found to contain five hundred sheets of finely-lithographed notes, purporting to have been issued by the Corporation of the City of New-York, pursuant to an ordinance of Oct. 15, 1862. Upon each sheet there were two hundred of these shinplasters, and of the denominations of five cents, ten cents, twenty-five cents and fifty cents. Upon a pretty accurate calculation of the several amounts represented, by the sheets in the bundle which was seized, it was ascertained that no less than the sum of $30,000 was therein contained, all, or the greater portion of which, would, doubtless, have been speedily passed off in different parts of the country, to unsuspecting people, who know that the credit of this City is good; and who having heard of the fact, that the Common Council passed an ordinance authorizing the issue of $3,000,000 of shinplasters, would take all that they could get, the same as they would bills upon any good bank of this City, in preference to the bills of country banks.

abstract: Capt. FULTON, of the bark Parker Cook, one of the most recent victims to the Alabama, has arrived in Philadelphia. His report states that he sailed from Boston for St. Domingo with a cargo which was composed mainly of provisions. Whilst off the Moro Passage, Nov. 30, his vessel was taken by the privateer Alabama. The charts and chronometer of the Parker Cook, the crew,...
lead_paragraph: Capt. FULTON, of the bark Parker Cook, one of the most recent victims to the Alabama, has arrived in Philadelphia. His report states that he sailed from Boston for St. Domingo with a cargo which was composed mainly of provisions. Whilst off the Moro Passage, Nov. 30, his vessel was taken by the privateer Alabama. The charts and chronometer of the Parker Cook, the crew, and also a part of the cargo, were taken on board of the Alabama, and the bark was burned. The Captain and crew were detained on board until Dec. 5. When off Cape Mais, fell in with the schooner Union, for Jamaica, of and from Baltimore. As her cargo belonged to British subjects, the Union was released upon giving a bond for $1,500, and the Captain and crew of the Parker Cook were placed on board, and conveyed to Jamaica. Thence Capt. FULTON took passage for Baltimore, leaving the crew in charge of the American Consul. Capt. FULTON left Philadelphia on Friday for his home in Boston. He states that a brother-in-law of JEFF. DAVIS, of the name of POWELL, holds the position of Lieutenant of Marines on board the Alabama. When SEMMES comes across the "wrong customer," he changes his tactics, shifts his politics, and stretches his conscience. Capt. FULTON himself was in irons, and experienced all the cruel kindness to be expected under the circumstances.

abstract: Opinions of the North at; Richmond Dispatch on Hon. James Brooks' Peace Propositions
snippet: Opinions of the North at; Richmond Dispatch on Hon. James Brooks' Peace Propositions
lead_paragraph: The Richmond Dispatch notices the peace propositions which JAMES BROOKS presented with such applause before a convocation of the Democracy of this City some time since, and thereupon breaks forth into the following astonished inquiries: Are the Northern people all natural-born fools? or are they only stricken with that judicial madness which we are told the gods always inflict upon the victims of their wrath preparatory to their ruin? Can they suppose that the South is as gallless and as lily-livered as themselves?"

abstract: The, the "Test Case" of the Union
snippet: The, the "Test Case" of the Union
lead_paragraph: The popular heart is rapidly wearied by an exhausting and indecislve struggle. With the reserved forces of a nation as yet untouched, and its real ability to achieve the purpose with which it set out still beyond question, there yet comes a time, in almost every great struggle, when sheer fatigue and inconstancy reduce the war party to a minority, and peace at almost any price would be welcomed.

abstract: Sullivan-street M. E. Church. Desecration of the Dead
snippet: Sullivan-street M. E. Church. Desecration of the Dead
lead_paragraph: The wonderful mutations that have taken place upon this Island of Manhattan during the last fifteen or twenty years, consequent upon the rapid and extraordinary growth of the City, have not been confined in their effects to the living solely, but have also cast their shifting shadows down among the dark vaults of the dead. Many are the bones of ancient Burghers and modern Cits that have been dragged from their resting-place -- innocently supposed to be their last -- to witness the "march of improvnment," and be offered up a sacrifice to the "progressive spirit of the age." Sometimes the sacrilege has seemed to be so necessary and inevitable -- as in the laying out of streets avenues, &c., that it was, in a measure, excusable; at other times it has been so evidently dictated by avarice and mercenary greed, that it received, as it merited, the condemnation of every right-minded person in the community. To the latter category belongs the case now under consideration.

abstract: We have this morning an official account of the victory at Arkansas Post, one hundred miles up the Arkansas River. While an attack was made on the rebel fortifications in front by the gunboats, the land forces debarked two miles below, and marched to their rear, thus...
lead_paragraph: We have this morning an official account of the victory at Arkansas Post, one hundred miles up the Arkansas River. While an attack was made on the rebel fortifications in front by the gunboats, the land forces debarked two miles below, and marched to their rear, thus forcing a speedy surrender. Six rebel regiments were captured in the earthworks, and two Texas regiments, marching to reinforce the place, being ignorant of its capture, were also "bagged." A large amount of ammunition and stores were taken. Our loss was not so heavy as at first reported.

abstract: By the arrival at this port yesterday of the brig Costa Rica, Capt. PEEL, from Aspinwall, we learn that on the night of Dec. 26, a fire broke out in the strip-chandlery store of Messrs. LANSBY & BRANDEN, on Front-street, destroying some three blocks of buildings on Front-street. Among the buildings destroyed were the Panama Railroad Company's office. Howard House, St. Charles Hotel. Aspinwall House, and several other fine edifices. The loss is estimated at upward of $300,000. The steamer America, from New-York, was at Aspinwall with her passengers from New-York still on board. When the Costa Rica sailed (Dec. 30) the steamer on the Pacific side from San Francisco had not arrived. The steamship Champion, which left New-York Dec. 22, had not arrived at Aspinwall.

abstract: The U. S gunboat steamer Sagamore, Capt. EARLE ENGLISH, has just returned (10th, 12 M.) from a cruise up the East coast of Florida, having captured two prizes. The English sloop Avenger, of Nassau, N.P., inside of Jupiter Inlet, Fla., with a cargo consisting of blankets and sundries, and the English sloop Julia, near Jupiter, bound in from Nassau with salt and sundries. Two other small vessels were wrecked and abandoned near Indian River.
lead_paragraph: From Our Own Correspondent.

abstract: the traveler and author--his career
snippet: the traveler and author--his career
lead_paragraph: Mr. ROSS BROWNE, who makes a "Trip to Iceland" this evening, at the hall of the Historical Society, has seen about as much of the world, and turned his hand to as many odds and ends of human enterprise, as any man within the range of our knowledge. He commenced his strange career, as he tells in some of his published sketches, by an extensive pedestrian tour through the Western States; after which he made several voyages down the Ohio and Mississippi Rivers in the capacity of a common boatman. He next turned up as a police reporter in Louisville, from which he gradually diverged into the study of medicine. Not liking that, he took up the profession of stenographer, and spent some time as Congressional reporter in Washington. With a capital of fifteen dollars, the net result of his labors in that branch of industry, he set out to see the world; got as far as New-York, spent his money, and shipped before the mast in a New-Bedford whaler. During a voyage of a year and a half to the Indian Ocean, he assisted in the capture of many whales, visited the Azores, Canary, and Cape de Verd Islands, Madagascar, Comoro, and Zanzibar. At Zanzibar a mutiny broke out, and he left the vessel. He spent three months on the island, among the Arabs, and then worked his passage home in a Salem merchantman, visiting St. Helena on the way. The result of this voyage was a Narrative of Adventures in the Whale Fishery, published by the HARPERS in 1844. From that date till 1848, he was engaged in the United States Treasury Department as compiler of bank statistics, and private secretary to Mr. ROBERT J. WALKER. He was next appointed a Lieutenant in the revenue service, and ordered for duty to the Pacific coast. During a voyage round Cape Horn he visited the Brazils, the Island of Juan Fernandez, Lima, and other places of interest, of which he has given some amusing sketches. His visit to Crusoe's Island, published in Harper's Magazine in 1853, attracted considerable attention.

abstract: United States vs. Various Blockade Runners
snippet: United States vs. Various Blockade Runners
lead_paragraph: The United States vs. The Schooner Water Witch and her Cargo.-This vessel was captured Aug. 23, 1862, off Aranzas Bar, Texas, by the yacht Corypaehus, tender to the United States bark Arthur. No one intervened in the suit for either vessel or cargo. Only one witness the master of the vessel, was examined. He explained the non-production of the rest of the crew by testifying that they were all Spaniards and Portuguese, as they told him, and had been taken out of prison in Havana, and impressed into service on board the prize, and it was considered dangerous to send them with the vessel to this port. They were accordingly left at Pensacola

abstract: The New-Year's Day Disaster at
snippet: The New-Year's Day Disaster at
lead_paragraph: View it in what light we may, the NewYear's Day disaster at Galveston, of which we yesterday presented a full account from our correspondent at Galveston Bay, is about the most disgraceful stain which has been put upon our arms during the whole progress of this war. The capture of the town by the rebels was bad enough; but when, at the same time, we hear of the boarding and seizure of one United States war vessel -- the blowing up of another -- and the ignominious flight of the rest, before two or three pasteboard Mississippi steamboats piled up with cotton bales and manned by musketeers, the measure of the nation's shame and anger is filled to overflowing.

abstract: Capt. FULTON, of the bark Parker Cook, one of the most recent victims to the Alabama, has arrived in Philadelphia. His report states that he sailed from Boston for St. Domingo with a cargo which was composed mainly of provisions. Whilst off the Moro Passage, Nov. 30, his vessel was taken by the privateer Alabama. The charts and chronometer of the Parker Cook, the crew, and also a part of the cargo, were taken on board of the Alabama, and the bark was burned. The Captain and crew were detained on board until Dec. 5. When off Cape Mais, fell in with the schooner Union, for Jamaica, of and from Baltimore. As her cargo belonged to British subjects, [???] Union was released upon giving a bond for [???],580, and the Captain and crew of the Parker Cook were placed on board, and conveyed to Jamaica. Thence Capt. FULTON took passage for Baltimore, leaving the crew in charge of the American Consul. Capt. FULTON left Philadelphia on Friday for his home in Boston. He states that a brother-in-law of JEFF. DAVIS, of the name of POWELL, holds the position of Lieutenant of Marines on board the Alabama. When SEMMES comes across the "wrong customer," he changes his tactics, shifts his politics, and stretches his conscience. Capt. FULTON himself was in irons, and experienced all the cruel kindness to be expected under the circumstances.

abstract: United States vs. Bodine and Seaver; Forged County Applications
snippet: United States vs. Bodine and Seaver; Forged County Applications
lead_paragraph: The United States vs. John Bodine and Zachariah Seaver. -- These defendants were put on trial under an indictment charging them with fraudulently transmitting, or causing to be transmitted to the office of the Commissioner of Pensions, false, forged and counterfeited papers for the purpose of obtaining bounty land. The paper was an application purporting to be signed by one William E. Spencer, claiming bounty land on account of service on board the U.S. ship Potomac. It purported to have been sworn to before Seaver as Notary Public by Spencer, and by two witnesses named Thomas Kimble and George Ward, Spencer making his mark. Mr. Anson appeared as counsel for Bodine, and Mr. Nash and Judge Stewart for Seaver. Before the evidence was commenced, Bouine's counsel moved for a separate trial for him, which was denied. Before the evidence was closed he pleaded guilty, and the trial proceeded against Seaver alone.

abstract: Mr. WALLACK favored his inconveniently numerous patrons with a revival of VANBRUGH and CIBBER'S comedy of the "Provoked Husband," on Saturday evening, attracting to the exhumation of that delectable fossil one of the most crowded and fashionable audiences of the season. The piece is hardly...
lead_paragraph: Mr. WALLACK favored his inconveniently numerous patrons with a revival of VANBRUGH and CIBBER'S comedy of the "Provoked Husband," on Saturday evening, attracting to the exhumation of that delectable fossil one of the most crowded and fashionable audiences of the season. The piece is hardly known to the present generation of theatre-goers, and will not, we think, live in remembrance from its present resuscitation. Sir JOHN VANBRUGH belongs to the dullest period of English dramatic literature, when under the influence of good Queen ANNE, the stage was trying to purify itself of the licentiousness of the previous reign, and to set itself up as a monitor. The "Provoked Husband" teaches the lesson that female gamblers bring misery to their homes, and in the end are sure to estrange the affections of their husbands. Wholesome as this lesson may have been in the day when it was given, it has lost its significance now, and the homilies of Lord Townley, and the fashionable flippancies of his lady are alike wearisome. Of plot or intrigue there is really nothing. The analyist looks in vain for anything beyond characterization; listens with unrewarded diligence for an expression higher than a conversational commonplace. The only character that possesses vitality is that of Lady Townley, and it is probable that SHERIDAN, in calling her Lady Teazle and giving her a reasonable opportunity in the "School for Scandal," was actuated by motives of benevolence. It is certain that the two characters are almost identical. For the rest we may say briefly that the piece is long and tiresome, that it has a comic department bearing no relation with the main concern, and that the fun is the fun of clod-hoppers. Why the piece should be produced, except to add another unfortunate husband to the calendar of Mr. WALLACK's Court of Arches, we are at a loss to understand.

abstract: Meeting condemning Mr. Callicott's course in the Legislature; meeting in Brooklyn condemning his course on New-York Speakership
snippet: Meeting condemning Mr. Callicott's course in the Legislature; meeting in Brooklyn condemning his course on New-York Speakership
lead_paragraph: The announcement that Hon. T.C. CALLICOTT Democratic representative from the Fifth Assembly District of Kings County, had allowed his name to be used in connection with the office of Speaker of the present House of Assembly in this State, in opposition to Hon. GILBERT DEAN, the regular caucus nominee of the party, has nowhere created such intense excitement in the Democratic ranks as in the City of Brooklyn, the Ninth and Eleventh Wards of which he represents in the present Legislature. A meeting of the Democracy was held last evening in the Governor's Room, City Hall, for the purpose of taking such action in the premises as might be deemed most advisable. The room was literally packed with the followers of the Democratic Party, and at ten minutes to 8 o'clock the meeting was called to order by Mr. JOHN J. WHITE, who nominated Mr. THOMAS H. FARRON. City Comptroller, as Chairman.

abstract: Sullivan-street M. E. Church. Desecration Case Investigated and Proved
snippet: Sullivan-street M. E. Church. Desecration Case Investigated and Proved
lead_paragraph: The account published exclusively in yesterday's TIMES of the disgraceful manner in which the dead bodies are being removed from the vaults of the old Sullivan-street Methodist Episcopal Church, under the direction of its former owners, the present Trustees of the Methodist Church in Fourth-street, caused a good deal of excitement among the friends of those whose remains were thus sacrilegiously violated, as well as in the public at large, which was shocked, as well it might be, by the narration. The investigation had before City Inspector DELAVAN yesterday fully substantiated every statement published in the TIMES, and, if possible, made the matter still worse.

abstract: By the steamship America, which arrived at this port last evening, we receive our correspondence from the Isthmus of Panama to the 9th inst. She left Aspinwall in company with the steamship Champion, with the California treasure on board, convoyed by the gunboat Augusta, but they parted company on the 15th, off Watling's Island. Our letter from Aspinwall gives a full account of the fire which occurred there on the 26th ult. It destroyed all the hotels in the place, the Panama Railroad office, the United States Consulate, and WELLS, FARGO & CO.'s office. The news from the interior of New-Granada is not important. We have by this arrival, also, later advices from Central and South America, but they present no feature worthy of special mention.

abstract: The iron-clad steamer Ozark, building at Mound City, has had her ribs put up, and will in a few weeks begin to assume the aspect of a finished vessel. Considerable curiosity exists in the navy about this vessel, owing to the fact that Chief Engineer WHITAKER, who was called home from the Mediterranean Station to test a new iron-clad annihilator, is at work putting his new invention on board. The Ozark does not belong to any of the classes of iron-clads hitherto printed in order. She is of the same general description as the Tuscumbia, and others of that rate. There is still another type in course of construction, some of the vessels of which have not, we believe been commenced up to this time.

abstract: The Postmaster-General is inexorably determined not to extend the time for the redemption of soiled postage-stamps. To-day is therefore the last day, and all applicants, from 9 o'clock A.M. to 4 P.M., will be promptly served. Packages of less than $5 will be immediately cashed, while all amounts exceeding that sum must take their turn among the hundreds of packages already received, and to count which will occupy a dozen men at least three months. The latest estimate is that about $300,000 will be paid out for the redemption [of soiled stamps, and that at least $30,000 of the amount offered has consisted of stamps already used once. Of course this latter sum has not been paid, but has been saved to the Government by the keen research of the gentlemen engaged in the examination. Postmaster WAKEMAN evinces a disposition to give the public every possible opportunity to get their old stamps redeemed, and as to-day is the last day, will detail clerks enough to attend to all who come. As many as a thousand packages have been handed in and receipted for in one day, but should even double that number be presented to-day, they will be duly attended to. So ample has been we notice, and so prompt the method of dispatching business at the Post-office, that it is believed that very nearly all the spoiled postage stamps in this City will have been redeemed by to-night.

abstract: Credit; a Plan for Restoring
snippet: Credit; a Plan for Restoring
lead_paragraph: Almost every man and woman in the country has his, or her, favorite plan for sustaining the National credit and paying off the interest and principal of the rapidly-growing public debt. Those in foreign countries who have remarked the various bills introduced into Congress, and who have read the speeches of members and the articles in leading journals, may well be struck with the fecundity of our national genius in this respect, if not with the facility with which the American people can raise money, pay fearful debts, and come out of a huge war wealthier and stronger then when they entered upon it. Out of all these conflicting schemes of finance the true one will, doubtless, finally be evolved, and perhaps put in operation.

abstract: and Longstreet, The Armies of
snippet: and Longstreet, The Armies of
lead_paragraph: -- The immense fall of rain and snow in the west and southwest, has put an end to all apprehension that Gen. ROSECRANS would find difficulty in supplying his army at Nashville. All the rivers of Tennessee and Kentucky are at their highest Winter flood. Boats of the heaviest draft known on the western waters can navigate the Cumberland as easily as the Mississippi. The telegraph announces the arrival of twenty boats, yesterday, at Nashville, laden with army supplies. With the river and the railroad to serve him, Gen. ROSECRANS will not be detained from pursuit of the enemy by lack of provisions. It is said, however, that reinforcements are needed before the rebel army, now under the command of LONGSTREET, can be again attacked. This is probable. Our loss at Murfreesboro was doubtless equal to 16 per cent. of the force we had engaged. We had none too many for the work in hand, and the rebels have since been reinforced by a better General than BRAGG, and it is said by a heavy body of troops from Virginia. We need to strengthen ourselves before the campaign is renewed; for in addition to fighting an obstinate rebel army in his selected position. Gen. ROSECRANS will need to build and defend a railroad in his rear to maintain his connection with his base of supplies.

abstract: ASSAULT UPON POLICEMEN IN THE FIFTH WARD. -- We find the following upon the returns of yesterday, from the Fifth Police Precinct: About 1 o'clock on Sunday evening, Officers COLES and CONNELLY, of the Fifth Precinct, while in the discharge of their duty, entered the liquor-store of M. HILDEBRAND, at No. 97 West Broadway, where they were immediately attacked by five or six of the inmates of the place, including the proprietor and his clerk, who beat them with bottles, clubs, &c. Officer COLES was knocked down, and afterward thrown from the place, while Officer CONNELLY was locked in and afterward badly beaten. Officer COLES ran to the Station-house for help, when Sergeant BARNETT and others went to the store and demanded admittance, which was refused. They then broke open the door and arrested FRANK MULLER, the clerk, AUGUST KRUGER, an ex-policemen, and HENRY ROSE. The proprietor and others made their escape through a back window. The officers represent that they were badly bruised and beaten during the melie.

abstract: REPUDIATION "SQUELCHED" IN ORANGE. A large mass meeting of the citizens of Orange was held at Library Hall, on Saturday afternoon, at which the proposed supplement to the Town Charter, authorizing the issue of $40,000 in bonds to make good the town certificates now held by volunteers and citizens, was unanimously adopted.
lead_paragraph: REPUDIATION "SQUELCHED" IN ORANGE. A large mass meeting of the citizens of Orange was held at Library Hall, on Saturday afternoon, at which the proposed supplement to the Town Charter, authorizing the issue of $40,000 in bonds to make good the town certificates now held by volunteers and citizens, was unanimously adopted. It is stated that an attempt was made by "secesh" sympathisers to pack the meeting, in order to secure the repudiation of the action of the Town Council, and to adopt Alderman HARRISON's amendment, providing for $20,000, which would simply have paid the certificates held by the volunteers, and left the citizens holding the balance of the $40,000 in the lurch. Much indignation has been caused by the effort of the repudiators to force the town into a course of action which is justly regarded an dishonorable and dishonest.

abstract: Gen. MORGAN'S command returned to Tennessee Saturday last. In their campaign in Kentucky the Bacon Creek, Nolin, Elizabethtown, Shepherdsville, (eighteen miles from Louisville,) and other bridges were totally destroyed for the distance of eighty miles. The trestle work of the two first was at Muldrough's Hill, twelve hundred feet long and ninety feet high, and burnt and completely destroyed.
lead_paragraph: From the Winchester (Tenn.) Bulletin, Jan. 9.

abstract: The President has sent a message to Congress, announcing that he has signed the Joint resolution recently passed, proceeding for the additional issue of $100,000,000 in Treasury notes, to provide for the prompt payment of our soldiers and sailors.
lead_paragraph: The President has sent a message to Congress, announcing that he has signed the Joint resolution recently passed, proceeding for the additional issue of $100,000,000 in Treasury notes, to provide for the prompt payment of our soldiers and sailors. He takes occasion, however, to express his regret that it has been found necessary to authorize so large an additional issue, and urges the importance of adopting some scheme whereby a further inflation may be avoided. He suggests a reasonable taxation of bank circulation, and the establishment of banking associations authorized under a general act of Congress, as suggested in his Message at the beginning of the session.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, a communication from the Post-office Department was received, explaining that the detention of the mails between New-York and Washington was caused mainly by the increased travel on account of the war, but that it would be remedied. A bill to promote the efficiency of the Medical Department of the army was reported from the Military Committee. Mr. MCDOUGALL, of California, offered a series of concurrent resolutions relative to the proceedings of the French in Mexico, which, at his request, were laid over until next Thursday. The bill reorganizing the Court of Claims was debated until the expiration of the morning hour, when the bill on the discharge of State prisoners was taken up, and occupied attention until the adjournment. Speeches were made by Messrs. POWELL, of Kentucky, and WRIGHT, of Indiana.

abstract: Generalship, Failures in
snippet: Generalship, Failures in
lead_paragraph: In an article, two or three days since, upon our large battles, we showed conclusively that, notwithstanding the employment in them of rifled cannon and "arms of precision," on a scale never before known, they exhibited a remarkably smaller ratio of killed and wounded than the great battles of the century in Europe, or than even our own sharplycontested smaller engagements; that while the victors at Solferino lost over 30 per cent., and while at Friedland and Marengo the loss on each side was 21 per cent., at Jena 26, at Waterloo 30, at Aspern 35, at Eilau and at Borodino each 36; and while, in this present war, the loss at Wilson's Creek was 25 per cent., at Williamsburgh 19, at Fair Oaks 25, and at Corinth 20, yet in the very few large battles hitherto fought -- in which 50,000 or over were engaged on each side -- our losses in killed and wounded averaged only a half or a third as much -- those of Shiloh, Fredericksburgh and Murfreesboro being only about 10 per cent. each, and those at Antietam about 13. Now, what does this signal difference indicate? It proves that as yet we have had no fit generalship.
headline: {'main': 'Failure in Generalship.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Failure in Generalship.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The Deficiencies of
snippet: The Deficiencies of
lead_paragraph: We are not at all prepared to accept the very bitter spirit lately manifested in the Senate against West Point as a just exponent of the feelings of the people; but it is undeniable that the institution is no longer the popular favorite it was. The Senate minority did wrong in seeking to make an end of the institution by withholding the appropriation necessary to its life; and yet it is perfectly true that the rebellion has brought out great evils and deficiencies in its management, never appreciated before. The aim should be not to destroy but to correct.

abstract: There was a steady, hard frost all through Monday night, and yesterday morning the ice on the lower pond in the Central Park was pronounced thick and solid enough to bear any number of skaters that might please to crowd upon it. So, at quite an early hour the "ball" was run up, and all the cars that ran from the Park to the lower part of the City bore the usual announcements of the fact.

abstract: By the steamship Arabia, which arrived at Halifax yesterday morning, we receive advices from Europe two days later than those by the Hibernia at Portland, published yesterday. Reports were again current that the Emperor NAPOLEON intends to recommend an armistice between the North and the South. The American Minister, Mr. DAYTON, had had interviews with the French Minister for Foreign Affairs, and also  with the Emperor.
lead_paragraph: By the steamship Arabia, which arrived at Halifax yesterday morning, we receive advices from Europe two days later than those by the Hibernia at Portland, published yesterday. Reports were again current that the Emperor NAPOLEON intends to recommend an armistice between the North and the South. The American Minister, Mr. DAYTON, had had interviews with the French Minister for Foreign Affairs, and also with the Emperor. It was also assorted that the English Government would persevere in refusing to interfere in American matters in any manner. Sympathizing addresses to President LINCOLN had been adopted in London and Birmingham. The British Parliament has been called to assemble in February. The Liverpool Chamber of Commerce have resolved to give a suitable reception to the officers of the first ship from America with provisions for the distressed operatives. The main English journals indignantly repudiate the recent advocacy of Slavery by the London Times, on Scriptural grounds. A ship had reached Liverpool with 1,700 bales of cotton, from the Cape of Good Hope, raised from Sea Island cotton seed. Another vessel brought 350 hales from Portugal. A new brigade of French troops was to embark for Mexico about the middle of January. Heated debates on the Mexican question were taking place in the Spanish Cortes. The Liverpool Cotton market was quiet and unchanged. Breadstuff's quiet, but steady. Provisions dull, but firm. Consols for money, 93 1/8@93 1/4. Illinois Central Shares, 41@40 1/2 discount; Eries, 43 1/2@44.

abstract: FRIENDS AN INJUNCTION THREATENED. The disclosures made in the TIMES of Monday,  and republished in the other City papers yesterday, with regard to the desecration of the dead in the Sullivan-street Church vaults, have created a good deal of feeling among the friends of persons buried there, and yesterday large numbers of them gathered around the church, eager to ascertain the disposition that had been made of their friends' remains.

abstract: The New-York Times, we are happy to be able to assure it, is entirely in error in its interpretation of the recent refusal of the House of Representatives to agree to the motion of Mr. COLFAX, to discharge the Committee of Ways and Means from the further consideration of the proposition to reduce the duty on foreign printing paper from 35 to ten per cent[???], and to consider It (in the House) immediately. Their action on that occasion simply meant that they declined to give the subject precedence over all other business -- that's all. Out of forty-seven members of the House with whom we have spoken with reference to this proposition, we found but one opposed to it. All the rest appreciated its justice and propriety. Under these circumstances we apprehend, that there can be little doubt that when it comes up in its regular turn it will be adopted by an over whelming majority. -- Washington Star.

abstract: Last evening the second jubilee meeting, in honor of the President's Emancipation Proclamation, was held in the large hall of the Cooper Institute. Mr. JOHN PETERSON, colored, occupying the Chair After Rev. J.C. LOCKWOOD, from Fortress Monroe, had offered up a prayer, the Chairman explained the object of the meeting, and said that the anniversary of Jan. 1, 1863, would always be held as a jubilee, for on that day ABE LINOOLN, stigmatized as the "rail-splitter," knocked Slavery, with his Governmental axe, into pieces much smaller than rails.

abstract: -- The Elmira Advertiser says "The report sent over the telegraph wires, and published in all the papers, of the death by drowning of twenty-seven persons at Harpersville, Broome county, a day or two since, turns out to be a cruel hoax. The person guilty of the meanness of perpetrating it should be ducked in a horse pond until he is nearly or quite drowned, and never allowed the pleasure of skating again in his life."

abstract: Mr. BROWNE's first lecture on Iceland was delivered before a large and intelligent audience, seated in the hall of the Historical Society. The lecture included an account of his journey from Frankfort to Iceland, by the way of Copenhagen and the Faroe Islands. A description of the town of Reykjavik, the capital of the dreary island, was illustrated by a handsome panoramic view and the progress of the lecture was further illustrated by similar pictures, of which the view of the Great Geyser, the Stroher, and the singular Rock of Laws -- where once sat the old Icelandic Parliament -- were the most remarkable. Smaller sketches in water colors of characters met on the journey were also introduced.
lead_paragraph: Mr. BROWNE's first lecture on Iceland was delivered before a large and intelligent audience, seated in the hall of the Historical Society. Smaller sketches in water colors of characters met on the journey were also introduced.

abstract: Smiths and Browns, The
snippet: Smiths and Browns, The
lead_paragraph: There is one portion of the intercepted correspondence of the Confederate Government with their agents in England which will, we do not doubt, inspire the loyal public with more misgiving as to the future than anything which has yet come to light. We have borne, if not with equanimity, at least with fortitude, during two long years, the covert or avowed hostility of the influential classes in Europe. The rank and fashion of England and the Continent are all against us, or use their immense moral influence in bringing us and our cause into disrepute, in exaggerating our reverses, and discrediting our victories. Much as this chagrined us for a time, everybody knows it has not at all disheartened us. Our soldiers have fought just as bravely as if their praises were on every lip in the "gilded saloons " of the aristocracy, and have borne their hardships just as firmly as if there were a thousand duchesses and countesses occupied every night in making pie for them. There is, however, a limit to human endurance, and we greatly fear the revelations made in the intercepted dispatches have brought us close upon it. We needly hardly say that the discovery which so profoundly discourages us is, that, as appears by Mr. MEMMINGER's dispatch of the 25th October to Mr. MASON, the Confederate Plenipotentiary in London, SMITH, of Glasgow, and BROWN, of Edinburgh, have both gone over to the enemy, and are now affording aid and assistance to the rebels. The importance of this incident must furnish our excuse for a second time publishing the dispatch which reveals it:
headline: {'main': 'The British Smiths and Browns.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The British Smiths and Browns.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The steamboat Express, Capt. PHILIP R. CLARKE, went up this afternoon to City Point, under flag of truce, for the purpose of bringing down exchanged prisoners. She will return, probably, on Tuesday morning. Capt. JOHN E. MULFORD, Third New-York, goes in the boat as truce officer. Col. LUDLOW, of Gen. DIX'S staff, returned, yesterday, in the Henry Burden from City Point, having negotiated an exchange with Major OULD, the rebel Commissioner.

abstract: COMFORT FOR OUR SOLDIERS. We would suggest to our readers, and especially those interested in providing comforts for the sick and wounded soldiers, that boast is one of the greatest luxuries that can be sent them. A large quantity has been sent by the citizens of Albany, but all they can furnish is but a tithe of what is needed.
lead_paragraph: COMFORT FOR OUR SOLDIERS. -- We would suggest to our readers, and especially those interested in providing comforts for the sick and wounded soldiers, that boast is one of the greatest luxuries that can be sent them. A large quantity has been sent by the citizens of Albany, but all they can furnish is but a tithe of what is needed. The Surgeons who have used it, especially upon the battle-field, have been almost extravagant in praise of it, saying that the person who first suggested the plan has little idea what a blessing it has proved. Made of the aerated bread, and prepared (thoroughly dried,) in a baker's oven, it will keep for months, and a bowl of hot water is all that is needed to make it just as good as if freshly toasted. A barrel can be furnished for much less than one of crackers, while it is far more palatable and nutritious. To the poor sufferers who have, perhaps, lived on "hard tack" till they loathe it, it gives a grateful change, and to those wounded about the face, particularly, as it is easily masticated.

abstract: -- A few days ago the two Houses of Congress passed a resolution ordering that the soldiers who are fighting the battles of the Union, should be paid. Yesterday it was announced that Secretary CHAER had placed to the credit of the army Paymasters an aggregate amount sufficient to pay the whole of both the army and navy of the United States all their dues up to date. All owing to this joint resolution of Congress!

abstract: EXILES IN DISCORD.  One of the anomalies of the Confederate Congress is, that it has Senators and Representatives from the States of Missouri and Kentucky States which have no connection whatever with the Confederate Government, do not pay any allegiance to it, but in their organized, official capacities, call out, arm ...
lead_paragraph: -- EXILES IN DISCORD. -- One of the anomalies of the Confederate Congress is, that it has Senators and Representatives from the States of Missouri and Kentucky States which have no connection whatever with the Confederate Government, do not pay any allegiance to it, but in their organized, official capacities, call out, arm and forward, forty to fifty thousand soldiers each, to war upon secession as upon a traitorous insurrection. No popular elections were ever held in Missouri or Kentucky to choose and send members of Congress to Richmond. No ballot was ever cast in either State for a member of the rebel Government. Not a man, claiming to be a Senator or a Representative at Richmond, from the States of Kentucky or Missouri, could go back to "his constituents" without the absolute certainty of being snatched up by his admiring fellow-citizens, and safely lodged in the cells of a prison. Yet men, claiming to be such Representatives and Senators from Kentucky and Missouri, continue to meet periodically at Richmond -- participate in JEFF. DAVIS' Congress -- help to levy taxes on the rest of the Confederates, and pass conscription bills, with an impudence that is amazing. Why do not the real, genuine "old original" Secessionists, who bear the burden and heat of the day, spue these Border State neophytes out of their Government? It does not look well -- the bogus representatives of a non-existing constituency holding the highest seats in the synagogue of Secessiondom.

abstract: -The question most eagerly asked of persons just come from E[???]skilled is generally the all-important one of whether the wells are holding out or not. It is a fact that many of the flowing wells have ceased to flow; and others, while still continuing to flow, do not longer yield the immense quantities that they did at first. But then, there remains yet untouched a large area of what there is every reason to believe to be good productive [???] territory. The work of drilling and sinking wells is still vigorously carried on, and a rise in the prints of crude oil to $1 or $2 per barrel would set the drills [???]going at a rate hitherto unheard of. The owners of wells which have ceased to flow do not think [???] [???] while to drill down any further until [???] more [???]ative demand arises for crude oil. When this takes place, every effort will be trade, both by drilling further and pumping [???] bring the oil up, if there is any to bring. The question whether former flowing wells will yield on by pumping, has yet to be [???]ined.

abstract: No one has made the trip between NewYork and Washington, by railroad, within the memory of man, without being convinced that it is the most uncomfortable route of travel, for its importance and amount of patronage, in the United States. The inconveniences of the trip have been owing mainly to the breaks at Philadelphia, Baltimore and Havre de Grace, and the transfers of passengers at these places from one set of cars to another.
lead_paragraph: No one has made the trip between NewYork and Washington, by railroad, within the memory of man, without being convinced that it is the most uncomfortable route of travel, for its importance and amount of patronage, in the United States. The inconveniences of the trip have been owing mainly to the breaks at Philadelphia, Baltimore and Havre de Grace, and the transfers of passengers at these places from one set of cars to another. Whether these changes of cars, and the confusion and delays they occasion, have been owing to lack of enterprise or want of accommodation, on the part of the railroad companies forming the line, or are to be charged to the jealousy of State and municipal legislation, we are not prepared to say. If the latter, the railroad companies are not so much to blame. They have made, perhaps, the best time and the closest connections possible with the municipal privileges they enjoy. Erie, in the north corner of Pennsylvania, for years contended for the privilege of making all the Lake Shore travel between the East and West change cars amid the pen-nul and pie-stands of her chief street; and in this claim was sustained by the Legislature, of the Keystone Slate. Philadelphia, we believe, has not entirely outgrown the village peevishness manifested at Erie. We observed lately in one of her leading journals, a violent protest against the use of her Br[???]-street for the accommodation of proposed through trains between New-York and Washington.

abstract: State Legislature; Contest for Speakership--Disgraceful Scenes
snippet: State Legislature; Contest for Speakership--Disgraceful Scenes
lead_paragraph: The disgraceful scenes which have been exhibited for a fortnight at Albany still go on unabated. People have flocked to the capital from all parts of the State, and our telegraphic correspondent says that the multitude is constantly increasing, and the asperity of feeling growing greater. Last night the dense crowd which filled the passage ways to the Assembly Chamber burst open the door, and rushed in, but only to learn that the House by mutual agreement, had decided to adjourn till to-day at noon.

abstract: the new rumor of; Emperor, the, Intention of, Toward the United States
snippet: the new rumor of; Emperor, the, Intention of, Toward the United States
lead_paragraph: There is another rumor afloat of an intention on the part of the Emperor of the French to repeat his offer of mediation. The story is not in itself unlikely, because the Moniteur, in commenting on addresses recently presented to the Emperor from some of the distressed cotton districts, hinted broadly that those who were interested in the restoration of peace in America might count on his "perseverance" in the course on which he had entered. In addition to this, it must not be forgotten that the battle of Fredericksburgh has occurred since he last brought forward his proposition, and has furnished him with a new argument in favor of its repetition.
headline: {'main': 'The New Rumors of Mediation.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The New Rumors of Mediation.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The French progress not encouraging
snippet: The French progress not encouraging
lead_paragraph: We have advices from Mexico to [???] ult., which are important. Congress adjourned on the 15th, with the full determination of prosecuting the war against the French to the bitter end. The French, contrary to the reports which have before reached us by way of Havana, had not advanced upon Puebla, but were still at Palmar, thirty miles distant, unable to move for lack of teams and mules. The most active preparations were in progress in Puebla for their reception -- new works of defence being thrown up at all points.

abstract: Cooper Institute was crowded to excess last evening, on the occasion of the delivery of Mr. WENDELL PHILLIPS' "Amen to the Proclamation." Every seat in the house was filled long before the hour for the commencement of the oration. The platform was occupied by a number of distinguished gentlemen in the Anti-Slavery cause, and a somewhat unusual number of ladies. Indeed, the pitiless storm did not prevent on attendance of the gentler sex, comprising at least half the audience. The brass buttons of M.P.'s were visible all over the house, and reserved platoons were in readiness in adjoining rooms, prepared for any exigency. At precisely 8 o'clock, Mr. PHILLIPS entered, preceded by OLIVER JOHNSON and THEODORE TILTON. Mr. TILTON opened the proceedings by nominating for Chairman EDGAR KETCHUM,, Esq., who was unanimously chosen.

abstract: In the Senate yesterday, the credentials of Mr. SEMREP, received from Massachusetts, and Mr. WALL, just elected from New-Jersey for an unexpired term were presented. After some business  of no particular importance, the bill for the re  organization of the Court or Claims was taken up. The motion to lay it on the table was re
lead_paragraph: In the Senate yesterday, the credentials of Mr. SEMREP, received from Massachusetts, and Mr. WALL, just elected from New-Jersey for an unexpired term were presented. After some business of no particular importance, the bill for the re organization of the Court or Claims was taken up. The motion to lay it on the table was rejected Mr. G[???]MES' substitute repealing the original act establishing the Court was also rejected. A long [???] took place on the merits of the bill under consideration, in the course of which the subject of the payment of the soldiers was touched [???] -- Mr. WILSON, of Massachusetts, contending that Congress was in no way responsible fo[???] he failure to pay them. The Court of Claims [???] was finally passed, with the provision for two additional Judges stricken out. A resolution offered by Mr. HALE, declaring that CORNELIUS VANDERBILT, Commodore VAN BRUNT and CHAS. A. HASWELL, who fitted out the transports for the Banks Expedition, are guilty of negligence in the duty assigned them, and that the commission exerted by F.J. SOUTHARD was a violation of agreement, and should be refunded, was laid over, -- and the Senate adjourned.

abstract: The great activity and the general advance in prices in the produce market, noted in our last issue, has continued to be the marked features of the past week's trade. Prices rule steadily in favor of the seller, and the extraordinary rates required, have the effect, in many cases, of stopping transactions. Butter continues to be less affected by the general rise in prices than any other article in the produce market. However, the continued high rate of exchange, and limited concessions on the part of holders of fine grades of Butter, have induced exporters to resume their transactions, and a fair trade and much better feeling is the result. The business as for home trade is fairly active, and extra qualities for consumption are
