abstract: VICTORIA. -- Coroner RANNEY yesterday concluded the inquest on the body of MICHAEL CONROY, who died at the New-York Hospital on Tuesday, from the effects of injuries received on the evening of the 14th inst, on the ship Victoria, an account of which we published at the time. There were six witnesses examined, including the Captain of the vessel, all of whom concurred in the statement that the colored cook, named HENEY VAN VALKENBURGH, was the person who inflicted the stabs which resulted in the death  of the deceased. They did not sit see the wounds inflicted, but immediately after the affray they heard the victim say that VAN VALKENBURGH was the man. When the latter was pointed out to the witness, he ran from the vessel to the dock, and then ran back to the vessel, and suddenly jumped into the water; since which time the offender has not been seen. It is believed that ha was drowned. The jury rendered a verdict "that the deceased, MICHAEL CONROY, came to his death by a stab with a knife in the hands of HENEY VAN VALKENBRUGH."

abstract: Cochin's Augustin; Results of Emancipation
snippet: Cochin's Augustin; Results of Emancipation
lead_paragraph: -- WALKER, WISE & CO., Book Publishers of Boston, have done humanity and civilization a service in republishing the Frenchman, AUGUSTIN COCHIN'S work on the Results of Emancipation. What GUIZOT accomplished in his History of Civilization, and DE TOCQUEVILLE in his Democracy in America, M. COCHIN has aimed to accomplish in the work under consideration. He has studied the history of African Slavery in all civilized countries, in connection with the efforts of the past fifty years to abolish it; and from the mixed results that have been obtained, vindicated the general principle that progress -- progress for both races, for the white race as well as the black -- has been the invariable result.

abstract: Gen. WOOL, the veteran and respected Commandant of the Department of the East, is busily engaged, with his Staff, in fulfilling the orders of his commission from the Government, and so assiduously does he apply himself to his onerous duties, that from 10 o'clock in the morning until 5 in the afternoon, he seldom is found absent from his office. From the hour at which he commences work until the afternoon his office is crowded with those officers and soldiers, in compliance with the strict injunctions of the orders which he has issued in respect to their absence from their posts of duty. When these appear before him he enters into a minute examination of their separate cases, and evinces the greatest anxiety in regard to the reasons why they have absented themselves from their duties in the field. This is particularly observable in the case of deserters, whom he treats with much sympathy, yet firmly states to them that there is only one alternative left to them, namely, to make immediate preparation for joining their different regiments, or abide the consequences.

After an Executive Session, the Senate adjourned.

abstract: Commerce of 1862; Commerce of 1862
snippet: Commerce of 1862; Commerce of 1862
lead_paragraph: Nearly two years of war have passed over our country, and though our own City has been far removed from the scenes of actual conflict, and the din of arms has not sounded in our ears, yet the effects of the war have been visible on every side, and in every business. New-York,the great financial centre of the Union, has been sensitive to every victory and every defeat. Not only has this City sent its thousands upon thousands to the seat of war, but it has furnished a great portion of the money necessary to maintain the army and navy, and to render both efficient. Upon the prosperity of this City, then, much has been dependent.

abstract: Iron-clads, the Seaworthiness of
snippet: Iron-clads, the Seaworthiness of
lead_paragraph: A good many naval problems have been solved off Cape Hatteras. It would be difficult to exaggerate the importance of the few hours of tempest there, when the Monitor went down, with reference to the whole subject of naval defences. The Monitor indeed went down, and settled alongside the Central America and the other weak vessels that have nestled snugly on that sea-bottom since coasting began, and from similar causes; but the Passaic and the rest rode out the storm, although their decks were but eighteen inches out of water. High sides, then, are not a necessary feature of a seaworthy vessel. A great billow did not roll over them from stem to stern and swallow them up at a gulp. So long as the welts and rivets of her hu[???] held on, the cabin of the Monitor even was as dry as the saloon of the Adriatic. At the first tidings of her loss, there were most gloomy apprehensions. The last hope of constructing a vessel that would carry armor thick enough, because small in area, to stand modern ordnance, was slender. But when it turned out that the Monitor only leaked full from weakness, instead of being simply swallowed up in the trough of the sea, patriotic regret at her loss was more than compensated by professional satisfaction at her design.

abstract: The speech of WENDELL PHILLIPS, last night, was after the style and matter of all the speeches he has delivered for the last quarter of a century. Most of it is very familiar to those who have listened to or read any of his previous orations. His forte is still, as of old, denunciation and dissatisfaction. Nothing pleased him, and nothing ever will. Still, notwithstanding rain and mud, an immense audience came and listened to him, and rent the house with acclamations at each of his well-worn, well-polished periods.

abstract: Discipline and punishments of the
snippet: Discipline and punishments of the
lead_paragraph: -- One of our cor respondents, writing on Monday from the headquarters of the left wing of the Army of the Potomac, sends us a number of the sentences passed by Court-martial upon offenders -- which indicate the existence of a just and severe system of discipline in some of the army corps. One private soldier, "for misbehavior before the enemy," was sentenced to forfeit all pay due him, except just dues to his laundress (that is proper) and sutler, and all pay that may become due him during his term of service, and to be confined at hard labor. A like sentence was passed upon another man "for offering violence to his superior officer." A corporal, "for absenting himself from his company and regiment before the enemy at Fredericksburgh," was reduced to the grade of private, forfeited all pay due or that may become due, and was condemned to serve the balance of his term at hard labor. A man for "skulking during the battle of Fredericksburgh" was condemned to march before his regiment, having a board lashed to his back with the word "Coward" on it, and to be put to hard labor, with ball and chain attached to his leg.

abstract: In the Senate yesterday, a petition was presented, asking relief for the widow of THOMAS GREGG, the original inventor of iron-clad vessels. A joint resolution was introduced, directing the Secretary of the Navy not to accept the title to
lead_paragraph: In the Senate yesterday, a petition was presented, asking relief for the widow of THOMAS GREGG, the original inventor of iron-clad vessels. A joint resolution was introduced, directing the Secretary of the Navy not to accept the title to League Island until Congress shall so direct. Two daughters of the late Commodore RENSHAW, and two sisters of the late Commander WAINWRIGHT, both killed at Galveston, sent in petitions asking for pensions. The Military Committee was instructed to inquire into the expediency of publishing monthly the names of all officers of the army who are absent on leave, with the date of the leave of absence, &c. The proposition to annul the treaties with the Sioux Indians was debated at some length, and then postponed until to-day. The bill to reimburse the State of Minnesota, for expenses incurred in defending the State against Indian outrages, was passed. Mr. WILSON's bill to provide for the greater comfort of sick and wounded soldiers was taken up and debated, but not disposed of. After an Executive Session, the Senate adjourned.

abstract: There seems to be no longer any reason to doubt that the Army of the Potomac, or at least a portion of it, has once more crossed the Rappahannock, prepared to make another effort to defeat the main rebel army in Virginia. We have
lead_paragraph: There seems to be no longer any reason to doubt that the Army of the Potomac, or at least a portion of it, has once more crossed the Rappahannock, prepared to make another effort to defeat the main rebel army in Virginia. We have very direct confirmation of this fact, both from our Special Correspondent, who announces the movement of the Army, writing on Thursday, and from the rebels themselves -- advices from Richmond to the 20th having reached us, embodying positive statements that a portion of our army had then already crossed, both above and below Fredericksburgh. The rumors of fighting which have reached us from Washington may be premature, but we shall no doubt soon receive details of another great struggle on the Rappanannock. A still further assurance of this may be found in the Address of Gen. BURNSIDE to his Army, published among our dispatches. It is dated the 20th (Tuesday), and announces in positive terms that another movement against the enemy was about to commence. The crossing probably took place on Wednesday, above Fredericksburgh, a simultaneous movement being made below as a feint, which, however, would be turned into a real attack, should circumstances justify it. It is possible, also, that a crossing might be again made at the City.

abstract: West Point Graduates and the Gen. Porter Court-Martial; the Court-Martial Decision on
snippet: West Point Graduates and the Gen. Porter Court-Martial; the Court-Martial Decision on
lead_paragraph: --If it be asked, how does the dismissal of Gen. FITZ-JOHN PORTER bear upon the question of the loyalty of the West Point graduates the obvious answer is, that the Court-martial was composed of nine Generals, and of these, seven, all but two, were West Point graduates. These seven are Gens. Hunter, Hitchcock, Rufus King, Ricketts, Casey, Buford and Morris -- with one exception, all veterans of the Regular Army. Brig.-Gen. ROBERTS, the Inspector-General of POPE's army, and the prosecutor, is a West Point graduate. Col. HOLT, the Judge-Advocate, is not a graduate.

lead_paragraph: James S. Carpentier vs. Peter Chrystal. -- The plaintiff is a lawyer, and was formerly a partner with the late David Graham. In his complaint he describes the defendant thus "At the time (1845) of the formation of the copartnership (between Graham and Carpentier) Peter Chrystal was a client of said Graham, and had retained and employed the said David Graham, to defend him (Chrystal) upon two charges of felony then pending against him, upon which indictments were about that time duly found in the Court of General Sessions, and were, upon the motion of David Graham, removed into the Court of Oyer and Terminer for trial."

abstract: There was much anxiety felt in naval circles in this City, yesterday, to bear from the iron-clads Nahant and Weehawken, which left here on Sunday. The suspense was relieved by the receipt of a [???] from Capt. RODGERS of the Weehawken, informing of his safe arrival. From information received from another source, it is probable that the Naval and Lack[???]nne have sheltered themselves behind the Delaware Breakwater. It will be seen that the Weehawken proved her seaworthiness by successfully weathering one of the severest gales on record. The importance of this experience is inestimable, and the thanks of the country are due to Capt. RODGERS for having overcome the prejudices of the sailors, and for having the courage thus to test the only matter which remained to be proved -- the seagoing qualities of our Monitors. Verily, this is an important event, and its influence on our foreign relations cannot but be beneficial.

abstract: The  THE PERY COMPANY AND GEN. POPE The public were greatly surprised yesterday to learn the decision of the Court in the case of Major-Gen. PITZ-JOHN PORTER. It was univer
lead_paragraph: The THE PERY COMPANY AND GEN. POPE The public were greatly surprised yesterday to learn the decision of the Court in the case of Major-Gen. PITZ-JOHN PORTER. It was universally anticipated that he would be acquitted of the charges made against him by Gen. POPE -- an anticipation probably based, in great measure, upon the [???]sion that it was impossible to have any high officer of the army convicted and punished for any military offence whatever. Yet we think no one can have read carefully and [???]y, the evidence given on the trial, which we have published very fully, without being convinced of the justice of the sentence he has received, in being cashiered and dismissed the service for disobedience of orders. PORTER was not disloyal in any sense of consciously aiding or abetting the treason of JEFF. DAVIS -- and he was not on trial on any such charge -- but, in the wide and deep significance of the word loyalty which implies faithfulness, truth and devotion to a superior -- which superior in this case happened to be Gen. POPE -- we think nothing can be clearer proven than that he was disloyal. It was not only in one nor in two instances that he effended, but he evaded, disregarded or disobeyed almost every one of the orders he received while acting under Gen. POPE. To attempt to assign as an excuse for his disobedience any motive whatever is preposterous; in a military and patriotic sense, his motives were necessarily bad. We are glad that in the first case in which an officer's culpability has been proven, punishment has followed; and we are rejoiced that the President has had courage to approve the sentence.

abstract: One of the most sinister portents of the ethics is the advent of bullyism into the precincts of legislation. It has, as yet, shown itself most at Albany; but it is unmistakably
lead_paragraph: One of the most sinister portents of the ethics is the advent of bullyism into the precincts of legislation. It has, as yet, shown itself most at Albany; but it is unmistakably present also at Harrisburgh and Trenton. Its aim is to overawe and intimidate. If allowed to proceed as it has begun, it will, in all likelihood, end in the destruction of all regular legislation; perhaps, in the dispersion of the Legislatures [???] selves.

abstract: The news, and the absence of news, from the Army of the Potomac, for the last few days, have been rather exciting. It has been so much the custom of the Government to withhold intelligence from the people when it was of a kind calculated to unduly affect their
lead_paragraph: The news, and the absence of news, from the Army of the Potomac, for the last few days, have been rather exciting. It has been so much the custom of the Government to withhold intelligence from the people when it was of a kind calculated to unduly affect their nerves, that the embargo on the telegraph from Falmouth and Washington has been taken as a pretty sure indication that a battle was going on, and by the croakers that we had met with a disaster.

lead_paragraph: The Cooper Union for the Advancement of Science and Art, the design and object of which are, as most of our readers know well, the dissemination of useful knowledge among the working classes, is in a more flourishing condition to-day than ever before. The splendid edifice was erected and supplied with all the apparatus and appliances requisite for such a purpose by the munificence of PETER COOPER. The building is one among the principal architectural ornaments of this City; and as an educational institution, it is unequaled in it somewhat peculiar sphere. Until Mr. COOPER completed and dedicated this, the greatest and best enterprise of his life, to the objects named, it was rare that those of limited means, however anxious they might be to acquire a knowledge of some of the higher branches of education, could obtain tuition in studies not named in the regular course taught in our public schools. Since the opening of this institute all who desire, and particularly those who work for their own support, can avail themselves, free of charge, of all the advantages the institution affords. Those only are supposed to pay anything who are abundantly able, or prefer to do so. For those who can attend during the day there are teachers there to form them into classes, and teach them. For those who work during the day there are evening classes, and the teaching them is as extensive and thorough as the other.

abstract: A lamentable accident occured on the Hoboken and Newark Railroad at a few minutes past 6 o'clock this morning, by which three persons lost their lives and two others were seriously injured. The first morning train on that road leaves Newark
lead_paragraph: A lamentable accident occured on the Hoboken and Newark Railroad at a few minutes past 6 o'clock this morning, by which three persons lost their lives and two others were seriously injured. The first morning train on that road leaves Newark at 6 o'clock, and usually arrives in Hoboken at 18 minutes past 6. At a little more than half the distance from Newark to Hoboken the road passes over a bridge spanning the Hackensack River. This bridge has a draw which is always left open during the night to allow vessels to pass, but is required to be closed early in the morning, before the train from Newark comes along, unless a vessel should be passing at the time, in which case a signal is required to be displayed, as a warning for the train to stop. Whether that signal was so displayed when the train came along this morning is a question in dispute, and will probably be a subject of investigation at the proper time. If it was displayed, it was unfortunately not seen by the engineer in time to stop the train, and the result was that the engine and tender, together with the baggage and smoking car, were precipitated through the draw into the river. There was only one passenger-car in the train, and this, fortunately, escaped. It was but a hairbreadth escape, however; for the car was propelled to the very brink of the gulf, and now stands upon the bridge, with its forward end projecting some feet over the draw. Teere were some ten or twelve passengers in the car at the time, all of whom escaped injury. The persons who were killed, were the engineer, whose name was JACOB A. WOODRUFF, and who is supposed to have remained at his post and gone down with his engine, and two passengers, whose names are unknown. Although the tide was low at the time, yet such was the impetus, that the engine and tender were completely buried out of sight in the bed of the river. The passengers who lost their lives were in the smoking-car at the time, together with the conductor and a boy, who escaped. The conductor, however, whose name is WM. H. HAVENS, was thrown into the water, where he remained some time, and is considerably injured. The fireman, also, saved his life by jumping from the falling wreck, although he landed in the water and was considerably injured. The passengers who were lost, the conductor says, were laborers going to their work at the long dock of the Erie Railroad. Neither of their bodies nor that of the engineer has yet been recovered. The passengers say that after the accident occurred, the man who attends the drawbridge came out of his house near by with nothing on but his pants and shirt, and with the appearance of having just got out of bed. They are of the opinion that he neglected to display the signal, although he says that it was up, and when the passengers' attention was called to it they found it properly displayed. They think, however, that the signal was raised during the excitement and confusion after the accident, in order to make it appear all right for the bridge-tender. The passengers agree in saying that the whistle blew and the brakes were put on before the train reached the bridge, but not in time to prevent the accident. The engineer whose business it was to look out for the signal, having lost his life, cannot of course give his evidence as to whether it was displayed or not; but whatever may have been the facts, the accident teaches a lesson which should have been sufficiently learned from the great Norwalk accident, (which was precisely similar to this,) and that is, that the lives of scores of passengers should not be made to hang on the chances of an engineer seeing a given signal, or the chance of a signal man attending to his business, but every train should be compelled by law to come to a dead stand at every draw-bridge, whether the signal be up or down. This is the preventive that has been applied on the Eastern roads since the Norwalk accident, and it has proved effectual and satisfactory to the public.

abstract: MICHAEL LALLY, a deserter from the rebel army, has just reached New-Bedford, Mass, He formerly resided in Fall River, but about six years since went to Charleston, S.C., where he lived at the breaking out of the rebellion. Of course he was at once forced into the rebel service, and, according to his account, has well earned all that the rebels paid him. He was in both battles of Bull Run, with JACKSON ...
lead_paragraph: -- MICHAEL LALLY, a deserter from the rebel army, has just reached New-Bedford, Mass, He formerly resided in Fall River, but about six years since went to Charleston, S.C., where he lived at the breaking out of the rebellion. Of course he was at once forced into the rebel service, and, according to his account, has well earned all that the rebels paid him. He was in both battles of Bull Run, with JACKSON when he drove BANKS to the Potomoc, fought withFREMONT and ran away from SHIELDS, took his part in the seven days' fighting before Richmond, was at the capture of Harper's Ferry, and wound up his career as a Confederate soldier at Fredericksburgh, when he quietly crossed the river and made for the North star. He says, until within three months the rebel troops have been regularly paid, and that there has been no lack of provisions. Shoes were scarce. He speaks well of JACKNON, as a bold man, careful of his men, but despising danger himself, saying always that God would take care of him. LALLY is a bright, active fellow, quick witted and ready for work.

abstract: the Necessity for a
snippet: the Necessity for a
lead_paragraph: -- The establishment of an efficient Bureau of Statistics, on a plan similar to that which the Secretary of the Interior recommended to Congress a few days ago, is a National necessity. Involving no additional expense whatever to the Government, it would confer on the most vital interests of the country benefits which might be cheaply purchased at the cost of millions of dollars. Every nation in Europe with any pretensions to commercial importance, has its Statistical Bureau. The monthly reports of the Board of Trade possess a value which no consideration would induce Great Britain to be without. Moreover, it is a circumstance not a little remarkable, that the time when this English Bureau of Statistics was established, marks exactly the turning point in the course of British opulence and industrial ascendency. From the moment when Mr. BULL began to set his house in order and to look into his monthly accounts -- both the Government and the people noting the ebb or rise of National prosperity -- a new impulse was given to progress, fiscal errors were brought to light, exhaustless productive forces were unchained, labor and wealth developed each other, and a prodigious capital has been annually heaped up which is the wonder of the age.

abstract: It did not take long for the House to clear away the rubbish which had accumulated during the past week and get to a vote for Speaker. The Democrats were hopeful, on account of various circumstances. The Unionists reserved all opinion. One hundred and twenty-four members responded to the calling of the roll, and then, with no thought of fillibustering, went straight to a vote for Speaker.

lead_paragraph: There is flinching in New-Jersey. The Democratic majority in the Legislature cannot all yet "screw their courage up to the sticking-place." Instead of referring the BrooksWood armistice-and-peace resolutions to a favorable Select Committee, as was expected, the most they could bring themselves to do was to hand them over to the Standing Committee on Federal Relations, who, it is supposed, will quietly put them on the shelf, there to remain until a fitter opportunity.

lead_paragraph: The trial of JOEL B. FERGUSON, for false pretences is obtaining $1,000 from ELIZABETH CARTER, was continued in this Court yesterday. A large number of spectators, including a good share of the members of Bedford-street Church, were in attendance. Mr. HULL, one of the counsel for the defence, said he desired to ask a few questions of the last witness for the prosecution, Mr. JAMES H. ROOME. Mr. ROOME was accordingly recalled to the stand and questioned at length with regard to the statements made by Mr. FERGUSON at the hearing before the Church Committee, all of which may be omitted in this report, as the prosecution offered to admit all the testimony alleged to have been given by the defendant before that Committee, not as true, but as having been his statements at that time. In answer to a question, the witness disavowed the inference that defendant's counsel drew from one of his statements made the day before, that Rev. J.P. NEWMAN counseled or advised a criminal prosecution in this case. He said the reverend gentleman was not instrumental in any way, by advice or otherwise, in bringing this case before the Court.

abstract: Escape from Rebeldom
snippet: Escape from Rebeldom
lead_paragraph: The people of New-York, as well as, to some extent, of the whole country, will remember Dr. JAS. W. REDFIELD, formerly of this City, most widely known by his works on physiognomy, his special science. Dr. REDFIELD having quietly disappeared from our midst some years ago, many of those who had known him were wondering what had become of him, when a few days since he made his appearance in this City, a refugee from the South. His story, as the experience of an intellectual and educated man, possesses a peculiar interest among the many of a like nature that have come to our ears.

abstract: GEN. THUMB AND HIS PROGRESS. We learn today that an unexpected hitch has occurred in the arrangements for the wedding between TOM THUMB and LAVINIA WARREN. Rev. MORGAN DIX, the Rector of Trinity Parish, has forbidden the opening of the church or any of its chapels. Th reason of this prohibition probably arises from the fact of the necessary restrictions for admission.
lead_paragraph: GEN. THUMB AND HIS PROGRESS. We learn today that an unexpected hitch has occurred in the arrangements for the wedding between TOM THUMB and LAVINIA WARREN. Rev. MORGAN DIX, the Rector of Trinity Parish, has forbidden the opening of the church or any of its chapels. Th reason of this prohibition probably arises from the fact of the necessary restrictions for admission. Every service recorded in the Prayer-book is, of necessity, a public service, and, according to the rules of the church, is open and free to all who may choose to attend. It is possible also that the edict about appearing in evening dress at the chapel has something to do with the refusal, as there is no provision in the Prayer-book rendering such an apparel essential to attendance on any of the church services. Fortunately, there are other churches besides those of Trinity Parish, and the wedding will come off with all the expected brilliancy. Immediately thereafter the party will adjourn to the Metropolitan Hotel, of which they have engaged the entire first floor, where a grand reception will be held. We understand that a serenade will be tendered the bridal pair, and that the gay and festive bridegroom will appear upon the balcony and make an acknowledging speech. Last night Gen. THUMB, Miss WAREEN and Commodore NUTT were the guests of Mrs. AUGUST BELMONT, on Fifth-avenue.

abstract: A dispatch from headquarters of the army of the Potomac informs us that "the tempestuous weather since Tuesday last, and the consequent impassable state of the roads, have rendered any advance of the army beyond the Rappahannock a matter of utter impossibility. The same causes so delayed the transportation of the pontoons and...
lead_paragraph: A dispatch from headquarters of the army of the Potomac informs us that "the tempestuous weather since Tuesday last, and the consequent impassable state of the roads, have rendered any advance of the army beyond the Rappahannock a matter of utter impossibility. The same causes so delayed the transportation of the pontoons and heavy artillery to the designated points as to prevent a surprise of the enemy at the point designed to cross." We learn from our Washington correspondent, in addition to the above, that the Quartermaster's Department, as usual, was behind with its supplies. The delay, however, can only be temporary, and we may expect the contemplated movement to be executed the moment the roads and the Quartermaster will permit.

abstract: THE NEW COURT-HOUSE AND OTHER IMPROVEMENTS. The new Kings County Court-house is very slowly but steadily progressing toward completion. The work on the front, facing the City Hall, appears to have been suspended, but operations are going on in the rear, in the construction of that portion of the
lead_paragraph: THE NEW COURT-HOUSE AND OTHER IMPROVEMENTS. -- The new Kings County Court-house is very slowly but steadily progressing toward completion. The work on the front, facing the City Hall, appears to have been suspended, but operations are going on in the rear, in the construction of that portion of the edifice fronting Livingston-street. The walls are now up the full height, and the frame-work for the roof has been nearly all placed in position. If the weather continues favorable during the Winter, the building on the Livingston-street side will be ready for occupation in the Spring or early in the Summer. It is to be occupied by the Board of Supervisors, Superintendents of the Poor, and other County officials. The front and centre buildings are mainly intended for the Courts, the District Attorney, Register, and County Clerk. From present appearances, another year elapse before that portion will be ready for use.

abstract: The question of making military instruction a part of the regular course in the pubic schools of this City, is now before the Board of Education, and will probably be considered by the Commissioners at their neat meeting. Even before the breaking out of the present war, the same question had been mooted, but there was not any action of consequence on the subject, until after the attack upon Fort
lead_paragraph: The question of making military instruction a part of the regular course in the public schools of this City, is now before the Board of Education, and will probably be considered by the Commissioners at their next meeting. Even before the breaking out of the present war, the same question had been mooted, but there was not any action of consequence on the subject, until after the attack upon Fort Sumter. Then the military spirit broke out in the schools, as it did everywhere else, and juvenile military companies, formed from the schools, were seen on the street every day. The drill, however, and other necessary preparations for parade, were attended to after school hours, and outside the school-rooms. In the larger schools the teachers soon saw the advantages of such military drill in the management of the male departments, and it was not long before the boys were drilled in marching, countermarching, right face, left face, and such other manoeuvres as tended to their more orderly movement from one class-room to another; and now the drill, so far as marching in military order goes, is practiced in nearly every public school in the City. In nearly all the female and primary departments and schools, calisthenics, to a greater or less extent, have been introduced as a daily exercise. The military drills and evolutions are confined principally to the boys' departments of the grammar schools. These exercises are looked upon with great favor by the Superintendent, who believes that no better mode could be adopted by which that physical bravery which is indispensable to health, both of body and mind, be combined with a spirit of patriotism, and the duty which, in a crisis like the present, devolves upon every young man, of preparing himself adequately and thoroughly for defending his country against foreign or domestic foes. Among the schools in which the marching drill has been particularly attended to are: No. 49, Thirty-seventn-street. near Second-avenue; No. 44, corner of North Moore and Varick streets; No. 45, Twenty-fourth-street, between Seventh and Eighth avenues: No. 35, Mr. THOMAS HUNTER, Principal, in Thirteenth-street, near Sixth-avenue: No. 32, T.D. MARTIN, Principal, Thirty-fifth-street, near Ninth-avenue No. 17, JAMES MONTRETH, Principal, Forty-seventh-street, between Eighth and Ninth avenues; No. 14,Twenty-seventh-street, near Third-avenue; No. 11, Seventeenth-street, near Eighth-avenue, and No. 10, Wooster-street, near Bleecker. But, as has been said, in nearly all of them some attention is given to the marching drill. In several, there are teachers who have been connected with the City militia, and through their knowledge of military movements thus obtained, the pupils have arrived at greater proficiency than in other schools in which there are no teachers who have had a military training themselves. In school No. 10, there is a very fine little military company, which has been taught by Mr. HANNIDAL ROBINSON, a teacher there, who was a soldier in the Mexican war. This class understands and practices not only the marching drill, but also the manual of arms. Should the Board of Education decide in favor of placing military instruction in the regular course of studies, we shall soon have a large and interesting army of little warriors in this City alone. The whole number taught in the Ward Schools, when the last annual report was made up, was 119, 932, and in the Primary Schools 32,352; which, including the Corporate schools, gives a grand total of 162,503. Should military instruction be confined to the boys in the Grammar departments entirely, we would even then have an army of about, if not quite, 30,000 growing up in our midst, which, in a very few years, in case of invasion, or of another rebellion, could march out disciplined and ready to defend the land of Common Schools against all comers.

abstract: Throwing Away Fruits of Blunt's and Herron's Victories
snippet: Throwing Away Fruits of Blunt's and Herron's Victories
lead_paragraph: -- The operations of the little army under Gens. BLUNT and HEItRON in Western Arkansas, in December last their marches, their battles, and their stupendous achievements, were the wonder of the whose country. We supposed that that at least was an army that would never disappoint the country. But just after these two officers had given HINDMAN the most tremendous whipping at Prairie Grove -- after their troops had marched from Fayetteville across the Boston Mountains to Van Buren, had captured that place, and, gazing across the Arkansas River, had caught a glimpse of the routed rebels flying as fast as their legs could carry them toward Arkadelphia -- after BLUNT and HERRON had captured steamboats, transports and abundant supplies, and found plenty of forage -- after the way was open and clear to Little Rock, and the complete occupation of Arkansas -Gen. SCOFIELD, who ranked both BLUNT and HERRON, arrived on the field, took command of the army, stopped its progress, and planted it on the banks of the Arkansas River. It has not been heard of since. Gen. SCOFIELD was sick at St. Louis while the irrepressible BLUNT was performing his exploits. We fear the journey to Van Buren brought him down again. We fear he is sick -- as some imagine the country to be -- of West Point. Of that trouble BLUNT was altogether free. SCOFIELD, however, has succeeded in throwing away the fruits of the border-fighters' victories. As the latter performed such wonders while in command, we do not see why he was not allowed to finish his work.

abstract: Condition and Prospects of
snippet: Condition and Prospects of
lead_paragraph: Now that the main army of the country, according to the words of its Commanding General, "is about to meet the enemy once more," the anxious thought of every man is, what is the prospect? What is the real strength of our army? what is its condition? what its spirit? Where is it likely to meet the foe, and how will it confront him? Will BURNSIDE try to outflank the rebel position, or will he make another assault direct upon their works, as he is known to hold the opinion that had his Generals assented to his proposition to renew the assault the day after his repulse on the 13th ult., he would have carried the heights behind Fredericksburgh? Other very important questions suggest themselves, such as, whether the military movements going on in North Carolina are intended to have any direct bearings upon BURNSIDE's campaign, and whether there is to be any movement in the rear of Richmond by a cooperating column? is the comprehensive plan with which the public were edified two months ago, of a simultaneous advance of military columns to Weldon, to Petersburgh, and up the Peninsula, aided by iron-clads on the James and the York, as outlying supports to BURNSIDE's movement, to be now actually carried out? or are the heavy bodies of troops we have at Newbern, at Suffolk, and on the Peninsula, together with the Monitors, of which we have for a long time had so many hopes and enjoyed so few performances, to be kept paltering and playing where they are of no earthly use to us, and no damage to the rebels?

abstract: In the Senate yesterday, some vacancies in the Standing Committees were filled. The bill to provide for printing the annual report of the Banks of the United States, was passed. A resolution was adopted instructing the Military Committee to inquire into the condition of the soldiers in the convalescent camps.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate yesterday, some vacancies in the Standing Committees were filled. The bill to provide for printing the annual report of the Banks of the United States, was passed. A resolution was adopted instructing the Military Committee to inquire into the condition of the soldiers in the convalescent camps. The Secretary of War was asked to inform the Senate whether any more Major and Brigadier Generals have been appointed and paid than authorized by law. The Secretary of the Treasury was called upon for information regarding the amount of revenue from the duty on printing paper, and whether the reduction of the duty would tend to increase the public revenue. A resolution was offered by Mr. WILSON, of Massachusetts, instructing the Committee on the Conduct of the War to inquire whether any plans of Gen. BURNSIDE for the movement of the Army of the Potomac have been interfered with in consequence of the representations of subordinates. At Mr. WILSON's request the resolution was laid over. The joint resolution for the relief of the holders of the FLOYD acceptances was discussed until the expiration of the morning hour. The Secretary of War sent in a list of Major and Brigadier-Generals in the service, which was ordered to he printed. The President sent in the report and correspondence concerning the exportation of arms for the use of the French army in Mexico. It was ordered to be printed. The bill to provide for the greater comfort of sick and wounded soldiers was passed, after being materially amended. The bill to provide for an increase of the clerical force in the Quartermaster General's office, was debated until the adjournment.

abstract: The expose of the shameful manner in which the bodies buried under the old Sullivan-street Church were being removed, (which appeared exclusively in the TIMES of Monday last,) has created an excitement in this community unsurpassed in the annals of local intelligence. Tne purchase of church
lead_paragraph: The expose of the shameful manner in which the bodies buried under the old Sullivan-street Church were being removed, (which appeared exclusively in the TIMES of Monday last,) has created an excitement in this community unsurpassed in the annals of local intelligence. Tne purchase of church property in this City hereafter will be suspiciously regarded as a cemetery investment, and additional clauses will be demanded in the deeds conveying such property, to the effect that there are no human remains lying beneath the buildings, or buried in the lands sought to be conveyed, or that, if there be any such, they will be removed at the expense of the vendors and not of the purchaser. Already this idea is being acted on in a case which has come to our knowledge, only that, in this instance, the purchaser will be put to the expense of removal, in case he does not contest the terms of the contract of purchase. It will be recollected that in the disastrous conflagration in November last, in the vicinity of Greene and Houston streets, the Associate Presbyterian Church which stood on the southwest corner of those streets was burned, leaving only the walls remaining. Although the neighborhood is one which presents a most extensive field for religious labors, (the majority of the residents being very far from practicing angelic virtues,) the congregation decided not to rebuild the edifice, but sold the property to Mr. THOMAS STILLMAN, of No. 248 Greenwich-street. In the verbal terms of sale was a proviso that if any human remains should, on excavating, be found burled there, they were to be removed at Mr. STILLMAN's expense -- the idea conveyed to that gentleman being that there were but few, if any such, there. To this provision, understanding it as above mentioned, Mr. S. agreed. The expose of the Sullivan-street affair, however, set him to thinking whether he might not possibly have bound himself to perform rather a large job in the resurrection line, and investigation proved that there is an immense vault underneath the ruins, containing probably not less than twenty-five hundred corpses. To paying for the removal of these the purchaser demurs, alleging that the proviso in the terms of sale has been used to deceive him, and that if the vendors have not been guilty of an expressio falsi, they are at least chargeable with a suppressio veri -- that they were in a position to know of the existence of this vault and its contents, but failed to inform him of it.

abstract: BROOKLYN ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- Mr. LEONARD GROVER, of Grover's Theatre, Washington, D.C., has temporarily leased that chaste temple of the drama, the Academy of Music, for the purpose of bringing out thereat a series of exclusively moral dramas to suit the market. On Monday next, with an excellent company, of which Miss LUCILLE WESTERN is the star and principal attraction, he will present the "moral emotional drama" of "East Lynne." This occasion affords all classes of people in the City of Churches an opportunity of beholding a good play, of receiving a moral lesson, and of having a good time generally.

abstract: Morris and Essex Train thrown into Hackensack River; Golden City; Pacific Mail Steamship, Launch
snippet: Morris and Essex Train thrown into Hackensack River; Golden City; Pacific Mail Steamship, Launch
lead_paragraph: A lamentable accident occurred on the Hoboken and Newark Railroad at a few minutes past 6 o'clock yesterday morning, by which three persons lost their lives and two others were seriously injured. The first morning train on that road leaves Newark at 6 o'clock, and usually arrives in Hoboken at 18 minutes past 6. At a little more than half the distance from Newark to Hoboken the road passes over a bridge spanning the Hackensack River. This bridge has a draw which is always left open during the night to allow vessels to pass, but is required to be closed early in the morning, before the train from Newark comes along, unless a vessel should be passing at the time, in which case a signal is required to be displayed, as a warning for the train to stop. Whether that signal was so displayed when the train came along, yesterday, is a question in dispute, and will probably be a subject of investigation at the proper time. If it was displayed, it was unfortunately not seen by the engineer in time to stop the train, and the result was that the engine and tender, together with the baggage and smoking car, were precipitated through the draw into the river. There was only one passenger-car in the train, and this, fortunately, escaped. It was but a hairbreadth escape, however; for the car was propelled to the very brink of the gulf, and now stands upon the bridge, with its forward end projecting several feet over the draw. There were ten or twelve passengers in the car at the time, all of whom escaped injury. The persons who were killed, were the engineer, whose name is JACOB A. WOODRUFF, and who is supposed to have remained at his post and gone down with his engine, and two passengers, whose names are unknown. Although the tide was low at the time, yet such was the impetus, that the engine and tender were completely buried out of sight in the bed of the river. The passengers who lost their lives were in the smoking-car at the time, together with the conductor and a boy, who escaped. The conductor, however, whose name is WM.H. HAVENS, was thrown into the water, where he remained some time, and is considerably injured. The fireman, also, saved his life by jumping from the falling wreck, although he landed in the water and was considerably injured. The passengers who were lost, the conductor says, were laborers going to their work at the long dock of the Erie Railroad. Neither of their bodies nor that of the engineer has yet been recovered. The passengers say that after the accident occurred, the man who attends the draw-bridge came out of his house near by with nothing on but his pants and shirt, and with the appearance of having just got out of bed. They are of the opinion that he neglected to display the signal, although he says that it was up, and when the passengers' attention was called to it they found it properly displayed. They think, however, that the signal was raised during the excitement and confusion after the accident, in order to make it appear all right for the bridge-tender. The passengers agree in saying that the whistle blew and the brakes were put on before the train reached the bridge, but not in time to prevent the accident. The engineer whose business it was to look out for the signal, having lost his life, cannot of course give his evidence as to whether it was displayed or not; but whatever may have been the facts, the accident teaches a lesson which should have been sufficiently learned from the great Norwalk accident, (which was precisely similar to this,) and that is, that the lives of scores of passengers should not be made to hang on the chances of an engineer seeing a given signal, or the chance of a signal man attending to his business, but every train should be compelled by law to come to a dead stand at every draw-bridge, whether the signal be up or down. This is the preventive that has been applied on the Eastern roads since the Norwalk accident, and it has proved effectual and satisfactory to the public.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, a memorial from Dr. W.S.G. MORTON was presented, asking for compensation for the use of ether in the Army and Navy. A bill relating to jurors in the Courts of the United States was referred to the Judiciary Committee. A bill to establish the office of Register of Deeds for the District of Columbia was referred to the Committee on District Affairs. The resolution directing the Secretary of the Navy not to accept the title to League Island until Congress so directs, was passed. The Consular and Diplomatic Appropriation bill was reported from the Finance Committee. The Secretary of the Treasury was asked to communicate to the Senate any information he may have received from the Commissioners appointed for the District of South Carolina, under the act for the collection of direct taxes in insurrectionary States. The bill providing for increased clerical force in the Quartermaster-General's office was passed, after some amendment. A bill to establish the guage on the Pacific Railroad and its branches was referred to the Select Committee. The Senate then adjourned until Monday.

lead_paragraph: -- Mr. J.H.B. Latrobe, of Baltimore, has published a card explaining the circumstances of his recent visit to Fredericksburgh under a flag of truce. He says: "Private business taking me to the Rappahannock, I availed myself of the opportunity to try and see a son on Gen. Longstreet's staff, whom I believed to be in Fredericksburgh, and, accordingly, I accompanied a flag of truce with permits from both parties to cross the river. No preliminary conversation between the pickets took place. When the usual hail, on the exhibition of the flag was answered, I crossed with the boat, learned that my son was not at hand, and sent a message asking him to meet me the next day, not having left the boat or attempted to do so. On the morrow I returned to the river bank on this side, and, without crossing, received, by a flag, a note from the officer commanding the Confederate picket, saying that my son was in Richmond, and regretting, in polite terms, my disappointment. This is the whole story. I had no purpose of seeing Gen. Lee, nor was his name mentioned on the occasion."

abstract: A bill will soon be presented to Congress to constitute certain street railways, already built in Philadelphia, a military and post route, in order to enable the New-York and Washington trains to pass through the unaccommodating right-angled village without transhipping passengers or breaking bulk. This result was effected last Summer by ferrying the trains bodily across the Delaware; but the boat employed for that purpose is quite inadequate for Winter navigation. Indeed, transshipments by city cars occupies less time. A bill contemplating the same objects was defeated by the last Congress, on the ground that the existing monopoly would have too much power, and might, in virtue of the authority thus given, bridge the Delaware below Philadelphia and the Hudson at New-York. An equally satisfactory objection would have been that the convenience of travelers would be too greatly enhanced. What excuse Congress will next interpose, we cannot divine. In fact, the proposed law, instead of giving a valuable monopoly to the existing Companies, will impose upon them the cost of adapting the City tracks in question to long cars, for temporary use only, as they are already constructing a steam road around Philadelphia, to be completed within a year, thus leaving the Quaker City out in the cold, as far as through traffic is concerned. This new road branches from the Philadelphia and Baltimore at Gray's Ferry, a few miles below the former city, on the west side of the Schuylkill, and runs five miles to the Reading Railway, which already crosses the Schuylkill and connects with the Philadelphia and Trenton -- that is to say, the Camden and Amboy. The latter Company are about to still further shorten this detour by a straighter line, to meet the new branch of the Philadelphia and Baltimore. If Congress, then will grant the power asked, the public will, in a few weeks, be able to cross Philadelphia without changing seats -- which, we think, conveys a more striking idea than changing cars -- and without the risk of permanently aiding the present Companies, if that is any objection. Otherwise, the public will have to endure the present annoyance another year; and it may be that the Government and the country will suffer for the want of proper connection between the Metropolis and the Capital. While Congress is declining to act, in the fear that some corporation or other will be unduly benefited, the emergency will have subsided.
lead_paragraph: A bill will soon be presented to Congress to constitute certain street railways, already built in Philadelphia, a military and post route, in order to enable the New-York and Washington trains to pass through the unaccommodating right-angled village without transhipping passengers or breaking bulk. This result was effected last Summer by ferrying the trains bodily across the Delaware; but the boat employed for that purpose is quite inadequate for Winter navigation. Indeed, transshipments by city cars occupies less time. A bill contemplating the same objects was defeated by the last Congress, on the ground that the existing monopoly would have too much power, and might, in virtue of the authority thus given, bridge the Delaware below Philadelphia and the Hudson at New-York. An equally satisfactory objection would have been that the convenience of travelers would be too greatly enhanced. What excuse Congress will next interpose, we cannot divine. In fact, the proposed law, instead of giving a valuable monopoly to the existing Companies, will impose upon them the cost of adapting the City tracks in question to long cars, for temporary use only, as they are already constructing a steam road around Philadelphia, to be completed within a year, thus leaving the Quaker City out in the cold, as far as through traffic is concerned. This new road branches from the Philadelphia and Baltimore at Gray's Ferry, a few miles below the former city, on the west side of the Schuylkill, and runs five miles to the Reading Railway, which already crosses the Schuylkill and connects with the Philadelphia and Trenton -- that is to say, the Camden and Amboy. The latter Company are about to still further shorten this detour by a straighter line, to meet the new branch of the Philadelphia and Baltimore. If Congress, then will grant the power asked, the public will, in a few weeks, be able to cross Philadelphia without changing seats -- which, we think, conveys a more striking idea than changing cars -- and without the risk of permanently aiding the present Companies, if that is any objection. Otherwise, the public will have to endure the present annoyance another year; and it may be that the Government and the country will suffer for the want of proper connection between the Metropolis and the Capital. While Congress is declining to act, in the fear that some corporation or other will be unduly benefited, the emergency will have subsided.

abstract: The Assembly Chamber was again disgraced yesterday by unparliamentary and revolutionary proceedings on the part of the Democrats, led by Mr. FIELDS, of New-York, Mr. MURPHY, of Erie, and others prominent in the party, and assisted by their coa[???]ors in the lobby and in the galleries. The proceedings opened with a personal exploration from Mr. FIELDS, in answer to some just strictures [???] a New-York paper. The ninety-first ballot for Speaker was then taken, in which Mr. T[???] had 60 votes, Mr. CALLICOTT 60, and Mr. D[???]W [???] -- the member being absent. When the ninety-second ballot was commenced, the member before absent had returned, and cast his vote to, Mr. CALLICOT, thus insuring that ge[???] election should the ballot be consummated. A s[???]e of the greatest excitement ensued, [???] the old game of filibustering to prevent any further proceedings, was immediately commenced. At one point in the proceedings, the Clerk having left his position for a few minutes, the Democrats attempted to usurp the Speaker's chair for one of their number, but this was carrying the matter too far for the patience of the Republican and Union members, and their opposition came near leading to bloodshed. Finally the Clerk reappeared, and [???]ook his place, when the excitement gradually subsided, but not, it appears, before it was understood that an adequate police force had been called, and were at hand to enforce order. It was finally agreed to adjourn until Monday, at 11 o'clock A.M., at which time the vote is to be proceeded with without further opposition. There appears to be little doubt now that Mr. CALLICOTT will be elected.

abstract: The Discipline of
snippet: The Discipline of
lead_paragraph: One of our correspondents with the left wing of the Army of the Potomac, gave us, in a letter which we published on Friday last, some facts in reference to the more stringent discipline which has recently been put in force in that Grand Division, and cited some instances of severe punishment inflicted upon soldiers for misbehavior before the enemy, for absenteeism, for skulking and other military offences. Another correspondent, in a letter which we published yesterday, writing from the Grand Reserve Division of Gen. SIGEL, stated that during the last few weeks Courts-martial had been held in that command, and also cited some instances of the severe but just sentences which had been passed upon officers for various derelictions of duty. Among them was that of a Lieutenant-Colonel cashiered for drunkenness, and a captain cashiered "for cowardice and misbehavior before the enemy." The Commanding General, in confirming the proceedings, findings and sentence of the Court in the last-mentioned case, remarked: "The punishment is not too severe; the proper punishment for such conduct is death." In the other Grand Divisions of the Army of the Potomac we hear of similar proceedings. And we are inclined to think, from various indications, that the days of trifling and leniency with military offenders is past.

abstract: Greece and the Great Powers; Pay and Mail Robbers'
snippet: Greece and the Great Powers; Pay and Mail Robbers'
lead_paragraph: A recent Paris telegram announces that a conference of the representatives of the Great Powers is to be shortly held in London, in order to determine the conditions on which the Ionian Islands shall be ceded to Greece. Those islands, then, are not to be a free gift from England. Their cession is to be made dependent on the assent of the Greeks to certain terms, not yet formally promulgated. A quid pro quo is to be exacted for their surrender; and what the general nature of that quid will be, may be gathered from another telegram transmitted by the British Government, at an earlier date, to its Minister at Athens. This brief note intimates to the Hellenes the terms on which England is ready to hand over the Septinsular Republic to their little State. If the people adhere to a monarchical form of government, and choose a sovereign acceptable to England, England will be prepared to reward their docility by surrendering to them those coveted islands. But should the Greeks presume to abjure monarchy, or to elect a King who shall not find favor in British eyes, they must not expect any such surrender. These conditions are not creditable to England. They indicate a disposition to take an ungenerous advantage of the weakness and difficulties of Greece. They betray a desire to exact an exorbitant price for that which England should freely surrender. The Greeks have already given manifest proof of their predilection for monarchy -- of their partiality for the reigning house in England. But, since they cannot induce Prince ALFRED to reign over them, are they to forfeit all claim to British favor should they prefer a native ruler to another German, or a constitutional Republic to an alien despotism? Let England palter with her promise -- let her withhold the Ionian Isles from "living Greece" if she pleases; but let her not persist in tempting the Greeks to barter their rights as freemen for the acquisition in question. The country which first gave consistency to European civilization is surely not less worthy of having her privileges respected than her younger sister, Italy.

abstract: The steamer Die Vernon, from Memphis, brought up to-day a considerable number of the sick and wounded from the late battle-fields of Vicksburgh and Arkansas Post. Twenty of these died on the passage up from wounds, sickness and exhaustion. Among them were men belonging to the Eighty-third Indiana, Third Iowa and One Hundred and Eighth Illinois Regiments, one Lieutenant of the latter, besides five rebel soldiers.

abstract: MORE SOLDIERS PAY. -- Mr. MARCUS L. WARD, of Newark, yesterday afternoon received a large sum of money from the Seventh New-Jersey Regiment, the proceeds of their recent payment. The plan upon which Mr. WARD operates, in the delivery of money to the families of soldiers, and which originated with that philanthropic gentleman, is so simple, and at the same time, admirable, that we describe it for the benefit of other localities which are as yet destitute of any system of distribution. The plan is for the men, as soon as paid, to hand their money to the Chaplain of their respective regiments, taking a receipt for the same. A draft is then forwarded to Mr. WARD for the amount, the soldiers sending their receipts to their families, who present them to Mr. WARD, when they are duly honored. By this plan it is found that much less money is squandered by the soldiers than is customary, as a faithful Chaplain usually succeeds in persuading the men to forward nearly all their pay. Mr. WARD has received hundreds of thousands of dollars -- probably fifty thousand within the past week -- and not a dollar has been lost. The performance of the almost incredible labor of receiving, arranging and paying out this money, besides writing innumerable letters for soldiers wives and friends, all of which is performed by Mr. WARD without fee or reward, render his example one of the noblest with which genuine Christian philanthropy has ever blessed mankind. We think the plan adopted by Mr. WARD, if introduced everywhere, could not fall of the happiest results. It is true every community is not blessed with such a large-hearted friend of the soldier, to perform the labor gratuitously, yet even if some competent person had to be paid for doing it, it would be far better than the ordinary plan of the soldier simply forwarding his money, without any one to look after it. In the case we have described, not only the direct appeals of the Chaplain are effective, but the pride of the soldier, prompts him to be not behind his fellows in the amount he sends home.

abstract: Grant and McClernand soon to Move in Southwest
snippet: Grant and McClernand soon to Move in Southwest
lead_paragraph: Our three great armies in the Southwest that of ROSECRANS at Murfreesburo, that of GRANT at Memphis, and that of McCLERNAND, on the wing will soon, we have reason to believe, be again in motion and action. Gen. ROSECRANS has had a great deal of work to do during the three weeks that have elapsed since he defeated the army of Gen. BRAGG. He had communications to open and keep open, supplies to bring forward, and heavy preparations of various kinds to make, before he could again assume the offensive. Nearly all this work is now done. And we have the good news also in a definite shape that he has really received very large reinforcements. In the meantime the enemy is about the same distance away from him that they were when ROSECRANS moved against them from Nashville; they are at Shelbyville and Tullahoma, and it is supposed that their next place of battle will be on Duck River. We have had no confirmed of LONGSTREET's having reinforced them with eleven rebel brigades; but if he has, we suspect they will find that ROSECRANS, too, has at least eleven brigades more than he had when he drove them from their works at Murfreesboro. The threatening demonstrations which they made in the direction of the Tennessee River ten or twelve days ago, seem to have been nothing but guerrilla raids, and were not preliminary to any offensive movement, as some feared. Nothing, however, could suit ROSECRANS better than that they should assume the offensive. He could keep them out of Nashville with one quarter of his army, while with the remainder he would push on to Chattanooga, which is the real strategic centre of the whole country for hundreds of miles around, and which, if once in our possession, would put the entire game in all this part of the Southwest in our hands. ROSECRANS, however, can now anticipate no such good luck as this. He is quietly and cautiously preparing to move out from Murfreesboro; and he will probably do so as unexpectedly to the public as he left Nashville. ROSECRANS, as one of our correspondents remarked yesterday, is sending out no rumors of a grand advance, and giving the enemy no clue to his plans. But the rebels are none the less fearful of his appearance, and are probably trying to give the impression that they have received immense reinforcements, that they may thus delay as long as possible the evil day.

abstract: The Common Council Committee who went to Washington and Suffolk to procure the body of Adjt. CHARLES LATY, of the Fifty-second Regiment New-York Volunteers, who was killed at Fredericksburgh, to present a stand of colors to the Sicktes Brigade and to present a sword to Brig.-Gen. MICHAEL CORCORAN, returned from their mission yesterday. They went first to Washington, with the intention of going down the Potomac, but this design was frustrated, owing to the refusal to grant any more passes to Gen. BURNSIDE's army, which was understood to be in active preparation for a movement of some kind. The Secretary of War took charge of the colors for the Sickles Brigade till the Committee should return to take them, or give orders for their farther disposition.

snippet: Bethune, Dr. G. W.; Memoirs of Mrs. Joanna Bethune; Marsh, George P; Origin and History of English Language; Penny, Virginia; The Employments of Women; Brown, W. W.; The Black Man, his Antecedents, >amp;c.; Ellsworth's Text Book on Penmanship; Sza...
lead_paragraph: For this work, as for Mr. MARSH's former admirable treatise on the English language, we are indebted to the stimulus afforded by an invitation to deliver a course of public lectures. In the present instance, our obligation is to the Trustees of the Lowell Institute; in the former we had to thank the management of Columbia College. Though neither book is essential to the completeness of the other, the two form together a noble monument of comprehensive and thorough learning, of fine, scholarly taste, and of philosophic judgment. Of the two, the present course -- for the form of lectures is retained in the book -- is, perhaps, the more substantial and valuable. Treating of the language in its origin and literary history, rather than in its anatomical structure and grammatical development, it lays down general principles of great importance to scholars everywhere, at the same time that it puts us in possession of a far more judicious, integral and satisfactory view of the literature than was previously accessible.

abstract: We receive, by way of Havana, some additional news from Mexico, though nothing later from the Capital -- our former advices reaching to the 20th ult. Advices from Vera Cruz and other points, however, are to the 1st inst. Nothing of importance has occurred, the French awaiting reinforcements before advancing upon Puebla, toward which place they have progressed no further than Palmas. The expected reinforcements consist of two divisions of the Imperial Guard, and the entire effective force for attacking Puebla was expected to be only about 15,000 men. On the Mexican side the disposable force was much larger -- 25,000 regulars and 10,000 volunteers being in Puebla alone, while at other points were supposed to be in the neighborhood of 50,000 men. At Puebla ten forts have been constructed, mounting nearly 200 cannon, and the fortifications of the capital are on an equally extensive scale. A rumor prevailed in Havana at the date of our latest advices, that the French had advanced against Puebla, and had suffered another repulse. There is a possibility that the rumor is true.

abstract: Harbor, Defences of
snippet: Harbor, Defences of
lead_paragraph: When the question of the undefended condition of our City first became matter of anxiety, application for aid was made to the Government at Washington. The response was prompt and easily understood. New-York must take care of her own defences, and at some fitting time the Government will look at the question of reimbursement. The aid of the State was next invoked. Gov. MORGAN did not hesitate to submit the question to the Legislature, and recommend adequate measures of protection. No result has yet followed his recommendations. The Common Council moved next in the matter, and an appropriation of a million dollars was proposed by the Mayor, and, we believe, finally, after months of delay, passed into an ordinance. Action ceased in that quarter with the adoption of the measure proposed. The Chamber of Commerce then moved, upon the question. Resolutions were passed, speeches made, committees appointed, and there rested the efforts of the merchants. The National War Committee next took up the subject, and soon exhausted its energies without attaining any result.

abstract: The Sanitary Commission steamer Sir William Wallace arrived from Memphis early this morning, having left the latter place on Sunday. The strong current in the river protracted her passage to about sixty hours. She comes up for sanitary supplies, bringing nothing except about a hundred bales of cotton on freight. The troops of Gen. GRANT are moving below as fast as transports can be provided for them. Their destination is unknown.

abstract: The prosperity of the various places of amusement is so marked and extraordinary, that there are but few changes of importance to record in the bulletins for to-night. At Wallack's Theatre the craving for revivals of old pieces seems to be insatiable, and Mr. WALLACK wisely surrenders hinself to a necessity that brings in so much and costs so little. His ...
lead_paragraph: The prosperity of the various places of amusement is so marked and extraordinary, that there are but few changes of importance to record in the bulletins for to-night. At Wallack's Theatre the craving for revivals of old pieces seems to be insatiable, and Mr. WALLACK wisely surrenders hinself to a necessity that brings in so much and costs so little. His announcements for the present week are, to-night, "The Lady of Lyons;" on Tuesday, the "School for Scandal:" on Wednesday, "Love and Money;" on Thursday, (first time this season,) "Secrets Worth. Knowing;" on Friday, "Pauline," and on Saturday, the "Irish Heiress." At the Winter Garden Mr. COULDOCK's powerful performance of Peter Probity suffices to keep the "Chimney Corner" on the bills for another week -- a result which, we may add, is due in a large measure to the admirable way in which Mr. JACKSON has put the work upon the stage. Senora CUBAS, however, appears in a new part -- that of Naramattak, the Child of the Forest, in the piece of that name. At Niblo's Theatre, the play of "Leah, the Forsaken," in which Miss BATEMAN's success has been as decided as her most ardent admirers could have anticipated, will be repeated. The lady triumphs over the literary imperfections of the piece itself, and, by her own powerful and impressive acting of the principal character, has infused into it an amount of vitality and interest sufficient to render it one of the most popular and effective of her whole repertory. The theatre has been crowded every evening to the full extent of its capacious means of public accommodation, and there is every prospect of the piece continuing to be attractive for many nights to come. It is but just to say that Mrs. CHANFRAU, Mr. J.W. WALLACK, Jr., Mr. EDWIN ADAMS and Mr. BURNETT deserve great praise for what they usually do to insure the complete excellence with which the piece is presented. At Laura Keene's, the charming comedienne, Mrs. JOHN WOOD, will appear in the operetta called the "Pet of the Petticoats," and the farce of "Mr. and Mrs. White" will be given, with the other members of the company. At the Brooklyn Academy of Music Miss LUCILLE WESTERN commences an engagement in the moral emotional play of "East Lynne," supported by an efficient dramatic troupe. At Barnum's Museum, the charming LAVINIA WARREN, and in the lecture-room the play of "Charles the Second, or Waggeries in Wapping."

abstract: State Legislature; Outrages in Speakership Election
snippet: State Legislature; Outrages in Speakership Election
lead_paragraph: The Assembly Chamber was again disgraced on Saturday by unparliamentary and revolutionary proceedings on the part of the Democrats, led by Mr. FIKLDS, of New-York, Mr. MURPHY, of Erie, and others prominent in the party, and assisted by their coadjutors in the lobby and in the galleries. The proceedings opened with a personal explanation from Mr. FIELDS, in answer to some just strictures in a New-York paper. The ninety-first ballot for Speaker was then taken, in which Mr. TRIMMER had 60 votes, Mr. CALLICOTT 60, and Mr. DEPEW 1 -- one member being absent. When the ninety-second ballot was commenced, the member before absent had returned, and cast his vote for Mr. CALLICOT, thus insuring that gentleman's election should the ballot be consummated. A scene of the greatest excitement ensued, and the old game of filibustering to prevent any further proceedings, was immediately commenced. At one point in the proceedings, the Clerk having left his position for a few minutes, the Democrats attempted to usurp the Speaker's chair for one of their number, but this was carrying the matter too far for the patience of the Republican and Union members, and their opposition came near leading to bloodshed. Finally the Clerk reappeared, and took his place, when the excitement gradually subsided, but not, it appears, before it was understood that an adequate police force had been called, and were at hand to enforce order. It was finally agreed to adjourn until to-day, at 11 o'clock A.M., at which time the vote is to be proceeded with without further opposition. There appears to be little doubt now that Mr. CALLICOTT will be elected.
headline: {'main': 'THE STATE LEGISLATURE.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'THE STATE LEGISLATURE.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The Way to Put Down by Victories
snippet: The Way to Put Down by Victories
lead_paragraph: Since ROSECRANS' victory at Murfreesboro we hear but little of the ravages of rebel guerrillas in Kentucky or Tennessee, while previous to that event they seemed to be swarming in every county of those States. They destroyed immense quantities of supplies, picked up our little garrisons at numerous stations, and preyed upon Union men everywhere. A large part of them consisted simply of rebel farmers and others who were banded together in the various localities for this work, and who mounted their horses and started out at convenience on marauding excursions, to fill their pockets and aid JEFF. DAVIS. But a single great victory seems to have discouraged them completely, and put a stop to their operations; and excepting the late raid in the direction of the Tennessee River by a cavalry band from BRAGG's army, we have heard little of them in Tennessee or Kentucky since New-Year.
headline: {'main': 'THE WAY TO PUT DOWN GUERRILLAS.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'THE WAY TO PUT DOWN GUERRILLAS.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The Chicago Post gives the following particulars of the scene of the recent victory in the West: "Arkansas Post is on the east side (left bank) of the ...
lead_paragraph: -- The Chicago Post gives the following particulars of the scene of the recent victory in the West: "Arkansas Post is on the east side (left bank) of the river, and boasted of one store, a blacksmith-shop and a grocery. There is a road running from the place to St. Charles, on White River. The distance across is thirty miles. It was reported that a rebel force was at St. Charles, where the fortifications are very formidable. Gen. GORMAN had gone up White River with a view of taking that place. The capture of Arkansas Post will prevent the rebels from placing a battery at Cypress Bend, below Napoleon, on the Mississippi, where it was feared they would seriously obstruct the passage of transports on the way to Vicksburgh. The rebel Gen. HOLMES sent away most of his forces from Little Rock two weeks ago, to some point down the river. It may be that he has concluded to make a stand at St. Charles. If so, an early engagement will take place thereabouts.

abstract: T. J. Boyer's Charge of Election Corruption by
snippet: T. J. Boyer's Charge of Election Corruption by
lead_paragraph: A most extraordinary circumstantial statement has just been published by Mr. T. JEFFERSON BOYER, a Democratic member of the Pennsylvania Legislature, in reference to an alleged attempt of Hon. SIMON CAMERON to bribe BOYER to vote for CAMERON for the United States Senate. The story, in some respects, seems altogether incredible; yet it is told with such a minuteness of detail, and has in its main features such an air of truth, not to speak of the names mentioned and references given, that we trust it will be thoroughly probed before Mr. CAMERON is permitted to set out again to represent this Government at the Court of St. Petersburg -- preliminary to which duty, it is understood, he is now in Washington receiving instructions.

abstract: The scenes on Saturday in the Assembly were more turbulent and disgraceful than ever. While the ruffians in the galleries and lobbies continued still in full blast, the ill-disposed Democrats on the floor, led by a notorious minion of FERNANDO WOOD, cut loose from the little restraint that had before held them, and ...
lead_paragraph: The scenes on Saturday in the Assembly were more turbulent and disgraceful than ever. While the ruffians in the galleries and lobbies continued still in full blast, the ill-disposed Democrats on the floor, led by a notorious minion of FERNANDO WOOD, cut loose from the little restraint that had before held them, and abandoned themselves to reckless fury and utter lawlessness. The man FIELDS brazenly defied the peaceable majority of the House, and proclaimed, without mincing, that he "did not care for calls to order or the rules," and that "you cannot put me down;" and the defiance was greeted with approbatory yells that Bloomingdale itself would have been ashamed of. Another worthy of similar kidney undertook to steal the legal authority of the clerk over the House by a trick, such as not ten men out of the seven hundred in Sing Sing would have stooped to commit. The mad party excitements of other times have left many a stain upon our legislative record; but there is not one of them which does not now blanch by contrast into whiteness itself.
headline: {'main': 'The Outrages in the State Assembly.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Outrages in the State Assembly.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}
