abstract: BURGLARY.--A dwelling-house in South Third-street, E.D., occupied by Capt. THOMPSON, was entered on Saturday night by a gang of young burglars, and thoroughly ransacked, but the loss is not yet known, as the family is absent. Two boys, named...
lead_paragraph: BURGLARY. -- A dwelling-house in South Third-street, E.D., occupied by Capt. THOMPSON, was entered on Saturday night by a gang of young burglars, and thoroughly ransacked, but the loss is not yet known, as the family is absent. Two boys, named HUGH GORMAN and EDWARD ANDERSON, implicated in the robbery, were taken into custody yesterday. Last evening Officer MURPHY found a quantity of female wearing apparel, supposed to have been stolen from the premises, at a junk shop, where they had been sold for paper rags.

abstract: Conviction of Cowardice under Fire; New Theory of Military Duty; Democratic theory of reasoning on orders; the Kendall case
snippet: Conviction of Cowardice under Fire; New Theory of Military Duty; Democratic theory of reasoning on orders; the Kendall case
lead_paragraph: Second Lieut. CHARLES G. KENDALL, of the Forty-fourth Massachusetts Volunteers, was convicted recently, by a Court-martial held at Newbern of cowardice in quitting his company while his regiment was under the enemy's fire, and not coming back till the danger was over. For this peccadillo the Court sentenced him to be "reprimanded" by the commanding General, and he has been reprimanded accordingly; but we should also add that the General expressed his extreme disgust at the inadequacy of the sentence, and broadly intimated that if the said KENDALL had been shot, it would have served him right. There is no question that in any other army he would have been shot, and moreover rendered so thoroughly infamous that few of his friends would have cared to hear of him afterward.

abstract: standing in London, C.W. and one of a firm that does as large a business as any in their line in Canada, tendered at one of the stations on the line two American quarter-dollars for a ticket, the price of which was fifty cents. The ticket agent refused the quarters, demanding an additional amount, as the silver was stated to be at a discount. The gentleman then tendered in payment two British shillings and two cents, also British. This was also refused, the discount being still demanded. The party wishing to purchase the ticket refused the additional amount demanded, calling, at the same time, a gentleman to witness his legal tender of fifty cents. The would-be ticket-purchaser then entered the cars, and after traveling two or three miles, was removed by the conductor for not having a ticket and still refusing to pay the discount. The gentleman had, of course, to return to the station on foot. On reaching home he was about to commence an action for damages, when the Railway Company compromised the matter by paying him $259. -- London (C.W.) Daily News.

abstract: River, the sailors, >amp;c., wanted for the fleet in
snippet: River, the sailors, >amp;c., wanted for the fleet in
lead_paragraph: -- Men are very much wanted in the West by Admiral PORTER to man the naval vessels intended for operations on the Mississippi River. The inducements to enter this service are very great -- promotion to command for those who earn it, and good pay and subsistence. Our letter from Cairo this morning gives a statement of the wages paid to men and officers engaged in the various branches -- ranging from forty-five down to twelve dollars a month, exclusive of rations. Men are wanted for all sorts of ship and steamboat work; men who can handle an oar, pull a rope or splice a brace; men for quartermasters, stewards and coalheavers, as well as craftsmen, like coopers and armorers, and professors of the fine arts, like musicians and cooks. Plenty of men are complaining of hard times in New-York, while the movements of our flotillas in the West are actually delayed for want of handy laborers, craftsmen and sailors.

abstract: We publish this morning, from the pen of our special correspondent, an interesting and graphic account of the recent movement of the Army of the Potomac preparatory to the second crossing of the Rappahannock a consummation which was prevented by the terrible storm which raged ...
lead_paragraph: We publish this morning, from the pen of our special correspondent, an interesting and graphic account of the recent movement of the Army of the Potomac preparatory to the second crossing of the Rappahannock -- a consummation which was prevented by the terrible storm which raged during three days of last week, and which put the roads in the vicinity of the river in such a condition that the movement of the pontoons and artillery was found to be impossible. Our correspondent thinks the campaign is now at an end for the Winter. Gen. BURNSIDE was again in Washington, on Saturday, and had interviews with the President, Secretary STANTON and Gen. HALLECK. A telegram from the Army of the Potomac says there is nothing of interest to communicate. No movement of importance has been observed among the rebels.

abstract: Richmond Examiner on the Necessity of Conscription
snippet: Richmond Examiner on the Necessity of Conscription
lead_paragraph: -The Richmond Examiner, of Tuesday last, quotes from a recent issue of the TIMES some remarks in reference to the military and territorial gains of our arms in rebeldom during the year, and admits that another year or two of such progress will find us masters of the Southern Confederacy. It sarcastically adds that this condition of things is very consoling to the South, and then proceeds to indicate a remedy for it. "The remedy lies," says the Examiner, "in the extension and rigid enforcement of that law to which we owe our salvation. We must bring out the conscripts." "If," it is added, "we do not within the next two months add seventy-five or a hundred thousand men to our forces in the Southwest, we shall come to grief." This is all indubitably true. The rebels in the Southwest will come to grief in the Spring if they do not raise a hundred thousand new conscripts; and a hundred thousand new conscripts they cannot raise; and they will come to grief whether they raise them or not. We in the North do not look enough at the broader and deeper aspects of affairs -- do not dwell enough upon our great gains and glorious victories, but are reduced almost to despair by the defeats which are necessarily mingled with our triumphs.

abstract: -A ridiculous story has been circulated that Gen. WOOL has undertaken to have all the State Militia regiments brought under his authority, and the State Rights sticklers have got themselves in a fever of fermentation thereupon. The simple fact is, that Gen. WOOL undertook to control the new recruits enlisted in his district, believing that as soon as a recruit was mustered into the United States service, he was under his control, as a United States officer. It appears that a different opinion is entertained at Albany, but there is not the slighest chance of any serious difficulty. Uncle Sam has too much love and gratitude toward New-York to wish to do anything not strictly legal. The story about Gen. WOOL's ordering "regimental Commanders" to report their force to him is nonsense. If Gen. WOOL assumed such authority, his orders would necessarily come through the Division and Brigade Commanders first.

abstract: We receive, by way of Havana, important news from Mexico, though nothing later from the Capital our former advices reaching to the 20th ult. Advices from Vera Cruz and other points ...
lead_paragraph: We receive, by way of Havana, important news from Mexico, though nothing later from the Capital -- our former advices reaching to the 20th ult. Advices from Vera Cruz and other points are to the 1st inst. The French were said to be awaiting reinforcements before advancing upon Puebla, toward which place they had progressed no further than Palmar. The expected reinforcements were to consist of two divisions of the Imperial Guard, making the entire effective force for attacking Puebla only about 15,000 men. On the Mexican side the disposable force was much larger -- 25,000 regulars and 10,000 volunteers being in Puebla alone, while at other points were supposed to be in the neighborhood of 50,000 men. At Puebla ten forts had been constructed, mounting nearly 200 cannon, and the fortifications of the capital were on an equally extensive scale. A rumor prevailed in Havana at the date of our latest advices, that the French had advanced against Puebla, and had suffered another repulse. There is a possibility that the rumor is true. Indeed, we receive from another correspondent in Havana news of a more explicit character, which leads us to place considerable reliance in it. The communications between Vera Cruz and Orizaba are said to be entirely cut off, and can only be restored by posting strong guards all along the road. The guerrillas are in strong force, and worry the French unceasingly. The report of the repulse at Puebla is reiterated, with the addition that the French vanguard, four thousand strong, was completely surprised by eight hundred Mexican cavalry, and about two thousand of them killed and wounded. Several French officers had been captured by the lasso and dragged off, and every straggling soldier is served in the same manner.

abstract: THE HOBOKEN AND NEWARK RAILROAD ACCIDENT. -- The bodies of PATRICK GALLAGHER and the unknown young man dressed in soldier's clothes, who were drowned at the Hackensack drawbridge, on the Hoboken and Newark Railroad, on Saturday, were recovered that afternoon. GALLAGHER's remains were conveyed to Newark, and the body of the unknown man was taken to Hudson City, where an investigation will be commenced, before Coroner DONNELLY, to-day. The baggage-car has been got out of the river, and the obstructions removed from the track, so that the trains will run as usual, to-day. Workmen are engaged in endeavoring to raise the locomotive, which lies in about 30 feet of water.

abstract: ROBBERY OF JEWELRY IN BLEECKER-STREET  A CASE OF MISPLACED CONFIDENCE. Two parties named ELLEN FOX and WM. LAMBERT, were yesterday brought before Justice QUACKENBUSH, upon the complaint of Mrs. CHARLOTTE GUEST, of No. 391 Bleecker
lead_paragraph: ROBBERY OF JEWELRY IN BLEECKER-STREET -- A CASE OF MISPLACED CONFIDENCE. -- Two parties named ELLEN FOX and WM. LAMBERT, were yesterday brought before Justice QUACKENBUSH, upon the complaint of Mrs. CHARLOTTE GUEST, of No. 391 Bleecker-street, who alleges that the prisoners stole from her private apartment, on the 5th inst., property consisting of a box of jewelry, a crape shawl, a gold watch and chain, and other valuables, amounting in all to $267. The testimony discloses the fact that ELLEN had recently been in the employ of Mrs. GUEST, as a dressmaker, and while there she had an opportunity to learn the place where her employer kept her valuables. The evening previous to the theft ELLEN learned that the complainant would be out the next forenoon; she accordingly made her arrangements, entered Mrs. GUEST's private apartment when there was no one in the house to interfere with her plans, took the property and departed. The shawl was subsequently recovered at a pawn shop, where it had been pledged by ELLEN. The remainder of the property has not been found. The other prisoner, LAMBERT, is known to have presented some of the other articles at a pawn shop in Greene-street, but the pawnbroker refund to receive them in pledge on the ground that he suspected them to have been stolen. The latter prisoner has recently abandoned an intelligent and amiable wife and seven children, who reside in Forty-third-street, and has since been living with ELLEN FOX at the corner of Crosby and Spring streets, where both parties were arrested by Officer BOWER, of the Second District Police Court. The Magistrate committed ELLEN for trial. The other party was discharged, the evidence upon this complaint being deemed insufficient.

abstract: In the Senate, on Saturday, a memorial from Dr. W.S.G. MORTON was presented, asking for compensation for the use of ether in the Army and Navy. A bill relating to jurors in the Courts of the United States was referred to the Judiciary Committee. A bill to establish the office of ...
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, on Saturday, a memorial from Dr. W.S.G. MORTON was presented, asking for compensation for the use of ether in the Army and Navy. A bill relating to jurors in the Courts of the United States was referred to the Judiciary Committee. A bill to establish the office of Register of Deeds for the District of Columbia was referred to the Committee on District Affairs. The resolution directing the Secretary of the Navy not to accept the title to League Island until Congress so directs, was passed. The Consular and Diplomatic Appropriation bill was reported from the Finance Committee. The Secretary of the Treasury was asked to communicate to the Senate any information he may have received from the Commissioners appointed for the District of South Carolina, under the act for the collection of direct taxes in insurrectionary States. The bill providing for increased clerical force in the Quartermaster-General's office was passed, after some amendment. A bill to establish the guage on the Pacific Railroad and its branches was referred to the Select Committee. The Senate then adjourned until Monday.

abstract: The Army of the Potomac, during the less than two years of its existence, has had a larger number of Generals at its head than has fallen to the lot of any great army of modern times during an equal period. From the days when it was organized by Gen. SCOTT, to the time when it was led to the fatal field of Manassas by Gen. MCDOWELL, -- and after that during the period of its reorganization by Gen. MCCLELLAN and its campaign on the Peninsula, -- subsequently during its operations under Gen. POPE, and its Maryland campaign after the reinstatement of MCCLELLAN -- down to the appointment of Gen. BURNSIDE and the campaign of the Rappahannock, -- it has been without a leader capable of handling it so as to produce by it those victorious results which the nation deemed it capable of achieving.

abstract: Notwithstanding old Jupiter Pluvius, who seems to have a spite against all festivities this Winter, and who has rained down objections to nearly every grand ball thus far given, the firemen flocked in vast numbers to the Fourteenth-street Opera House last night, and, as might be expected of gentlemen in their profession, brought their "flames" with them. Once within the Academy's walls, they all with one accord folded up the outside dampness with their overcoats and cloaks, and speedily entered upon the jovous business of the evening.

abstract: Illinois and other Legislatures
snippet: Illinois and other Legislatures
lead_paragraph: Letters from the Southwestern camps all concur in representing a universal and intense indignation, among officers and soldiers, against the treacherous movements of the Copperheads in the Illinois and other Western Legislatures. This feeling is said to be completely independent of old party ties. The Democrats are every whit as much incensed as the Republicans. All alike protest that the war is bound to go on, and that they will stand no treachery in the rear.

abstract: In the Senate yesterday, the Committee on Commerce was instructed to inquire into the expediency of appointing an Assistant Collector of Customs for the District of New-York, to reside in Jersey City. A bill to organize a volunteer militia force, to be called the National Guard of the United States, was introduced by Mr. WILSON, of Massachusetts, and referred to the Military Committe. The bill providing for the removal of Indians from Kansas wss debated but not acted upon. The bill for the better protection of overland emigrants to the Pacific coast was passed. A bill to provide for a National currency, to be secured by pledge of public stocks, was introduced by Mr. SHERMAN, of Ohio, and referred to the Finance Committee. Mr. SUMNER's bill to suspend the sale of lands in South Carolina and Georgia was passed. Mr. FOSTER of Connecticut, presented a communication from laborers in England, many of them residing in Lancashire, expressing gratitude for our municipal donation of provisions, etc., and the wish that some means might be provided for their emigration to this country. The communication, coming from foreigners, could not be received. A bill to provide for additional transportation facilities on the West was introduced by Mr. HARLAN, of Iowa. The Committee on Printing was instructed to make inquiries regarding the printing of departmental correspondence in newspapers as an advertisement. A resolution, calling upon the President for a copy of the record of the proceedings in the case of Gen. PORTER, was laid over. A bill to improve navigation between the Mississippi River and Lake Michigan was referred to the Military Committee. The resolution instructing the Committee on the Conduct of the War to make inquiries regarding alleged interference with Gen. BURNSIDE's plans, was adopted. The bill to abrogate treaties with the Sioux Indians, and to indemnify the people of Minnesota for losses sustained through Indian outrages, was passed. After an exciting session, the Senate adjourned.

abstract: Gen. ROSECRANS hopes the Cincinnati, Louisville and other newspapers will desist from the practice of publishing reports of shipments of supplies to the Department of the Cumberland. This is substantially a notification to the rebels to prepare their forces for the capture of such supplies. It is understood, however, that newspapers would not make such publications if Quartermasters and Commissaries did not furnish the items.

lead_paragraph: Gen. BURNSIDE has resigned; Gen. HOOKER has been assigned to his place; Gens. SUMNER and FRANKLIN have been relieved of their commands of the Right and Left Grand Divisions, -- this is the news we have from the Army of the Potomac this morning. Gen. BURNSIDE's resignation was accepted on Saturday morning, and yesterday morning he turned over the command to Gen. HOOKER. When the change became known, a considerable number of superior officers called on Gen. BURNSIDE to take leave of him and tender their regrets at his departure. His parting address to the soldiers awards them praise for their courage, patience and endurance, and invokes their full and cordial support for his successor. The General, with most of his late Staff, has been granted leave of absence for thirty days, and will come immediately to New-York.

abstract: THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing. In addition to the latest intelligence by telegraph up to the moment of going to press, there will be found in the current number full details of all military movements in the different departments from the pens of our special correspondents. Also, all official orders, reports and documents, and the latest and fullest Washington news, European news, with graphic letters from our correspondents in London and Paris, giving the tone of public feeling abroad, is made a special and permanent feature. In addition to Editorials on all the current topics of the day, the SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES has a page of carefully prepared commercial matter, giving the latest financial news and market reports, items of agricultural and domestic interest, compiled from sources many of which are otherwise inaccessible to the American reader; and marriages and deaths of the week.

abstract: Senate's Resolution of Inquiry on Reponsibility for Army Movements
snippet: Senate's Resolution of Inquiry on Reponsibility for Army Movements
lead_paragraph: We observe with pleasure that the Senate yesterday adopted the resolution introduced into that body a few days ago, instructing the Committee on the Conduct of the War "to inquire whether any plans of Gen. BURNSIDE for the movement of the army were interfered with by officers writing to or visiting Washington to oppose them, and if such movements were arrested, and if so, by what authority." It is due to Gen. BURNSIDE, and, more still, it is due to our army, and to the cause of the country, that the truth be brought out on this point. It is needed, so that such interferences be prevented in future; for if subordinate officers, who object to the plan of the Commanding General they are serving under, may write or run to the President, and pour into his ears such tales as may affect his judgment of the skill and reliability of their superiors, then it will be impossible that any military programme should ever be carried out, or any success ever attend our arms. One will, said NAPOLEON, is essential to the operations of an army. Subordinate Generals may have their quarrels among themselves, but, toward their commander, nothing is permissible but unqualified devotion and loyalty. If the insinuation in the resolution is correct -- and it has been publicly made from more than one quarter -- the delinquent officers should be cashiered.

abstract: It is satisfactory to state that the reports which have been published in certain newspapers in regard to a fracas existing between Gen. WOOL and the military authorities of the New-York State Militia, is altogether without even the shadow of-foundation, and it is also untrue that any ill-feeling exists between any of the divisions of the said militia and the General, respecting the former ordering reports to be furnished to his department, and that they were refused. Such reports can only have had their origin in the fruitful, but nevertheless untruthful, cranium of some wag, who would wish to see this important department of the service dispensed with. These facts we have from the source best qualified to give the true and correct statement of affairs.

abstract: Hale, Rev. Dr. B. Rust
snippet: Hale, Rev. Dr. B. Rust
lead_paragraph: Rev. Dr. BAYNARD RUST HALL, whose decease has been recently announced, was born in Philadelphia, in 1798. He was a son of Dr. JOHN HALL, who once held a position upon the Staff of Gen. WASHINGTON. He studied for some time at Princeton College, but graduated at Union with high honors, and although his friends intended that he should follow the legal profession, he chose the ministry, completing his theological course at the Seminary in Princeton. At the age of 22, he was married to Miss YOUNG, in Danville, Ky., and then went West to settle. He was Pastor of a Church and President of a College in Bloomington, Ind., for some years. Subsequently, he removed to Bedford, Penn., where he was Pastor of a flourishing congregation, and Principal of a large academy. At various periods he has been connected with educational institutions in Bordentown and Trenton. N.J., and at Poughkeepsie and Newburgh, N.Y.

abstract: The "long agony" regarding the Speakership of the Assembly is at last at an end, Mr. CALLICOTT having been elected yesterday, by a vote of 61 to 59, six members being absent when the decisive ballot was taken. Some little disposition was shown on the part of Mr. FIELDS and some other Democratic members, to act in bad faith regarding the agreement entered into on Saturday, but they were shamed into decent behavior by the honorable action of other Democrats. Mr. CALLICOTT was conducted to his seat by Mr. DEPEW and Mr. SMITH, and made a brief address, after which the rest of the Officers of the Assembly -- all Union men -- were chosen, JOSEPH B. CUSHMAN, of Oneida, being Clerk. The organization being completed, Mr. FIELDS rose to a question of privilege, and offered a preamble and resolutions making grave charges against Mr. CALLICOTT, and providing for a Committee of Five, to investigate them. Pending the question of their adoption, the Assembly adjourned.

abstract: The pupils of HALASKO's Drill Academy, No. 865 Broadway, gave an exhibition on Saturday afternoon at Niblo's Garden, which was quite a success. There were in attendance about sixty of the pupils, who, by the way, style themselves New-York Cadets. The exercises opened with Company drills, and then an amusing play, so cast as to bring the entire class upon the stage, and to give them an opportunity of exhibiting their proficiency in drill, was given. After this was concluded, a beautiful stand of colors was presented to the Company by Maj. HALASKO, and the cadets returned the compliment by giving the Major an elegant sword. Speeches appropriate to the occasion were made, and the performances were concluded with some exercises in calisthenics. The Garden was crowded to its utmost capacity with the friends of the pupils, who were evidently greatly pleased with the exercises.

abstract: We need not direct attention to the very able and lengthy report we publish this morning from Judge-Advocate HOLT in reference to the case of Gen. PORTER. The dismissal of that officer is being very much complained of by certain party newspapers, as if it had anything whatever to do with party. But Judge HOLT puts the facts of his disobedience in a light so clear that even faction  cannot now complain of the decison of his military judges, unless it is proposed to make insubordination a cardinal principle in our army's organization. Like everything from Judge HOLT's pen, this is a document of extraordinary ability, lucidity, logical power, and of absolutely conclusive force.

abstract: -- At 2 o'clock on Friday afternoon, a terrific explosion occurred at the Watervliet Arsenal. Owing to a fortunate combination of circumstances, no person was injured, but the escape from a disaster even more serious than that which occurred in the Fall of 1861, was narrow. The explosion took place in the finishing shop. One of the workmen was engaged in polishing a fuse-cap against an eatery wheel, when the sparks set fire to a quantity of fuses that were lying near by. Six thousand fuses were simultaneously ignited, with a tremendous report. The doors and windows of the building were blown out, and the interior of the room was a blinding mass of smoke. Several men who were at work in the shop, which was in the second story of the building, rushed down stairs or jumped through the windows to escape the sulphurous fumes. It was found that no one was injured by the accident. Until recently, however, powder and shell had been kept within exploding distance. Had any of those destructive agents been near at the time of the accident, the building would have been a wreck and several lives have been lost.
lead_paragraph: -- At 2 o'clock on Friday afternoon, a terrific explosion occurred at the Watervliet Arsenal. Owing to a fortunate combination of circumstances, no person was injured, but the escape from a disaster even more serious than that which occurred in the Fall of 1861, was narrow. The explosion took place in the finishing shop. One of the workmen was engaged in polishing a fuse-cap against an eatery wheel, when the sparks set fire to a quantity of fuses that were lying near by. Six thousand fuses were simultaneously ignited, with a tremendous report. The doors and windows of the building were blown out, and the interior of the room was a blinding mass of smoke. Several men who were at work in the shop, which was in the second story of the building, rushed down stairs or jumped through the windows to escape the sulphurous fumes. It was found that no one was injured by the accident. Until recently, however, powder and shell had been kept within exploding distance. Had any of those destructive agents been near at the time of the accident, the building would have been a wreck and several lives have been lost.

abstract: KINGS COUNTY BOARD OF SUPERVISORS, The Supervisors met at the County Jail, in Raymondstreet, yesterday afternoon. The most important business, to those interested, was the removal of the present Deputy Keepers of the Penitentiary and the appointment of the following in their places: Meysis.
lead_paragraph: KINGS COUNTY BOARD OF SUPERVISORS, The Supervisors met at the County Jail, in Raymondstreet, yesterday afternoon. The most important business, to those interested, was the removal of the present Deputy Keepers of the Penitentiary and the appointment of the following in their places: Messrs. James Campbell, John McCanna, George A. New-sam, James Jones, Francis McCormick, Arthur Colgan, and Thomas Martin. A motion to appoint Mr. A.Y. SMITH as night watchman, at a salary of $700 a year, was referred to the Penitentiary Committee for report at the next meeting. The Special Committee on the communication of the District-Attorney, asking for the appointment, at a salary of $1,500 per year, reported in favor. The subject was however, laid over till next week. A communication from the County Clerk, calling attention to the defaced condition of the County records, &c., was referred to the same Committee, and the Board adjourned. until the 5th inst., at 3 P.M.

abstract: the Trial of; Disobedient Generals
snippet: the Trial of; Disobedient Generals
lead_paragraph: An attempt is being made to get up a popular clamor against the military Court which cashiered FITZ-JOHN PORTER. It proceeds on the assumption that the tribunal was influenced by personal and political projudice. There is no serious effort to substantiate this: the sole reliance is broad assertion and wild denunciation. It is taken for granted that these will tell well enough upon that great class who have not the time, or have not the disposition, to investigate; and that thus new animosity can be stirred up against the President, who approved the finding and the sentence.

abstract: We understand that a small quantity of tar has recently been produced from trees growing in the extensive pine forest of Andros Island, which realized $15 a barrel at Nassau. There are three other large nine forests in the Bahamas -- one at New-Providence, one at Abaco, and one at Grand Bahama -- which, under licence from the Crown, could be made available for the production of tar and turpentine; and since these articles bear so high a price in consequence of the civil war in America, we wonder that all our resources are not turned to account. -- Nassau Gazette, Dec. 27.

abstract: Callicot, Mr. and his Election as Speaker of the New-York Assembly; Paris Letter, Jan. 13; London Times Advises the Federal Government to Dissolve Itself; The splendid fighting under Gen. Rosecrans; French cruelties at Vera Cruz
snippet: Callicot, Mr. and his Election as Speaker of the New-York Assembly; Paris Letter, Jan. 13; London Times Advises the Federal Government to Dissolve Itself; The splendid fighting under Gen. Rosecrans; French cruelties at Vera Cruz
lead_paragraph: Mr. CALLICOT deserves the highest praise for the manner in which he has conducted himself throughout the whole of the extraordinary contest which has happily closed by his election as Speaker of the State Assembly. His triumph is something more than the triumph of a party, as his conduct also showed that he could rise above the trammels of party when the welfare of the State and the course of legislation required that party should be ignored. He has been maligned, insulted, browbeaten, and threatened by members of his own party; charges the most preposterous have been made against him; abuse the most malign and interminable has been heaped upon him; and bullies belonging to the riotous faction have even gone so far as to threaten his assassination in case he was elected. It was twenty days from the time the House met till it was organized, and ten days from the time Mr. CALLICOT was nominated until he was chosen Speaker. For the first ten days of the session it seemed impossible to relieve the deadlock which the position of parties placed upon legislation. There had then been seventy-seven ballots for Speaker, and the prospect was, if neither side of the House had been sufficiently magnanimous to take up a candidate from the opposite party, and if every member of each political party had factiously adhered to it, that the ballotings might have reached a thousand, and the purpose for which the Legislature was elected have been utterly frustrated. There was but one course for the Republicans to adopt, and a Democrat was nominated. Since then, for ten days, the Assembly Chamber has exhibited scenes the like of which never before disgraced the Legislature of New-York. The proceedings of the factionists were little short of being revolutionary. The violence culminated on Saturday last, when Mr. FIELDS, who had been the leader in it, poured out a torrent of vulgar defamation upon Mr. CALLICOT, and defied the House to enforce order. During all this time, and amid all these scenes, Mr. CALLICOT bore himself with a manliness, a courage and a prudence which could not be surpassed; and, through all, his patriotism has shone conspicuous. Those Democrats who, toward the end, exhibited a willingness to cut loose from the factionists who would have precipitated the State into revolution to forward their selfish purposes, and who aided in the effort to organize the House, also deserve the respect of all lovers of law and order.

abstract: IMPORTANT ARREST THEFT OF GOVERNMENT PROPERTY. RICHARD P. BRUFF, a Government contractor, doing business at No. 384 Broadway, made a complaint yesterday before Justice CONNOLLY, againat JAMES McLOUGHLIN, a workman in his employ, whom he charges with having stolen a large number of revolvers.
lead_paragraph: IMPORTANT ARREST -- THEFT OF GOVERNMENT PROPERTY. -- RICHARD P. BRUFF, a Government contractor, doing business at No. 384 Broadway, made a complaint yesterday before Justice CONNOLLY, againat JAMES McLOUGHLIN, a workman in his employ, whom he charges with having stolen a large number of revolvers. From the affidavit of the complainant we learn that Mr. BRUFF has been employed by the Government to manufacture revolvers and other kinds of pistols. In the early part of the present month BRUFF took into his service several parties, among whom was the prisoner, MCLOUGHLIN. From that time until the present the complainant has daily missed a quantity of the manufactured arms, and in many instances he missed them after the revolvers had been carefully packed in boxes ready for shipping. The matter at length became so serious that an application was made to the Police of the Sixth Precinct and Officer GOLDEN undertook to ferret out the facts and he very soon detected the prisoner and look him into custody while he was in the act of pawning one of the stolen revolvers. A further investigation led to the recovery of about thirty costly revolvers, all of which had been pledged at various pawn offices, in this City, by the accused. When going in pledge a pistol he invariably told the person in charge of the pawn-shop that he was a discharged cavalry officer, and in this manner he managed to avoid suspicion. Justice CONNOLLY committed him in full for trial.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, a bill to authorize contracts in such States as may advance pay and allotment to volunteers and militia in the service, was introduced and referred to the Military Committee. The Military Committee was instructed
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, yesterday, a bill to authorize contracts in such States as may advance pay and allotment to volunteers and militia in the service, was introduced and referred to the Military Committee. The Military Committee was instructed to inquire into the expediency of authorizing the President to offer bounty for reenlistment to volunteers now in the service, and of providing by law for three months' soldiers, either by enlistment or draft. A motion to take up the resolution calling for the record of the Porter Court-Martial was disagreed to -- 22 to 18. The bill to provide for the removal of Indians from Kansas was passed; also, the bill to provide for the removal of Indians from Minnesota. The documents concerning the capture of British vessels sailing from one neutral port to another, having on board articles contraband of war, were sent in by the President. The bill indemnifying the President and other persons for suspending the privileges of the writ of habeas corpus, &c., was then considered until the adjournment.

lead_paragraph: By the arrival at this port of the steamship Saxonia, we have advices from Europe to the 14th inst. The most important feature of the news is the address of the French Emperor at the opening of the Corps Legislatif, which is thought to shadow forth French intervention in the affairs of the United States. He says: "I have made the attempt to send beyond the Atlantic advices inspired by a sincere sympathy; but the great maritime Powers not having thought it advisable as yet to act in concert with me, I have been obliged to postpone to a more suitable opportunity the offer of mediation, the object of which was to stop the effusion of blood, and to prevent the exhaustion of a country, the future of which cannot be looked upon with indifference." There was very little change in the Liverpool Cotton Market. Breadstuffs were generally steady. Provisions were dull. Consols were quoted at 921 for money. American stocks of all ascriptions had advanced.

abstract: Under the auspices of the Mercantile Library Association of Brooklyn, the elite of that very respectable city enjoyed heartily, on Tuesday evening, one of the most charming promenade concerts that have been given in this, that, or any other city in the country, In order to afford ample room for the promenaders, a temporary floor had been laid over the parquette, leaving only a few seats for the aged or weary, nearest the entrance hall. In the centre, on a raised platform, the regiment of musicians, under HELMSMULLER, were stationed; and prompt to the time named, every member was in readiness to perform his alloted part. There was no tawdry ornamentation to be seen. The sombre hues which still adorn the walls of the Academy were considered the most appropriate background for a full realization of the beauties of the animated, the ever moving decorations, upon which the managers had wisely depended for their grandest effect -- the ladies in their rich and tasteful attire. At 7 1/2 o'clock the first of the long line of carriages arrived, and at 8 1/2 o'clock the vast [???]oor presented a most brilliant spectacle. The promenaders formed a dazzling circle, gliding sylph-like (the female portion) around the musicians, whose harmonies enhanced what alone presented all the enchantment of a fairy scene.
lead_paragraph: Under the auspices of the Mercantile Library Association of Brooklyn, the elite of that very respectable city enjoyed heartily, on Tuesday evening, one of the most charming promenade concerts that have been given in this, that, or any other city in the country, In order to afford ample room for the promenaders, a temporary floor had been laid over the parquette, leaving only a few seats for the aged or weary, nearest the entrance hall. In the centre, on a raised platform, the regiment of musicians, under HELMSMULLER, were stationed; and prompt to the time named, every member was in readiness to perform his alloted part. There was no tawdry ornamentation to be seen. The sombre hues which still adorn the walls of the Academy were considered the most appropriate background for a full realization of the beauties of the animated, the ever moving decorations, upon which the managers had wisely depended for their grandest effect -- the ladies in their rich and tasteful attire. At 7 1/2 o'clock the first of the long line of carriages arrived, and at 8 1/2 o'clock the vast [???]oor presented a most brilliant spectacle. The promenaders formed a dazzling circle, gliding sylph-like (the female portion) around the musicians, whose harmonies enhanced what alone presented all the enchantment of a fairy scene.

abstract: Spirit of the people
snippet: Spirit of the people
lead_paragraph: We give space, this morning, to some most interesting and important documents received by the last mail from Mexico. They embrace the speech of the President of the Mexican Republic at the close of the regular session of Congress, with the spirited and patriotic reply of the President of that body, and the address of President JUAREZ to the soldiers at Puebla, who participated in the victory over the French of the 5th of May, in presenting to them the medals which, by order of Congress, have been struck in commemoration of that event. We also publish a circular addressed to a Governor in the interior, from which we infer that in addition to all the other ills which have afflicted the French army in Mexico, is now added that of desertion.

lead_paragraph: A meeting of prominent clergymen of this City and Brooklyn was held at Clinton Hall yesterday afternoon, with a view to aid in extending the operations of the Christian Commission. Rev. Dr. WM. ADAMS occupied the Chair, and Rev. J. COTTON SMITH was Secretary. Addresses were guide by Messrs. W.E. DODGE, Rev. Mr. REED, of Philadelphia, Mr. G.S. GRIFFITH, of Baltimore and Mr. RUSSELL S. COOK, after which a series of resolutions were offered by Rev. Messrs. WILLIAMS, HITCHCOCK, HUTTON, SMITH, HOLDICH and TAYLOR, strongly indorsing the cause.

abstract: We pub  lish in another column Mr. WEED'S farewell to the readers of the Albany Evening Journal. His retirement from the editorship of that paper is an event in the political history of the State.
lead_paragraph: We publish in another column Mr. WEED'S farewell to the readers of the Albany Evening Journal. His retirement from the editorship of that paper is an event in the political history of the State. No man living has held in this country so commanding a political position for so long a time as he. No man has signalized so long a political career by greater sagacity, a more unselfish devotion to the political party whose success he deemed essential to the public good, or by more signal success in the attainment of the objects which he sought to accomplish. The Evening Journal has been from the outset an important, but not an indispensable, auxiliary to his efforts. His success has been due to his character: the Journal was but one of the instruments with which he worked.

abstract: Robinson, Prof. Edward
snippet: Robinson, Prof. Edward
lead_paragraph: Prof. EDWARD ROBINSON, the celebrated philologist and biblical scholar, died at his residence in this City on Tuesday night last, of dropsy in the chest. He has been in feeble health for some months. He visited Germany during the last Summer for surgical treatment of his eyes, which were for some time threatened with entire deprivation of sight. He returned in the Fall, but never resumed, actively, his accustomed labors. Dr. ROBINSON was one of the most distinguished scholars of biblical learning in this country. He was a native of Connecticut, born in 1794, graduated at Hamilton College in this State in 1816, and went to Andover in 1821, where he studied Hebrew and became associated with Dr. STUART in the translation of some text books from the German and in the instruction of his classes. In 1826, he went to Europe, where he studied four years, when he returned, and became Professor of Sacred Literature in Andover. He resigned this position in 1833, and removed to Boston. In 1837, he was appointed Professor of Biblical Literature in the Union Theological Seminary in this City, and held that position until his death. Previous to entering upon its duties he visited Palestine, and made a very minute and careful study of the country in connection with the geography of the Bible. In 1841, he published the results of this study, in three octavo volumes, which became the text-book for all the students in that Department Much of his subsequent life was devoted to the revision and perfection of this work, though he published some others connected with classical studies. Dr. R. married in 1816 a daughter of Rev. S, KIRKLAND, a missionary among the Oneida Indians, but she died three years after. In 1829, he married Miss TERESA A.L. VON JACOB, daughter of Prof. VON JACOB, of the University of Halle, a lady of rare ability and scholarship, whose writings and translations, under the name of "Talvi," are widely known in this country and in Europe. She survives a husband, who leaves also a son and daughter. Prof. ROBINSON was the leading man of a class, small, as yet, in this country, who achieve European celebrity in the department of letters to which he devoted his life.

abstract: We shall undoubtedly soon hear of the third attack upon the rebel defences at Vicksburgh. Gen. GRANT'S troops were at last accounts rapidly moving down the Mississippi from Memphis, and rendezvousing at Milliken's Bend. Gen. MCCLERNAND's forces and Admiral PORTER's Squadron ...
lead_paragraph: We shall undoubtedly soon hear of the third attack upon the rebel defences at Vicksburgh. Gen. GRANT'S troops were at last accounts rapidly moving down the Mississippi from Memphis, and rendezvousing at Milliken's Bend. Gen. MCCLERNAND's forces and Admiral PORTER's Squadron were at Young's Point, only twenty miles above Vicksburgh. Late rebel news indicates that a desperate defence will be made both at Vicksburgh and at Port Hudson, with the view of keeping open communication with Arkansas, Louisiana and Texas.

abstract: The so-called Democrats in our State As-sembly made a desperate attempt yesterday to defeat the resolution to go into the election of a United States Senator on Tuesday next. As the law is imperative on the point, no resolution was necessary; the Speaker could have announced the election at the time indicated as the only business then in order. But the resolution was adopted, and the resistance offered only served to show at once the recklessness and the powerlessness of the party which made it.

abstract: It is an unfortunate fact, that the deserving very seldom get their deserts in this world, and that neither energy nor enterprise are of themselves sufficient to insure success, even in the most laudable undertakings. Singers and placers, as well as Generals and sailing vessels, are always at the mercy of the weather, and their best combinations, strategical or otherwise, may be frustrated by unfavorable atmospheric conditions. Two eminent instances in proof of this may be found of late in the frustrated movement of Gen. BURNSIDE across the Rappahannock, and the concert of Mrs. J.E. THOMAS on Tuesday night. In both cases nothing was left undone, on the part of the commanders, that could be done to make triumph a certainty, and only the weather was to blame for the different result. There is this difference between the two examples cited, however, which interferes to destroys perfect parallel. Mrs. THOMAS' assistants and subordinate officers lent her their best efforts, and neither urged postponement nor really threw obstacles in the way, while ostensibly lending loyal cooperation. Messrs. CASTLE and CAMPBELL sang, and Mr. MILLS played, as well as though the walls of Irving Hall were bursting with an audience, [???] [???] [???] giver of the concert brought her best voice and talent upon the stage. But what magic summons can bring people out from their warm firesides when rain and snow fill the air and mud carpets streets and crossings? Certainly, there was a fair circle of friends present, but not as many as the merits of the occasion demanded, though it is probable that many seats were paid for in advance which were not filled. May better weather smile upon Mrs. THOMAS in her next endeavor to entertain the public.

abstract: We have often directed attention to the perils to discipline and morals arising from the temptations of the camp. We are glad to perceive that the subject is receiving increased attention, and that prominent Christian gentlemen are bestirring themselves to provide systematic means for the moral and religious improvement of the army and navy. Mr. GEORGE H. STUART, of Philadelphia, has turned his large mercantile and banking establishment into a sort of moral arsenal, and as the head of the United States Christian Commission, has pushed forward an admirable system for the benefit of the soldiers. A score of like-minded men in this City have now taken the field, and a meeting was held yesterday afternoon, at which a large number of influential clergymen were present. Its proceedings, together with the comprehensive and effective plan of operations which they adopted, will be found in this morning's columns. Without abating a jot of zeal in the noble work of the Sanitary Commission, this more distinctively Christian Commission should, and doubtless will, press on with the steady zeal which such work demands, and which the gentlemen composing the organization are wont to manifest in other relations. We cannot doubt the ready and generous support of this community for a Commission that so admirably meets a universally felt necessity?

abstract: THE EXTENSION OF THE EIGHT-AVENUE RAILROAD TO HARLEM. A meeting of citizens of the Twelfth Ward was held at the Lyon Brewery, on One hundred and Tenth-street, Tuesday evening, to adopt measures for the extension of the Eighth- ...
lead_paragraph: THE EXTENSION OF THE EIGHT-AVENUE RAILROAD TO HARLEM. -- A meeting of citizens of the Twelfth Ward was held at the Lyon Brewery, on One hundred and Tenth-street, Tuesday evening, to adopt measures for the extension of the Eighth-avenue Railroad to Harlem. An association was organized called the Twelfth Ward West End Improvement Association, to further the object of the meeting, and for the general advancement of the interests of the Ward, and of the northwestern sections of the City. The following officers of the Association were elected, and a committee was appointed to carry out the objects of the meeting: THOMAS MANSON, President; Wm. Dunning. Robert Marshal, David S. Jackson, Jr., S.A. Dixon, Vice-Presidents; E. Bernheimer, Treasurer: Alex. Lewis, D.A. Knapp, Secretaries; W.E. Waring, Sergeant-at-Arms.

abstract: Nichols, Superintendant; Appeal for Aid to Contrabands
snippet: Nichols, Superintendant; Appeal for Aid to Contrabands
lead_paragraph: Suddenly one hundred thousand of emancipated slaves appeal to Northern benevolence. Some ask for clothing -- some want food. Large numbers are old, infirm, diseased, and require homes and medical aid. Then comes the ignorance of these thousands appealing to humanity to send them teachers and books; while their wrong views of Bible morality is urgently call for the labors of the missionary. That there is a willingness on the part of the philanthropic North to aid in this humane work, and give liberal aid, we can ask for no better evidence of the fact than the numbers of boxes and barrels that go out on every steamer or railroad car from our great centres of trade for the purpose of relieving the destitution of this class in the several points where they are gathered in the South as they have come inside the Union lines.

abstract: Newark, N. J., De Hart's Factory; two killed
snippet: Newark, N. J., De Hart's Factory; two killed
lead_paragraph: A frightful boiler explosion took place yesterday morning, about 11 o'clock, at the hatchet and edge tool manufactory of Mr. CHARLES A. DEHART, No. 60 Adams-street, Newark, N.J. The boiler was about 25 feet long, and the explosion shot the main portion of it, with the force of a thunderbolt, through the end of the boiler-room across a vacant lot adjoining, entirely through a building used as a soap manufactory, through a stable on the same premises, and nearly across another vacant lot, in which it was finally deposited. The engineer, who was named WILLIAM BLAKE, was sitting near the end of the boiler, and was carried with it through the wall of the engine-room and into the soap manufactory on the next lot. He was terribly bruised and burnt, and cannot possibly survive. The boiler also struck, in its passage through the latter building, the proprietor, Mr. MILES MURPHY, who happened to be the only person in the building. Mr. MURPHY was dashed to fragments by the terrible force of the blow. The boiler carried the remains of Mr. MURPHY, before it through the stable, when it also killed a horse, and carried the body of the animal with it in its dreadful flight.

abstract: Magazines for February
snippet: Magazines for February
lead_paragraph: -- If the February number of Harper's does not delight children, it will only be because they do not like picture-books. It has no less than five illustrated articles J. Ross BROWNE, that excellent historian, artist, poet and lecturer, leading off with a second paper of his "Californian in Iceland." If it were not quaint, and funny, and instructive, and as chastely humorous in illustration as in text, we should know at once that some other Brown than him whose prefix is "J. Ross," wrote it, that it was the work of some Brown, who is not in the habit of spelling his name with an e. "Doctor Hawley," the second illustrated article, by J.W. DE FOREST, opens well, and we look with pleasureable anticipation for the "party of the second part" to make its appearance. Miss EVANS' story of "Romola" develops a livelier interest with each successive chapter, and promises to prove a bright and glowing exception to most stories of Italian life whose scenes are laid in the past. CHARLES NORDHOFF makes a most successful "Tilt at the Woman's Question," and succeeds in unhorsing a great many old opinions, and sending a multitude of rather Pagan prejudices rolling in the dust.

abstract: Letter on Retirement from Albany Evening Journal
snippet: Letter on Retirement from Albany Evening Journal
lead_paragraph: PATRONS, FRIENDS AND READERS: My interest in, and connection with the Albany Evening Journal, as proprietor and editor, terminates with the present sheet; and but that custom sanctions, if it does not call for parting words, nothing would remain but to say -- Farewell!

abstract: The National Democratic primary meetings for the election of three delegates from each Brooklyn Ward and County town were held on Tuesday evening, and passed off in an orderly manner. In the Tenth and Twelfth Wards two tickets were run, and there was considerable excitement in consequence. The regular Democrats are to hold their primaries hereafter. It appears to be understood that the Nationals are to have the nominations for Sheriff and Street Commissioner, and the Regulars are to have the choice of the Mayor, two Superintendents of the Poor, and whatever other candidates there may be for election next Fall. The prominent contestants for Sheriff are Mr. JOHN J. WHITE and JOHN MCNAMEE, and for Mayor, Mr. BENJAMIN PRINCE is spoken of, although there will be other candidates, doubtless, before the Conventions are held.

abstract: Proposed Expulsion from the Senate
snippet: Proposed Expulsion from the Senate
lead_paragraph: If the United States Senate has any genuine self-respect, it will vindicate it by the summary expulsion of Senator SAULSBURY, of Delaware. A more outrageous indignity was never committed upon a deliberative body than was his conduct on Tuesday when called to order. In styling the President of the United States by name an "imbecile," he not only put himself on a level with the lowest pot-house blackguard, but commuted a gross breach of the rules. The Vice-President did nothing less than absolute duty in calling him to order. The Delaware Senator contumaciously and contemptuously refused to heed that call. The Vice-President, under the rules, had no alternative then but to order the Sergeant-at-Arms to take him into custody. In drawing his revolver -- a weapon which no man worthy of respect ever carries into a legislative body -- upon the officer, Mr. SAULSBURY defied the authority of the Senate; and all of his subsequent behavior, both in word and act, was to the highest degree "in contempt." It is hard to conceive how any man accustomed to gentlemanly associations could so play the bully anywhere. That a Senator of the United States should do it in the Senate of the United States is a thing till now altogether unheard of. We look in vain for something in palliation. Nothing of a personal character had been previously uttered to irritate and provoke. The debate had been perfectly cool and orderly. The Senator himself had held the floor for a considerable time before he launched out into his vulgarity. As there was no prior provocation, so there was no subsequent apology -- not a word that denoted regret. Even after he had had twenty-four hours to reflect upon his conduct, his only language was that of contemptuous defiance. "I have no favor to ask," comprised all that he had to say on the subject.

abstract: A WRESTLING MATCH FOR $1,400. -- A wrestling match for $1,400, has been arranged, to take place in Jersey City one week from next Saturday, between Mr. FREDERICK BUNNELL, of Chenango County, New-York, and a young man from Connecticut, who is reported to be a champion wrestler, and has never yet been thrown. The parties wrestled a few days since for $200 a side, but neither of them were thrown, and at that time the second match was made. Mr. BUNNELL is a large property owner in Chenango County, and a prominent man, at present holding the position of Supervisor.

abstract: Gen. Hooker
snippet: Gen. Hooker
lead_paragraph: One of the worst features in our army of late has been the habit of certain high officers of publicly criticising the military ability, the military plans, and the movements or projected movements of their Commanding General. The letter we published from Washington, on Tuesday, mentioned, as the primary cause of the failure of BURNSIDE's late advance, the insubordination of some of his Generals, who went about denouncing the movement before it had been begun, while it was in progress, and after it had been abandoned, in presence of their subordinates, and of all who chose to listen. Of course, it is impossible that any Commander or any operation should prove successful under such circumstances. Any disparaging remark of an officer concerning his Chief will nearly always be known even to every private soldier within an hour after its utterance, and repetition of such remarks must either destroy the soldier's respect for their utterer, or his confidence in the leader to whom they are applied; and in either case it will produce demoralization. Even a poor General, with a bad plan, often achieves a brilliant success if he is heartily sustained by his subordinates; but genius itself cannot rear an edifice that may not tumble in confusion if the workmen are unfaithful to the designs, and receive orders only to criticise or evade them.
headline: {'main': 'Discipline Among Army Officers.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Discipline Among Army Officers.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Address to Troops on Battle of Hartville
snippet: Address to Troops on Battle of Hartville
lead_paragraph: -- Capt. W.J. PALMER, of the Anderson Troop, of Pennsylvania, who was taken prisoner by the rebels some time since, has escaped from the South, by ways and means which he does not think it prudent to expose at present. He does not seem at all disposed to justify the action of the Troop in refusing to go into action when ordered to do so by Gen. ROSECRANS. In a card published by the Philadelphia Press the Captain says: "The old Troop was recruited for Gen. ROBERT ANDERSON, but before it was fully organized, both he and Gen. SHERMAN, his successor -- who had, on taking command, also chosen the old Troop as his escort -- had been relieved, and were followed by Gen. BUELL, who, only because it suited him, ratified the choice of his predecessors. In the present case, Gen. ROSECRANS, who had a perfect right to choose his escort, did not, it appears, select the Anderson Cavalry. Everyman in it knew when he joined the regiment that it was to be attached to Gen. BUELL's headquarters, as it would undoubtedly have been. But it the War Department or the President chose to remove that General, the men had no right to believe that they would descend as a legacy to his successor -- who was yet unknown as such -- although there was a reasonable probability that the same qualities which induced Gen. BUELL to select them for the post of honor would influence him who succeeded. This only was beyond question. Every man knew that he was taking an oath to serve the United States for three years or the war, to obey his superior officers, and to fight the rebels, which, if done well, would earn them as high honor as this world can give."

abstract: In the case of The People vs. Joel B. Ferguson, for obtaining $1,000 from CATHERINE CARTER by false pretences, the jury, on first retiring, stood 7 for conviction and 5 for acquittal. After discussing the subject for five or six hours, they agreed to compromise the matter by rendering a verdict of "guilty," with a strong recommendation of the prisoner to the mercy of the Court. After the verdict was announced, the Judge informed Mr. FERGUSON, if he expected the Court to exercise clemency in the case, he must bring the $1,000 into Court, on Saturday, and return it to the claimant. The prisoner replied that it would be utterly impossible for him to do this, for he had not a dollar in the world. The Judge then said that his friends must do it for him. After the adjournment of the Court, the jury had some conversation with the prisoner, during which it was suggested by one of their number that the Church to which he belonged ought to assist him in this emergency, and, if they would do so, it would be very easy to raise the $1.000. The juror said that, although not a member of the Church, he was ready to subscribe $10 toward it. Other jurors immediately made similar offers, and before they left the courtroom $50 was subscribed by the jury. If the money should be raised, as it doubtless will be, the defendant will probably be discharged with a nominal fine, and thus this unpleasant affair, which has excited so much bad blood and brought so much scandal upon the Church, will be settled, if not to the entire satisfaction of all, certainly not to the very serious injury of any.

abstract: Foreign, Horace Greeley and Jewett Working for; Favoring Foreign Intervention
snippet: Foreign, Horace Greeley and Jewett Working for; Favoring Foreign Intervention
lead_paragraph: The peril of foreign intervention is one which has overhung the nation from the very beginning of the war. If we can trust the assurances of the State Department, and the indications of current events, this peril seems for the present to be overpast. The French Emperor's attempt to secure a joint mediation with England and Russia in our domestic dispute, proved a failure. How complete that failure was, -- how definite was the refusal with which it was met, and how permanent may be the temper which prompted it, we have yet to learn. But we are warranted by the official advices which have thus far reached the public, in believing that the attitude of our Government and of the country toward any foreign Power that may attempt intervention in our affairs, is one of distinct and unequivocal hostility. The whole world has been given to understand that this is precisely the one thing which our people will not for an instant tolerate, -- and that if any foreign nation attempts in any way, singly or in concert with others, to control by dictation, by force or by unsought advice, the future fate of this Republic, that nation will be instantly met by the peremptory and, if needful, the armed resistance of the loyal people of the United States, without distinction of party.

abstract: on the Monitors
snippet: on the Monitors
lead_paragraph: There is no more important question, both in its bearings upon permanent national defence and upon the quelling of the present rebellion, than that of the seagoing qualities of Capt. ERICSSON's new style of iron-clads -- the Monitors. The first of the Monitors foundered in a storm, while the next two that went to sea, the Passaic and Montauk, rode out a gale which a dispatch from the Navy Department described as "one of the most terrific lately known off Hatteras;" but which Capt. WORDEN, the Commander of the Montauk, is stated, by our South Carolina correspondent, to have described as at no time heavier than what sailors call a "double-reefed topsail breeze." The first real test case was with the Weehawken, commanded by Capt. RODGERS, which left this harbor on the 18th inst., and concerning the voyage of which Capt. ERICSSON has sent us a letter which we publish this morning.

abstract: Appointment, Gen. Hooker's Chief of Staff
snippet: Appointment, Gen. Hooker's Chief of Staff
lead_paragraph: We see that Gen. HOOKER has appointed Gen. BUTTERFIELD his Chief of Staff. This is a high honor well earned. Gen. B. is one of the very best officers whom the volunteer movement has brought into the service. Though not a graduate of West Point, he has a thorough knowledge of military matters, and has written a text-book on the subject, which is conceded by military men to be the best of its kind accessible. He has taken an active and efficient part in all the engagements of the Army of the Potomac, and has shown everywhere conspicuous personal gallantry and a most admirable handling of his command. He will discharge all the duties of his new and responsible position with ability and success.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, the bill to establish a system of postal money orders was reported back from the Post-office Committee, with a recommendation that it do not pass. Mr. CLARK, of New-Hampshire, offered a preamble and resolution embodying a statement of the conduct of Mr. SAULSBURY, of Delaware, on Tuesday, and declaring him expelled from the Senate. It was laid over under the rule. Mr. WALL, of New-Jersey, offered a resolution, which was adopted, directing the Military Committee to inquire into the case of "Zarvona, the French Lady," confined in Fort Lafayette, and said to be insane. The President was called upon for all orders issued by the Secretaries of War and the Treasury, regarding a prohibition of the exportation of arms, etc., from the United States to Mexico, and relative to the exportation of articles contraband of war for the use of the French army. A bill for the encouragement of enlistments, &c., was introduced by Mr. WILSON, of Massachusetts, and referred to the Military Committee. The Invalid Pension bill was passed. The Army Appropriation bill was passed, with an amendment making an appropriation for the improvement of the navigation of the Fox and Wisconsin Rivers. The Consular and Diplomatic Appropriation bill was debated, but not disposed of. After an Executive Session, the Senate adjourned.

abstract: The New Pirate, the Florida
snippet: The New Pirate, the Florida
lead_paragraph: The new Anglo-rebel privateering steamer Florida (or Oreto) has begun her career of destruction in flaming style. She sailed out of the harbor of Mobile on the 16th instant, in presence of seven of our blockading vessels, and chased by the fastest one of them; but she escaped, and next day captured and burned the Boston brig Estelle; on the 20th she entered the harbor of Havana and coaled; on the morning of the 22d (Thursday of last week) she left Havana, and gave chase to an American bark which escaped, but on the afternoon of the same day, when near Matanzas, she captured and burnt the brig Windward; next morning she captured and burnt another brig, and shortly after captured two more brigs, one of which she burnt and the other sunk. All this was precisely one week's work; how many more of our vessels this piratical rover may have captured and burnt during the seven days that have elapsed since the 23d, we shall probably not be long in knowing. From the statements made, it would appear that the Florida is quite as fast a sailer as her compeer, the Alabama, and it is evident that Capt. MAFFIT is as venturesome a knave as Capt. SEMMES. Of course the capturing and burning of unarmed and unsuspecting trading craft in the West India waters is not a work that contains in it a single characteristic of courage, or that requires much skill; and the fact that the Florida depended entirely upon her speed for safety from the guns of our vessel that started off Mobile in pursuit -- and the further fact that when about to leave Havana, her commander had to obtain the assistance of the Spanish officials to enable him to escape one of our gunboats, and that he also obtained permission from the same functionaries to pass the guard-ship after nightfall, so as to evade our cruisers -- abundantly shows that MAFFIT was not willing to test the metal of his ship with that of any of our armed vessels. In this respect the Florida has begun in precisely such a careeras has been that of the Alabama.

abstract: The news from the Mississippi River this morning is important. Gen. McCLERNAND has landed his forces on the Louisiana side, five miles below the mouth of the Yazoo, and in full view of the city of Vicksburgh. At last accounts two brigades were engaged in opening the famous Cut-off, commenced by Gen. WILLIAMS last season.
lead_paragraph: The news from the Mississippi River this morning is important. Gen. McCLERNAND has landed his forces on the Louisiana side, five miles below the mouth of the Yazoo, and in full view of the city of Vicksburgh. At last accounts two brigades were engaged in opening the famous Cut-off, commenced by Gen. WILLIAMS last season. As the river is now "bank full" at Vicksburgh, there is a possibility that the enterprise may be successful, at least to the extent of permitting the passage of gunboats and transports. Gen. GRANT left Memphis on Tuesday last.

abstract: The, and its Opponents
snippet: The, and its Opponents
lead_paragraph: It was TOM PAINE, in the Revolutionary War, that said, "these are the times that try men's souls." A better man might have said it. It is so of all wars. There never was one yet which did not put to the test the stuff men are made of. The very object of war is to constrain by suffering, when constraint by reasoning is no longer possible. It is the ultima ratio -- the last resort -- purely because it is the most terrible extremity. It, of necessity, imposes trials such as human nature nowhere else encounters. The weak and the false are always sure to give way under it sooner or later. The strong and the true alone endure to its legitimate end.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, Mr. SAULSBURY, of Delaware, made an apology for his conduct on [???]sday, and action on his case was suspended. The credentials of THOMAS H. HENDRICKS, elected Senator from Indiana, were presented. A bill to facilitate transportation to Point of Rocks and Pittsburgh was referred to the Military Committee. The resolution censuring Commodore VANDERBILT and others regarding the Banks transports, was called up by Mr. HALE, who expressed the desire to erase the name of Mr. VANDERBILT. It was debated until the expiration of the morning hour. The bill to prevent and punish fraud against the United States was reported back from the Judiciary Committee. The bill to aid Missouri in the emancipation of slaves, was considered until the adjournment.

abstract: The professors and admirers of the manly art of self-defence have kept themselves for some time past particularly shady. Fights have been almost unknown, and sporting celebrities few and far between. The American Ring has, in point of fact, been under a cloud ever since the great contest for the Championship between HEENAN and SAYERS. Sundry exciting combats accomplished and matched upon the carpet...
lead_paragraph: The professors and admirers of the manly art of self-defence have kept themselves for some time past particularly shady. Fights have been almost unknown, and sporting celebrities few and far between. The American Ring has, in point of fact, been under a cloud ever since the great contest for the Championship between HEENAN and SAYERS. Sundry exciting combats accomplished and matched upon the carpet in the British Home of Boxing have, however, given a new impetus to the latent love of fisticuffs, which smoulder in the bosom of so large a class of our native and imported citizens. The results are rumors of more than one important "mill" in process of arrangement, and numerous announcements of benefits where pugilistic neophytes and artists of renown pummel each other with what are called, in a spirit of facetious technicality, "the mittens."

abstract: The additional news from Mexico which we have this morning confirms the report of the defeat of the French vanguard under BERTHIER. They numbered 4,000, and were attacked by only 800 Mexican cavalry, during a dense fog on the morning of the 18th. A convoy had also been surprised between Jalapa and Perote, and most of it captured. But the most important announcement is that 10,000 of the Mexican garrison at Puebla had sallied out and attacked a French division numbering 14,000, eight leagues from the city, completely routing them, and driving them back to Orizaba. Jalapa and Tampico have been abandoned by the French.
lead_paragraph: The additional news from Mexico which we have this morning confirms the report of the defeat of the French vanguard under BERTHIER. Jalapa and Tampico have been abandoned by the French.

lead_paragraph: The French Emperor's address to the Legislature, in so far as it relates to the American question, contains nothing calculated to modify the views of his plans and policy, to which we gave utterance a few days ago, but, on the contrary, confirms them. He desires to interfere, is satisfied of our inability to succeed in the field, is restive under the sufferings which the conflict has brought upon his own cotton operatives, and is not disposed to trouble himself much as to the effect which interference might have upon our political destiny. But in spite of all this, he shrinks from meddling in the quarrel, whether diplomatically or militarily, singlehanded. He desires to act in concert with the maritime Powers, or, in other words, as the leader and initiator of a movement in which they are to take a part; but as long as they refuse to cooperate, he confesses that he shall be obliged to wait and watch. "The great Maritime Powers not having thought it advisable to act in concert with him, he has been obliged to postpone to another suitable opportunity the offer of mediation." It is fair to conclude from this that the "suitable opportunity" will arise when the Maritime Powers shall have changed their mind.
headline: {'main': 'The French Emperor on the American Question.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The French Emperor on the American Question.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: THE BROOKLYN OLD LADIES' HOME. At the recent annual meeting of the Graham Institute, or Home for Respectable, Aged Indigent Females, situated in Washington-avenue, near DeKalb, the following officers were elected for the eusuing year; First Directress, Mrs. J.S.T. Stranahan; Second Directress, Mrs. Hosea Webster; Corresponding Secreta
lead_paragraph: THE BROOKLYN OLD LADIES' HOME. At the recent annual meeting of the Graham Institute, or Home for Respectable, Aged Indigent Females, situated in Washington-avenue, near DeKalb, the following officers were elected for the eusuing year; First Directress, Mrs. J.S.T. Stranahan; Second Directress, Mrs. Hosea Webster; Corresponding Secretary, Mrs. J.R. St. John; Recording Secretary, Mrs. Nathan Burchard; Treasurer, Mrs. David M. Stone. The present number of persons at the Home is fifty-three, in addition to six servants. Three ladies left during the year. One was dismissed and two died. The industrial character of the inmates is shown by the fact that at the late donation visit, 84 pairs of knitted hose, and 14 pairs of mittens for the soldier, were exhibited. The total receipts last year were $13,050, in which is included the bequest of $5,000 by the heirs of the late WM.H. CAREY, and a donation of $3,000 by Mrs. THOMPSON. The annual expenses were $10,503, leaving a handsome balance in the Treasury.

abstract: ARREST OF AN EXTENSIVE RECEIVER -- RECOVERY OF SEVERAL THOUSAND DOLLARS' WORTH OF STOLEN GOODS -- THE PROCEEDS OF FIVE DIFFERENT BURGLARIES. -- Detective FARLEY made the arrest, on Thursday, of a man named ABRAHAM WEINSTEN at No. 275 Sixth-street, near Avenue D, a receiver of stolen goods. A number of burglaries having been committed in the City for a few weeks past, Detective FARLEY set about ascertaining the authors of the same. On Thursday he observed a man named SNOW, a well known receiver of stolen goods going about from place to place, and followed him finally arriving at No. 275 Sixth-street. While watching this place, he observed the prisoner WEINSTEN, carrying a number of bundles into the house, and being satisfied that they were stolen property, procured the assistance of Officer SHANGLE, of the Eleventh Precinct, and overhauled the premises. The result of the descent was the arrest of WEINSTEN, and the recovery of several thousand dollar' worth of property, comprising a large quantity of Pongee silks, plate and silver ware, cloths, linen goods, black enameled morocco, &c., &c. Several parties, owners of portions of these goods, appeared at Police Headquarters and identified them. A large quantity still remain unclaimed for which owners are wanted. Among those who visited the central office were J.L. STROUB, Nos. 36 and 38 John-st.; BOUTON & SMITH, No. 656 Bowery, and HUNTER & Co., Bowery. Mr. STROUB found about $1,500 worth of the property stolen from his place a few nights since. WEINSTEN, the prisoner, is not a man known to the detectives, but is an intelligent appearing professional, and an undoubted expert at his villainous practices. Parties visiting headquarters to identify goods will have them shown to them by Sergeant YOUNG. Mr. ABRAHAM WEINSTEN, living at No. 239 Seventh street, wishes it distinctly understood that he is not the individual above referred to.

abstract: Message on Field Officers
snippet: Message on Field Officers
lead_paragraph: In a Message, on Jan. 20, to the Legislature of South Carolina, the new Governor of that State, Gen. M.L. BONHAM, earnestly recommends the repeal of the act requiring the Adjutant-General of the State to order an election for field officers of the several regiments of the First Corps of Reserves, and of such other regiments now in service, where field officers had been appointed by the Executive Council. The reason assigned for this recommendation is an absence of power to order an election for field officers of regiments transferred to the Confederate service. The Governor says that whatever opinion he may entertain as to the propriety of the field officers of these regiments being elected in the first instance, he believes it to be the true policy, under existing circumstances, to allow matters to stand as they are. He concludes his message with an injunction to harmony and concert with the Confederate Government.
