abstract: Mendota, S. S.; Launch of
snippet: Mendota, S. S.; Launch of
lead_paragraph: The new double-bow, paddle-wheel steamer Mendota was, yesterday, launched from the marine railway at TUCKER's ship-yard, Red Hook, South Brooklyn. After floating off the skids she drifted down the river, and was loose, when the steam-tug Hercules was dispatched to tow her back, which she did. The Mendota was put into the water some two weeks since, but had been receiving her copper on the railway, from which she was yesterday launched. She is one of a new fleet of twenty double-bowed paddle-wheel steamers, which were recently contracted for by the Government, and is the second afloat. Mr. HART, the able superintendent of Mr. TUCKER's yard, has turned her out in the best manner. The last batch of double-bowed vessels were not very successful -- the Cimmerone, Connernaugh, and others having absolutely failed. The Mendota has two decks -- one the spar deck, which holds the battery, and the other the berth deck, on which the quarters of the officers and men are situated. As no mention has hitherto been made of the fleet to which she belongs, we subjoin their names:

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- It will be a matter of rejoicing to the musical to hear that Signor BRIGNOLI has entirely recovered from his indisposition, and that Mr. GRAU has resolved on giving a final week of opera prior to his departure for Boston. The Academy will open on Monday, Feb. 2, with FLOTOW's popular opera of "Martha," in which Miss KELLOGG and Mlle. MORENSI will appear, supported by BRIGNOLI SUSINI and BARILI. There cannot be a doubt that Mr. GRAU will have three overflowing houses. It is a pity that the season cannot be extended, but this is impossible. The box office for the sale of seats opens to-day.

abstract: of North Carolina, Arrested for Disloyalty to the Confederacy
snippet: of North Carolina, Arrested for Disloyalty to the Confederacy
lead_paragraph: Gov. VANCE, of North Carolina, transmits to the Legislature of that State a letter received from the Secretary of War, giving the causes of the arrest of J.R. GRAVES, charged with disloyalty. The letter states that when applying to Gen. WINDER for a passport to proceed North, he represented himself as a citizen of New-York, desirous to return home, and in that character received permission. After his return to the South, he published a letter in the Richmond Enquirer on the state of public opinion in the North, which gave a most unfavorable aspect to the Southern cause and caused much comment and inquiries as to the antecedents of the writer. Gen. WINDER received several letters stating facts which gave good grounds for suspecting GRAVES to be a spy, or at least a disaffected person. An exchanged prisoner from Fortress Monroe, heard GRAVES give the Yankee officers a minute description of the war steamer building at Richmond, and, upon being shown diagrams of the Monitor, described where the Confederate steamer differed from her.

abstract: Monitors, the, at Sea and in Action; Does the War Promote Pro-Slavery Reaction; The French in Mexico
snippet: Monitors, the, at Sea and in Action; Does the War Promote Pro-Slavery Reaction; The French in Mexico
lead_paragraph: We have read with attention the very original and able speech of Mr. CONWAY, in the House of Representatives, in support of his resolutions for a cessation of hostilities, and an acknowledgment of the Confederacy. The fact that his was the only vote in favor of the resolutions does not detract from their intrinsic merit, if such they have. What influence mere party considerations had upon the decision, or the question of opportuneness, without reference to intrinsic merit at all, it is impossible to say, inasmuch as no further discussion occurred. The primary argument, however, is too important in the present unsettled state of the public mind, to be ignored. It should be recognized and confuted, before it can do mischief.

abstract: Complimentary Dinner to in New-York
snippet: Complimentary Dinner to in New-York
lead_paragraph: A complimentary dinner was given, on Thursday evening, to Maj.-Gen. POPE, by Mayor Opdyke, William A. Hall, George P. Wilson, William Curtis Noyes, Lyman Tremain, and twenty other wellknown gentlemen of this City. The affair was designed to be entirety private, and the arrangements were so well conducted, that Mr. DELMONICO, who prepared the dinner, did not know to whom it was to be given until the party began to assemble; and we hear that he was not a little disturbed when he learned the fact, alleging, with some vehemence, that he should have been informed of the name of the distinguished guest, in order that he might have undertaken such extra preparations as he would have been glad to make. The dinner was, nevertheless, furnished in really excellent style, and was fully enjoyed. The Mayor did the honors of the table with his usual urbanity, and was assisted by Surveyor ANDREWS; while the good humor, frankness and modest dignity of Gen. POPE were extremely creditable to him. The occasion was one of unusual interest.

abstract: The Navy Department has received information of the capture of the English steamer Antona, direct from England via Havana, by the gunboat Pocahontas, on the 8th instant. She had on board a valuable cargo of munitions of war, and was first discovered by the blockading force off Mobile, but was captured by the Pocahontas 30 miles south southeast of Cape San Blas.

lead_paragraph: We publish this morning, as given by our special correspondent with the Banks Expedition, a detailed narrative of Gen. abstract: A full congregation of learned divines, of theological students, and of members of literary and scientific societies, collected at the Mercer-street Presbyterian Church, yesterday afternoon, on the occasion of the obsequies of the late Prof. ROBINSON.
lead_paragraph: A full congregation of learned divines, of theological students, and of members of literary and scientific societies, collected at the Mercer-street Presbyterian Church, yesterday afternoon, on the occasion of the obsequies of the late Prof. ROBINSON. There were large representations from the Union Theological Seminary, Columbia College, the New-York University, the Free Academy, and the Historical, Geographical and Ethnological Societies. Seldom, indeed, have so many men of note in the Metropolis congregated on a similar occasion in this City. The pulpit was occupied by Rev. Mr. BOOTH, pastor of the church; Rev. Dr. SKINNER, Rev. Dr. SPRING, Rev. Chancellor FERRIS, and Rev. Dr. Cox. The funeral cortege, which had formed at the residence of the decased, reached the church shortly after 2 P.M., the following gentlemen acting as pallbearers: Revs. J.J. OWEN, R.D. HITCHCOCK, N. MCLEAN, HENRY B. SMITH, ALMON MERWIN and H.H. HADLEY, and Messrs. CHAS. BUTLER and J.P. KIRKLAND. As the body was borne to the front of the altar, the choir, consisting of Mr. MUGER, organist; Mrs. BARCLAY, alto; Miss FLINT, soprano; Mr. CUSHMAN, basso, and Mr. FARR, tenor, sang the anthem. "I heard a voice from Heaven." Rev. Dr. SPRING then offered prayer, and Rev. Dr. FERRIS read appropriate passages of Scripture.

abstract: On Saturday last, a man named ALBERT W. SINCLAIR, who also passes under the alias of Carrington, was arrested on Third-street, in the neighborhood of the African Church, by Detective FRED SHAFFER, of the Eastern District, in the same tenement from which WEBSTER, the spy was taken. About nine months since, SINCLAIR, who, at that time, paused for a Lieutenant in the Yankee Army, and professed to be a deserter, appeared in Richmond, and was committed to Castle Godwin as a spy. After being there a considerable time he succeeded in purloining himself on a green sentinel as an officer of the prison, and not only liberated himself, but passed out on his own authority the notorious Col. ADLER, a fellow-prisoner, who succeeded in making his way to the North. The officers heard nothing of SINCLAIR's whereabouts until a few days ago, when they were privately informed that he was in the city, and took measures to effect his arrest, in which they were successful, as above related. It is believed that he has been backward and forward from this city to the North several times since he escaped, and been thus useful to the enemy as a spy. When near the corner of Fifth and Broad streets, on his way to prison, he broke from the officers, and fled precipitately up Broad till arriving at second-street, down which he retreated rapidly till near the Abos House, when he was headed off, and again taken in custody. While the fugitive was attempting to escape, three shuts were fired at him, but without effect. He was taken to Castle Thunder for trial before Court-martial.

abstract: There is probably, not a ferry in the world which, from unpretending commencement, has increased so rapidly in sterling value, in accommodations and comforts for passengers, and as an adornment of the city, as the Fulton ferry, which, for several years, has been under the control of the Union Ferry Company. Its boats are unequaled for strength and safety now, and hardly a year passes during which the surplus on the capital invested, over and above the 10 per cent. which the law allows the stockholders to draw, does not furnish the means for some material increase in the ferry property. The last improvement, and, aside from the boats, the greatest yet made, is the erection of an imposing iron ferry-house at the foot of Fulton-street, this City.

abstract: THE BOILER EXPLOSION AT NEWARK VERDICT OF THE CORONER'S JURY. The investigation into the cause of the recent lamentable boiler explosion in Newark was concluded on Thursday night. A very large number of witnesses were examined, whose evidence was contradictory. The testimony
lead_paragraph: THE BOILER EXPLOSION AT NEWARK -- VERDICT OF THE CORONER's JURY. -- The investigation into the cause of the recent lamentable boiler explosion in Newark was concluded on Thursday night. A very large number of witnesses were examined, whose evidence was contradictory. The testimony of Messrs. HEWES & PHILLIPS, who made the boiler, showed that it was six years old. They said it was made of the best quality of Pennsylvania charcoal iron, and in their opinion it was in good order. The testimony of experts went to prove that the boiler had an extraordinary pressure upon it, which was corroborated by the evidence of a Mr. CADMUS, who swore that he was in the boiler-room about two hours before the explosion, when there was 102 pounds of steam on. He called the attention of BLAKE, the engineer, to the fact, who told him that he was compelled to carry high steam in order to raise the water. The wife and mother-in-law of Mr. BLAKE testified that he was a sober man, and that he had often told them the boiler leaked, and was not fit to run with. The jury returned the following verdict: "That MILES MURPHY and WM. BLAKE came to their death from a defective boiler, and an over-pressure of steam on said boiler; and that the jury cannot, from the character of the evidence before them, attach blame to any person or persons on account of the explosion of said boiler." The scene of the accident reveals the most tearful traces of the explosion. The building through which the boiler passed is completely pulverized, and one of the flues inside the boiler is flattened so that it looks like a single plate. Pieces of the unfortunate man (Mr. MURPHY) who was killed in the soap manufactory are yet picked up in the lot where the boiler lies.

lead_paragraph: Although Maj.-Gen. BURNSIDE, since his arrival and during his stay in New-York, has requested that no public demonstration should be tendered to him, preferring rather to enjoy repose after his late campaign, yet he could not resist the application of a Committee of the boys of the above School, better known as Ward School in Twenty-fourth-street, to pay them a visit. The Committee having waited on him at the Fifth-avenue Hotel, the General, at their request, and that of Mrs. BURNSIDE, consented.

abstract: Warm Winters are not considered healthy. They are believed to lay the foundation of an interminable catalogue of diseases, and to be the certain forerunners of some frightful epidemic or another.  There may possibly be some show of reason for the prevalence of these opinions. Whatever is unsea
lead_paragraph: Warm Winters are not considered healthy. They are believed to lay the foundation of an interminable catalogue of diseases, and to be the certain forerunners of some frightful epidemic or another. There may possibly be some show of reason for the prevalence of these opinions. Whatever is unseasonable -- therefore unnatural -- must have more or less of a pernicious effect on everything that comes under its influence; and the weather is no exception to the rule. But popular opinions too often degenerate into popular fallacies, and because the plague or cholera once happened to follow a mild and genial January there is no ground for supposing that such will always be the case.

abstract: ADDISON, GAGE  Co. began to  cut ice on Spy Pond to-day. The blocks are about a foot in thickness, and the weather is very favorable for securing a crop, as the workmen do not suffer from cold, and the open surface of the pond from which the ice is housed does not freeze over at night, so as to delay operations. The ice is ten inches
lead_paragraph: ADDISON, GAGE & CO. began to cut ice on Spy Pond to-day. The blocks are about a foot in thickness, and the weather is very favorable for securing a crop, as the workmen do not suffer from cold, and the open surface of the pond from which the ice is housed does not freeze over at night, so as to delay operations. The ice is ten inches thick on Jamaica Pond, and the residents in the vicinity are filling their ice-houses. On Spot Pond the ice is thirteen inches thick, and many tons are now daily carted therefrom to Boston. There is an abundance of ice from thirteen to fifteen inches in thickness on ponds within thirty miles of Boston, from whence a supply for export can readily be had.

abstract: The canvass for the Senatorship and the removal of clogs to legislation, by the organization of the Assembly, have caused a marked influx of strangers. Although the Senatorial question is one of much immediate interest, and though only four days intervene before the day fixed for going into joint ballot, there is as yet little or no tangibility or drift to the views of members or Senators on candidates. There was an informal gathering of some 30 or 40 members last evening, which adjourned, however, before the question of candidates had been very extensively gone into. That sterling patriot of the old Democratic stock, DANIEL S. DICKINSON, should be added to the list of gentlemen heretofore given in connection with the Senatorship. His services in behalf of the country are held in high estimation by the Union representation, as they are by his fellow-citizens throughout the State; and his eminent qualifications for the position, the duties of which would not be new to him, are universally acknowledged. The state of public sentiment in the country is eminently suggestive of considerations outside of strict party lines. The high claims of the country should always take precedence of these of party, -- and never before were such claims so great or pressing as at the present moment. Party services, though not inconsistent with, should be held subordinate to the higher claims of the country. Capacity, experience and unquestioned patriotism should, and I do not doubt will, be the qualifications first sought for. The State has an obligation to the country, in this hour of its trial and gloom, to be discharged before those of a mere party character. The Government has a claim for support overriding all others, and in discharging this obligation, and in responding to this claim, not only experience, but high capacity, vigor, firmness, and a combination of qualities that will cause the Empire State to be felt and honored not only in the highest branch of the National Legislature, but in every branch of the Government where her voice can reach, should be selected. Fortunately, the list of eminent names, as already given, affords more than one combining in a large degree these qualifications; and with this principle held in view as the standard of action, public expectation will suffer no disappointment.

abstract: Indians, Proposed Colonization of
snippet: Indians, Proposed Colonization of
lead_paragraph: It has long been apparent that the administration of our Indian affairs is involved in serious difficulties. The Government, with praiseworthy intention, has organized a system intended to secure the exercise of a patriarchal supervision, while it leaves the different tribes in possession of national independence. For the lands which they do not need, it pays them liberal prices, and rigidly prohibits encroachments upon their Reservations by their white neighbors. It provides by law for their protection against the evils apt to be inflicted by unprincipled traders who swarm in their midst, and in whose hands a gallon of whisky is made a key which equally unlocks Pandora's box and gives admittance to their ill-guarded treasures.
headline: {'main': 'Colonizing the Western Indians and Selling Their Lands.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Colonizing the Western Indians and Selling Their Lands.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}
